headline: Worst job I've ever had
pros: Team mates are really friendly (it was not thanks to the company, just my team was a bunch of good people). Good salaries and benefits.
cons:
People do not get promoted easily. There are so many hidden regulations to be promoted, which were not shared during the offer. Developers must have minimum of 2 years of exceeding expectations (4 out of 5) rating. And they must have been working for the company for 2 years. And first year review will not go higher than met expectation (3). And it is a rule. So you have be in the company for at least 3 years to be promoted.
They expect developers to work extra hours for free. If you ask for compensation for extra hours, management will ask you to not to joke and be professional. There are compensatory leaves for extra hours, but they come with extra terms and conditions. It is up to the manager to let you to take the comp: leaves and company does not comply them. Means they will not encashed.
When I was working, the manager had scheduled a meeting @6pm (working hours are 8.30 to 5.30) on every Friday to tell him what I would finish during weekends. And asked scrum master to make sure that I finished those tasks.
There was no growth in the career. I was stuck working on old technologies.

headline: Cutting costs + overworking employees is not a winning formula for anyone
pros:
+ Interesting work and you could learn a lot from people not just in your department but from others as well. 

+ Good benefits, 401(k), 15 days vacation + personal + sick time at entry-level. 

+ Working with clients and other colleagues from all different corners of the world, you get to learn about all different kinds of industries.
cons:
+Atrocious work/life balance, long hours, overwhelming pressure to meet deadlines. There was almost never a week where I didn't work overtime and urgent matters would get brought without prior notice. 

+ Inadequate training and short-staffed teams, while cuts to my department continued and experienced employees either left or transferred departments. 

+ Inefficient processes and systems make an already time-consuming job even slower because you have to wait for the systems to catch-up, or 

+ Expected to be responsive to other teams and departments outside of regular business hours when our department was only supposed to be 8-6. 

+ Payroll is outsourced so getting a hold of people if there's an issue or you have a question is difficult.

headline: Work/Life Balance
pros:
Since the pandemic, the company has embraced a work from home policy. They recognized that non-client facing employees can be trusted to perform away from their office desk. And they also realized that productivity went way up. 
They also began offering workshops and mind-space programs to help employees adjust to the new norm and cope with isolation from the pandemic.
cons: While the CEO is making changes within the organization to better execute, I.e., moving executives around, etc., there are still managers who have been with the firm for 15+ years and who have old managerial styles with little leadership skills.

headline: Nepotistic, corrupt and un-meritocratic
pros: The name carries you a long way

Management will quite literally fabricate falsehoods to justify low ratings, bonuses etc. if they don't like you, and will completely omit even the most value-creating contributions.

headline: hidden rules masked by "family corporate mindset"
pros: Vacations and working hours not extremely pushed as in consulting
cons: The corporate mindset is all around "family and people" instead the hierarchy and hidden rules (including promoting the ones who shake hands instead of meritocracy) is predominant. People tends to stay for several years and tends to not promote or teach new joiners (seems like they are jelous of their Clients or Assets, that are not theirs since all is blocked within the bank). These factors lead to unconfortable situations in which managers tends to feel like "princesses", untouchable and un-criticizable. TL;DR. Keep your idea for yourself, and do your job. In this huge corporation nothing changes and no one is fundamental. New idea of "digitalization" is only creating more fear in employees (really touchable) that could be fired since they are no more necessary, (that was not my case, given different business division)

cons:
Management puts saving money and cost cutting measures over improving experience and satisfaction. 

Very little training - from the service group up to management. No one has any idea what’s going on or how to properly get anything done.

401k match is 6% but only to an extent. Maxes very low.

headline: Good opportunity to start a career But don't stay too long.
pros:
-Good way to start your career.If you need to get a foot in the industry and get your licenses, this may be a good first step.
-Stable job.
-Good overall culture.
-Manageable work life balance.
-Overtime payment.
cons:
-Once you are in there is no growth in career and personal growth
-Minimal (0 to maybe 3k max) to no pay raise each year even if you work hard. Even if you get more licenses and certifications. If you want a promotion you have to participate in office politics. 
-Bonus is Flat % that in the same rank gets. Standard deviation is about +/- 0.5%, They make a huge profit and only give as high as 1 month pay as bonus.
-Performance reviews do nothing and wont help. Managers will always under score you.
-Lack of transparency.They provide zero direction and guidance. Expect you to learn on your own. Even on how to their systems
-High turnover rate. You will see coworkers leave for a higher paying job after 1-2 years if they don't get a promotion. Those that stay are most likely there because they are happy with the salary.

headline: Try to avoid if you can.
pros: Good name to have on a resume I guess. But at what cost?
cons: I was sold on an analytical role at the company, when I really got there I felt a little lied too. In reality the role was much more operational. Also, the archaic systems make it impossible to do any real analytics work. A lot of systems were built by external 3rd parties, and as a result they are overly complicated and inefficient. If your someone working in analytics do yourself a favor and look elsewhere. I was lucky enough to get out before wasting much time there. I had no experience in Finance but the amount of meetings these people have its astounding to me that any real work gets done. I sat in on a 5+ hour meeting my first week there. What could possibly be so important to talk about for 5 hours? The answer is nothing. I could hear the stress in everyones voice, I could tell that my manager was being overworked, nobody seemed to be enjoying themselves. They would just sit in meetings for hours and hours talking about how everything is awesome and the numbers are great etc. -- lots of red flags and life is short folks. Jobs and money are nice but not if they suck the life out of you.

headline: Worst company I have ever worked for
pros: Coffee and water is free
cons: I cannot express. There is absolutely nothing good about working here. The pay is 50% less than any other company, you are belittled by management. You are told you are not good enough no matter what you do. This company gets at least 5,000 complaints by clients every week. Every time you answer the phone it is a 70/30 chance it is a complaint. Management does not care about you, they only care about making themselves look good to directors. Upward mobility is definitely not even remotely an option here. UBS loves to pigeonhole their employees to the point where they leave. Any furthering education is on your own expense. Bonus’s and commission aren’t even enough to pay your fuel to get to the office every day. Trust me, don’t go here. If you work here, leave and go work for a NYC top 5 investment bank and make 6 figure base and stop waiting your time.

headline: A way to get a foot in the industry, and move somewhere else asap
pros: If you need to get a foot in the industry and get your licenses, this may be a good first step.
cons: Depending on what team you get put on, who your manager is etc, you may have a different experience, but in general there is a crushing case load and high stress and low pay. No one can keep up with the volume of work, which causes tons of mistakes to clients and tons of complaints coming in your phone and inbox. You'll get yelled at daily, spend tons of time filing complaints, and there is no support to find answers. They promised a structured training class, but there was basically no training. There's an impossible maze of policies and procedures to navigate through, managers don't have answers to the complicated issues that come up all day, you're left for yourself trying skype co workers to find a half way right answer to anything. If you genuinely care about giving good service to clients, you will find this place absolutely frustrating.

headline: Nope
pros:
I don't know if there are any but I will say I don't believe this is representative of the whole bank but more the department I work in.

Oh, I just remembered: great 'UBS University' opportunities if you want to learn a new skill etc.
cons:
UBS as a whole are losing great talent due to the way they figure salary. Salary, bonuses and Salary increases aren't as transparent as they like to claim it is. Managers make up the rules as they go along to give promotions to their 'friends'. 

Lack of reward for hard work - For example, if you find you're doing more than your colleague on the same team and find out they are earning more than you, you can ask for a salary increase but you would be wasting your time due to the reasons mentioned above. Even if you decide to apply for another role in the same company. You could go from an analyst to a manager and STILL be on the same salary till that annual promotions discussion and even then, you might not get a salary increase then.

Lets keep things clear: people work to live, not live to work. This company will continue to lose great talent

headline: good company to work for

headline: Jira Ticket Machine, toxic culture, dont work there
pros:
Base salary is competitive.
Depending where you are, UBS has highly skilled employees and you can (and have to) learn quickly.
cons:
No wedding congratulations, no card for the birth of our child, no happy birthday (never, not even an email), no good bye card or wishes.  That describes how they care about employees and what happened to me.

Average Bonus salary was around 50k CHF. If you work in IT as an employee and are a normal performer, you get maybe 4-5k max. That means 95-96% have been distrubuted before it reaches the normal employees.

Be ready to work cut off from business, working on jira tickets one after another.

UBS still has forced ranking. That means some team members will always be "low" or "under" -perfomer.
Be ready to be ranked worse as a new joiner or if you switch teams. 

You will meet older employees that dont give you any responsiblity or share all they know (seen it all over the place) because they are afraid of a bad rating and this fear became part of their DNA. 

Also this enforced fears lead to information hiding and a general elbow mentality is common practice. 

Also most people try to stay under the radar and not speak out if something does not feel not right regarding inter-personal or organisational problem areas.

Mobbing happens and stays undetected and unsanctioned as the ones who mob can be higher ranked, well connected managers or leaders who can and are ready damage your reputation substantially if you speak out.

At the moment: STAY AWAY no matter what they offer

headline: Hard to progress

headline: Excellent for young talents - after that, leave the bank for better salary
pros: As an ex Allround intern and current UBS JUNA talent (both young talent programs) I can really recommend UBS for young people to get in the bank industry. Salary during the program is top. Many training, workshop and rotation opportunities.
cons: It depends on the region, team, business division one is doing the program in - there are really nice teams but some exploiting and toxic ones as well. Most of young talents are used to fill in gaps where teams are understaffed and where a full headcount is too expensive. There is a salary range for any ex young talent which is absolutely not competitive.

cons: Business units are incentivized to not communicate; people are in leadership roles with no ability to lead; corporate structure is overly complex; people are overworked, making executing projects a grassroots endeavor over top-down; systems are unbearably complex; there is no coherent operational environment, so most things are prioritized based on who is being the most unreasonable about their deliverables not being completed.

headline: Innovative leadership in the company, good perks, remote work, not many interesting projects

- Multinational corporation, it's also in cons
- CEO is a great person for this position, sustainable growth from last year is somehow related to the trends and direction he sets up, he listens to others and replies to employees being very open-minded
cons:
- Some technologies and platforms are outdated, management doesn't understand it
- It's not a startup environment, it would be a challenge to ask for the usage of better technologies and things end up with well-known but lagging and outdated techs
- It's hard to find/change a team if the start doesn't look fine
- Projects can be not such as it's expected
- Multinational corporation, sometimes the difference in time zone and culture can be not an easy thing to adjust, as well some replies are infeasible to obtain
- It's unclear whether you can have benefits or any raise after all efforts

3. Minimum salary increase. Once I received less than a dollar/hr hike with decent ratings.
4. No recognition for hard work. No one cares ( including the team manager and the senior manager) how much one work hard it is never enough to get recognized and good ratings at the end. 
5. I have met quite a few colleagues sitting in the same position and doing the same job for ages but management like to hire people from outside ignoring the potential employees they have within.

headline: A security job, but not a great one
pros:
A few: 
- They are recruiting a lot in Poland.
- The coffee machine at the office is awesome. Really.
- It feels cool to work for a Swiss bank. They have a nice logo, a nice new office in Krakow, you work with Swiss/German directors with interesting accents. 
- The working hours are well respected, you probably won't work on evenings nor weekends. Over-hours are well followed. 
- You can work from home some/all days of the week.
- They organize pretty well their Confluence/wikis
cons:
Many: 
- Ask for a high salary when you join: the company from what I observed gives absent/low raises each year. They will promote that promotion is the way to go if you want a higher salary, where only a few internally get promoted after years and years of working. You'd better change job after a year or two, and come back after some time if you want an honest salary that stay competitive. A worker might feel over time like they are not valued/appreciated, until they might realize they might just be part of a big Swiss "Squid Game" where the main goal of the company is to make the 1% of the world richer, and it might not imply paying correctly and sustainably their employees.
- The turnover is pretty high, and you might wonder when the company decides to stop hiring in Poland for a even cheaper country. 
- There might be a lot of directors, hierarchy, divisions changes, so you might have multiple team leader in a year
- The whole security/ecosystem to log in and work is very bothersome. It looks cool at first, but you will quickly realize how annoying it is for the worker.
- All the money on equipment/training is being funded/refunded over a large period of time : you buy your laptop to be able to work (no laptop provided), you get a bit of its cost back every month for over 30 months
- The training provided internally is pretty bad/absent. You will probably work on topics you don't fully understand, but "that'll do"
- Working at a bank implies having to do frequently a lot of security/compliance trainings that take a lot of time, energy, and focus
- There is a lot of information a bit everywhere, intranet, confluence etc. When you want an answer (HR, tools, rules etc) , it can take a while to find what you need.

headline: AML Transactions Monitoring Team
pros: Experience in Private banking and wealth management for high net worth individuals
cons:
- Toxic environment
- The role you have interviewed for is not the same when you have started / joined the company. Totally a different role and tasks assigned when you join the AML Transaction Monitoring Team. 
- Stressful and there is no work life balance. During the interview, work life balance was promised. However, after joining the team, in a month at least 1-2 weekends is burned due to the need to return back to office. 
- efficient workers are not fairly rewarded/ compensated. 
- Terrible management and leadership due to overloading employees’ workload. 
- Employee has to return to work (complete the tasks given) even when you are on medical leave. 
-Team leads and management are not supporting the needs of employees. 
- High employees turnover rate. Avg 6 months to 12 months.

headline: Don't work in FML
pros:

I worked in the management company and met 2 team leaders which really helped me to grow and were sharing their knowledge. They have given me new perspectives and motivate me to start new things professionally and personnally.
cons:
The conducting officers are a disaster, collectively except one they are not very good but the one overseeing my stream was probably the worst.
In summary:
 - he promised me promotion and didn't give it to me and told me "it's not big deal wait next year"
- he never understood anything we were doing but was taking credit for everything (except of course when something was going bad then it was our fault)
- we had to write his emails for the people on the top, then he was sending them without even copying us
- before covid he was working from home very often but was forbidding it for us
- he was always speaking bad of people when they were not there

headline: Nice company, but wouldn't recommend this job!
pros: The company benefits are really nice. You get a lot of vacation time and personal days at the beginning of each year instead of acquiring them over time. There are also a lot of different employment discounts available to you.
cons: Working in the tax department requires a lot of overtime work between Jan. - April, and you can not take anytime off during tbis period. You typically work between 12-16 hours days & a full day on the weekends, so a work-life balance is non-existent during this time. Also, the pay isn't great for how hard you have to work, and raises are next to nothing, and getting promoted in this department is very hard to accomplish.

headline: Good start of career for future banking champion

-lack of experienced workers which are staying with company for more than 4-5+ years in most units
-technically software and hardware is worse than in rivals` companies in the city location
-lack of clear requirements for salary increase or career booster
-line managers in several cases are willing not to tell true arguments and are seeking to mark your nomination grade as low as it is possible
-covering of lazy coworkers, if you will show your potential you will work for your duties and duties of your lazy coworker
-there are no equalisation of salaries, you can be outpaid by absolutely fresh joiner which doesnt have any experience at all

headline: Average investment bank
pros:
Fantastic branding
Great office environment
Lots of young people
cons:
Bonus is so bad (flat 0.5 month for back office ops and not based on performance)
Bad yearly pay rise if you are not promoted
Very slow promotion
The worst of all: You need to fight for promotion like a squid game IF you are not a graduate talent programme (GTP) hire. All resources and salaries goes to GTPs. GTPs salaries are 50%-60% higher than a normal hire that it doesn't make any economical sense. All opportunities are given to GTPs as well. You need to fight like a squid game if you want any additional opportunities in UBS.
Overall, a very bad hierarchy and culture and treatment when it comes to GTPs VS normal hires.

headline: Zero visibility  outside the team
pros:
- Liberal leaves
- Good infrastructure
- brand name
cons:
- Ask for good CTC, HRs can otherwise fool you by underpaying overwhelmingly
- You are in total control of manager, 0 HR involvement, even on resignation. Manager runs the show for you, and you are totally obscured from the outside world. 
- A fish can be told to learn to fly here. You could be told to work on something which is not on your JD, beware.
- Lazy people are defended and working people are told to slog
- Lack of resources in the team. They will keep hiring to add people to already proficient horizontal, but wont hire to lessen the workload on already overburdened horizontal
- They dont provide laptop even during Covid, you have to work on your own laptop
- Little compensation of 1.5k per month for wfh. nothing else. very disappointing for such a big brand.
- Opaqueness on the rating and performance reviews. Overachiever will be given comparable rating to a non achiever, and manager will defend it like anything.
- Teammate at same level is allowed to boss you around, and manager is oblivious. the main reason for the reviewer to be leaving the organization

headline: Take caution when joininig
pros: Good work and life balance.
cons:
1. No pay rise. They offer a good salary to get you in but would then try to keep you on the same pay for as long as they possibly can. You have to stay in the same position for at least 2 years before even being considered for a promotion. If you make an internal transfer, then the clock resets.
2. Some real bullies here. Most people here are nice and polite, but I have come across a manager who was a real bully. She frequently shouted at me, humiliated me in front of other team members, set unrealistic goals and kept moving them. Upon reporting her to her line manager and HR, no actions were taken, as they would do what they could to protect the interests of the management.
3. Lengthy process. It could take years to implement a project. They could be spending most of the time trying to follow through internal processes or trying to find ways to get around them, but ended up having to follow them anyway.

headline: Highly Beauracratic and Low pay compared to competitors
pros: Like any other captive but work environment could be better.. typical beauracracy in work which at times is positive and negative too..Must continue with WFH as we have seen higher productivities with people working from home.
cons: High attrition primarily due to own pay policies.. India geography needs to revise overall pay range and high time considering competitors are a step ahead in the game.. also, leave policy is good but can be made better by giving flexible leave for employees to decide rather than fixing them against Indian holiday or festival calendar.. Covid has changed people's approach towards vacation and with WFH for here to stay it helps with flexible leave policies like HSBC has..

headline: Developer productivity killer company
pros: I can't think of any.
cons:
- To write a single line of code you need to join UBS workspace then to another Windows VM (basically two nested Windows machines)
- UBS workspace will log you out of VM when you're inactive and you will have to do 6-7 steps again to connect to workspace and VM
- Sometimes business people don't know what they are doing, thus you do not have clear requirements or mocks
- A lot of security layers literally kill your passion for software development
- There is dedicated team who develops React component library for internal use but all they do is to import and overwrite styles of Ant Design
- This makes hard to use those components and basically I would say those developers are waste of money, you can use Ant Design and assign those developers to another projects instead of hiring new ones
- You cannot even update VSCode because of security layers
- You don't know anyone else besides your line manager
- And many more...

headline: Company really looks after you, but is very stuck in it's ways
pros: The overall employee package is fantastic, good salary, with 14% extra to spend on pension, health insurance, extra holiday etc. Very progressive parental leave policy, 6 months full pay for mums and dads. Very supportive through Covid, though now trying to implement a minimum 3 days in the office policy. Great people to work with all trying their best to achieve the best results
cons: Very hard to make significant change, very institutionalised, even if they claim that they aren't. Lots of centrally mandated programs that are forced through with little consultation of the people who it will affect and who are able to identify issues and easy fixes. Attempting to modernise but years behind most software companies.

skills and talent is far away of their understanding.

headline: No-impact work
pros: Work life balance is maintained *most* of the time. Furthermore, colleagues are very friendly and there is great cohesion. Work-from-home is also permitted in many cases.
cons:
Projects guided by leaders that either don't understand the business well or have no idea about data science. These either don't have any business impact or are generally not well received. 

Furthermore, as a team member, your voice is not very well heard. Decisions are top-down only and the hierarchical structure prevails over all.

Finally, career opportunities are greatly impacted by office politics. In my experience, there is no reward in going the extra mile and work hard as tenure is the main (and only) metric for promotions.

You will only be promoted if u suck up to your boss, you actual performance will never be considered.

I was widely believed that my team lead was having an affair with on of my colleagues, and every possible effort was made to make sure I leave so that she can be promoted. I was even threatened by my boss to keep quiet else face to consequences.

I had over 15 referrals from colleagues stating my good performance yet my position was given to the lady in question and I was side lined

headline: Processes processes processes

cons:
1. A lot of bureaucracy and processes

3. Culture of people not working collaboratively
4. Mixed quality of people hired and high turnover rate for good workers 
5. Cost-cutting every single year and structural uncertainty leading to re-organization every year
6. Insufficient incentive for good workers, the system operates similar to that of a state owned enterprise

headline: At the end of the day, it’s a bank...
pros: Banking salary (20% higher than non-banking). Some genuinely nice people to work with. International environment, with English as main business language (selfishly speaking).
cons: Roles are overly specialized, limiting learning curve. Also overlapping/duplicate roles meaning significant competition for more interesting work. Lots of FaceTime. Lack of gender diversity (what’s new?). Often unrealistic timelines for no particularly good reason, but maybe other areas of the bank are different.

headline: Not worth your time here for fresh grads
pros:
- People are generally nice
- good brand name (but my advice is to look last the brand name and at the job scope more) 
- relatively high starting pay for corporate centre GTP
cons:
- pathetic increment (bosses will justify it that GTPs already get more than full time employees)
- pathetic bonus (2 weeks is default)
- cost cutting everywhere, from benefits like staff celebrations, even OT claims need to be approved before hand, outsourcing to lower cost areas 
- need to do 'CCA' to get 'noticed' and promoted..resulting in many promotees focusing on 'CCA' and organising all sorts of events, but disregarding their core work. Management claims these extra activities are the way to make you 'stand out' in ops where people have less obvious KPI versus e.g. Sales
- Ops management claims to be suporotive of internal mobility but if it involves mobility out of Ops, it's a different story. 
- even a senior Ops management once commented to Ops interns and potential GTPs to 'not consider Ops' and go else where, which says a lot about the kind of work and culture there. That being said, if youre looking for a retirement job or not looking for much progression, this place may be great for you

headline: Bonus and Promotion processes are very political
pros: UBS is a good employer with generally good benefits. If the section you work in is important for the bank (higher client segment, generating or protecting cash) you can, usually, expect promotions after your first 2-3 years with (more often than not) increasing intervals for the next one due to rank and increasing responsibility.
cons:
UBS has a very irritating bonus+promotion system called PMM. You have to achieve goals, your manager has to put you on a long- and then on a short list and fight for you if you want a promotion. You will be compared to peers (sometimes in completely different teams) and it feels like they want to find a reason not to promote you on low levels (the higher ranks always have priority for bonus and promotion). You have to hit your targets the entire year - if you slip, you might risk your bonus and promotion.
Also, you have to be very strategic in this game: If the manager knows that you are leaving the team or if you would never ever leave the team, they have less reason to fight for you and will rather distribute the resources to the 'strategically important' team members.

headline: No increment and poor bonus. Asia is always the second class region.
pros: Colleagues are nice but manager could be horrible. Less political as majority getting no increment and pathetic bonus anyway.
cons:
1) No Increment. Many in group functions (previously known as Corporate Centre) has no increment. Management will give you different excuses such as: 
a) It's your first 2 years , very rare for someone in first 2 years have increment despite market and industry data supported at least some adjustment, they will just ignore the ground. 
b) They will also give reason saying you are not at the junior end of the rank so no increment. Increment is giving to people at the bottom end of the band or people outside the band.
2) Pathetic bonus 
 - No matter how good you are, bonus is less than 1.5 months and some even less than 1 month. When they give you bonus >1 month, please expect to slave yourself and management will emphasize they are doing so much to fight for this good bonus for you and you need to do 2 - 3 persons job just to make it count. 
3) Poor people in Singapore always being compared with low cost location like India. They always bring up topic that India can do the jobs in Singapore and people in Singapore is high cost and need to work double, triple hard. But they never look at SG vs. HK or SG vs. the other business hub like US, UK , Switzerland from which we are lowest cost location and better corporate tax environment. 
4. Many conversion of work pass holders , and fair considerations is just a tick in the box exercise. Look at how many EP holders they hired in last 24 months.

headline: Swiss Cheese
pros: UBS supports work from home and encourages flexibility for family and personal considerations. Post pandemic it appears UBS will be very liberal in its WFH policy, most likely making office visits largely optional. Don't need to take Fridays off because most of the firm isn't really working after lunch on Fridays. and therefore nobody notices if you're not around too.
cons:
Typical big bank mindset in the divisions, overwhelming bureaucracy, outdated systems, inefficient processes. Very low salary increases, often zero for many people. Giving a direct report a 4% raise takes an act of Congress, i.e. don't bother because you're only annoying your management by asking.

Senior leadership is generally clueless about the business systems and processes they oversee, leading to big disconnects between hands-on people and strategy leadership. Inefficiency permeates the organization in every dimension. 

Employee benefits are expensive and mediocre compared with other firms in the industry.

Hardly a day goes by without some self-serving internal announcement congratulating the firm's exemplary commitment to diversity and inclusion. Then look around and you see almost no people of color. Seem to be really committed however to promoting women, although in most cases those women promoted are Caucasian "old boys" steeped in the ancient culture. Anybody who tries to radically change an outdated process or system will probably fail and leave the organization in frustration.

headline: Great people, terrible processes
pros:
Great people - genuinely care about helping each other make progress and doing the best for the client.

If you are innovative, and successful you can get promotions and extra responsibility very fast. Managers are generally good at circumventing HR's absurd bureaucratic promotion requirements.
cons: The risk aversion stemming from the 2008/9 crisis, plus the rogue trader, has led to a bureaucratic and risk averse environment that is stifling all innovation. The new CEO is doing nothing to correct this, and instead focusing on defining his 'purpose' - which if anything makes the situation worse.

headline: Good place to spend a couple of years
pros:
Ability to work with the people from across the globe. 
Ability to learn finance and investment banking business. 
Stable work - once you're in it's very hard to get fired. 
The deadlines vary depending on the project but on average are realistic and reasonable. 
Remuneration generally above the market average. 
Easy way to stand out among others. 
Ability to work with the new technologies and learn from the good specialists, although it heavily depends on the project/area. 
Good benefits and learning opportunities, like Coursera, O'Reilly, Safari.
cons:
Little-to-no career growth opportunities unless you're willing to wait for a 5-6 years, generally you shouldn't expect any promotion or significant salary raise regardless of the performance or the responsibilities. 
Annual performance reviews aren't completely fair, hearing from your superior something like "I wanted to give you higher rating but my boss told me to give you this" is quite common. 
A lot of bureaucracy, which heavily distracts from the main responsibilities and complicates the processes. 
Conservative environment and strong opposition to the changes, unless pushed by the senior management. 
Day-to-day work only on the virtual machines, which are slow, buggy, unreliable and inconvenient.

headline: Don't Trust UBS | Look out for yourself as UBS does the same
pros:
- medical and 401(k) benefits (but they aren't great)
- large company so that can be good for job stability
cons:
- Consulting companies' benefits are noticeably better than UBS'. This is strange considering the company takes over 50% of what the advisors manage (even the largest teams). The licensed staff on the advisors team has benefits worse than consulting companies. Even when they have been at the company for over a decade.

- Large company = bureaucracy

- Late adapters with legacy systems and intranet needs an entire overhaul. They are 10 years behind in most areas of the technology they use. Not all but most areas.

- when in an advisory role, its mainly sales first. UBS (along w any company you work for) will take a massive cut of what you manage. 50-67% give or take. 

- marketing support for advisors is very poor. There isn't a legitimate department dedicated to helping advisors generate and execute marketing plans. There was a single person across 3 office locations who helped teams with marketing. Considering UBS is primarily a wealth management company, dedicated marketing teams should have been around 15 years ago. The industry, as a whole, shares this similarity but that does not mean it's a good practice. Usually only the largest producers can afford to hire dedicated employees to market for them. Most advisors need help from UBS to do this but UBS has not taken any steps to address this issue in the past 20 years. UBS clearly favors its highest producing teams/advisors.

- The non advisors on a team may be overworked at times while having to cover for other staff members who are out of the office. Sometimes other staff members do not get replaced for extended periods of time. (months, many months)

- Compliance department/HR has rules more stringent than SEC, and FINRA. Get your own private lawyer for any issue you have, should one ever arise, and do not speak with the company unless that lawyer is on the phone or present. It is a fact that UBS will look for reasons to terminate your employment regardless of whether or not you have taken the proper steps to mitigate an issue.

headline: Good company
pros: Amazing place to work in
cons: Silo working style and management

headline: Loyalty Tax
pros: Flexibility, even pre-COVID, offered flexible work arrangements and permitted WFM at least a day or two a week.
cons:
Salary -- They DO NOT give raises, not even basic cost of living adjustments, unless you actually go up in rank - which is nearly impossible once you get to the Director level. This means you can go literally 10 years without a raise. It's known as the UBS loyalty tax. While they actually have a team called "FA Recruiting AND RETENTION". they unfortunately don't care much about retaining any other talent. Add to that, they are not backfilling jobs as people leave, so the work load is just astronomical and unmanageable. Unless you negotiate a big starting salary and are content with staying at that rate for years -- stay away. 

Also - while the senior most management is decent, they basically promote whoever based on "accomplishments" - without regard for whether they have any business managing people. Not everyone who is good at an individual contributor role belongs in management.

headline: Warm body mgt strategy
pros:
The name as leverage to better companies 
Exposure to interesting cases 
Just don’t stay too long as you won’t be paid for it .
cons:
Policy is to have one replacement headcount only if 5 leave. So, managers struggle to keep all under performers and bad attitude MC prone staff because 3-4 limp horses are better than 1 good new one. 

New people learn fast not to do their best as only the stupid people get all the work. 
Toxic culture pervades the firm as everyone is quick to shirk accountability . You must never be labelled as a workhorse as only the smart will dump work on others while sashaying to the top for glory.

headline: Well Managed Company
pros: Management wants you to succeed and provides many tools in that effort.
cons: There could be more discipline concerning office hours. I understand that High Net Worth Financial Advisers are independent contractors and don't need to "punch the clock" to succeed, but it seemed like there could perhaps have been one or two required weekly meetings to build more of an idea lab within the office. There are numerous very successful veteran Financial Advisers on staff - it seems logical to assume that there is a means of exploiting the collective knowledge of the office could in a way that could improve everyone's production.

headline: Tolerates threats of Violence within work place
pros: Great benefits, some good people to work with.
cons: Had to leave in 2020 as I was threatened with violence in 2018. Due to lack of evidence due to no witnesses I was asked to attended a meeting in London with the other party in 2020 to resolve the issue and move forward. Within minutes of the meeting the other party threatened me with violence again in front of HR and management, I had to walk out of the meeting because of the level of threat made for my own safety. No action was taken against the other individual and I was given no choice but to leave. I expressed my concerns at my exit interview but got the feeling no one cared or wanted to take any action. A month after I left the individual who made the threats was aloud to returned to work!

headline: 1990 called, they want their systems back
pros: Manageable work hours, work life balance
cons:
- Antiquated systems: Access, Quickbooks, Skype
- No CRM??? Everyone uses spreadsheets to manage backlogs, pipelines, budgets.
- New systems are not received well and not rolled out properly; Microsoft Teams, no one knows how to use; Zoom, only certain groups have it.
- No one uses video, 1 yr into the pandemic I’ve seen my coworkers 3 times! 1 time, for a team meeting, 2 times for non work related activities.
- They are still paying for all the dirt that went down in 09, everything needs to be approved and it’s a 3 week turnaround. Even internal materials need to be approved.
- Pay is the absolute low end of what is quoted on GD. HR was completely wrong of the pay range and lead me into a weird low ball negotiation.
- Not diverse at all, weird dynamic of trying to diversify by only hiring women but no racial mix up, probably hire woman to pay them less.
- All IT is in India, no one local.

headline: Decisions only from the top, no empowering of employees and little feedback culture
pros:
Global firm with many offices, high chances to be relocated to Zurich
Great learning experience of the banking industry
International environment
cons:
Huge workload and understaffed teams
Tasks extremely repetitive, especially in the business operations services sites
IT tools very much behind the current state of the art
No proper planning and work organization
Even the easiest decisions are taken from the very top causing no empowerment of lower levels and long bottlenecks
There is no feedback culture and if someone speak ups the management doesn't act upon
There is no long-term vision of the team and it's individuals, only short sight tasks (for the day or the week) 
Sudden and very often change of priorities with waste of time investment in activities already started

headline: Read before applying to Wealth Advice Center (WAC)
pros:
1. Will pay you while you get you licensed for a career in the investment industry and pay for the study materials

2. Doesn't care about previous investment work experience

3. Young coworkers and some young managers so there are fun days if you can avoid certain managers and can easily make friends if you're moving to a new city for this job

4. There are advisors that make over 6 figures each year in their mid 20's. Downside is that, unlike working at a branch or many other investment companies, you won't be paid commission trails. You'll get, or not get if you don't meet your total sales goal that quarter, a one time payout on what you sell. Start from zero the next quarter and good luck

5. When you quit, they'll ask you to leave the premises immediately but still pay you for the two weeks that you would've had to work somewhere else. Everyone's favorite day
cons:
Everything else

1. It's a call center. Managers will say it's not a call center when they want to motivate you to sell more Advice Portfolio but will not hesitate to remind you that it's a call center first and foremost to get you on the phones if the queues get backed up. As an employee at the WAC, you solely work with the accounts that the local branches didn't want (i.e not enough money, temperament issue, etc.). You'll be able to figure out why the branches didn't want many of these clients very quickly. And you can't enroll new clients so you have to tell anyone that may want to invest at UBS to drive themselves to a local branch.

2. You'll spend the vast majority of your day updating email addresses, mailing addresses, phone numbers, etc because although clients of every other major financial firm allows clients to update this on their website, UBS believes that it is important that these people call in to do it. It's not a secret that UBS is aware that this is the only way that many of these clients would speak with an advisor at UBS but it's not a good look that the clients' statements may be mailed to a complete stranger for years unless they wait in a hold queue for 20+ minutes to speak with an advisor who is much more focused on trying to sell them something they don't want. Countless clients have transferred their accounts for this reason.

3. You'll be asked to do a "call night" every now and then. Call nights mean that you are asked to be in the office as soon as the office opens until the office closes so that you can call as many clients as possible that are avoiding your calls on any other day. The amount of call nights depend on your manager as these look good for the manager but don't frequently benefit you as the advisor.

4. During the interview, it was explained to me that the goal of the WAC was to train the advisor and move them to a local branch in 3-5 years. This very rarely happens. I've seen managers refuse to provide recommendations to move to a local branch on an occasion or two to those that are highly qualified but aren't a favorite in the their eyes

5. If you decide that you no longer want to be an advisor, there are two options for you. Become a support staff/sales manager or leave. No room for growth

6. Management says that they care about diversity but, as far as I know, the first female and non-white managers weren't put in their positions until 2019 although the WAC was created around 2010. It wouldn't be a stretch to say that the office was ~80% white men at the time I left

7. Get ready to only try to sell one product, Advice Portfolio (a UBS managed account that neither you or the client can choose any investments in), for your entire time there as that is one of two products that goes towards certain sales goals that you must meet a minimum of in order to be paid anything on your quarterly bonus. Although if any client does a little bit of research, they would see that this product is of lower quality at twice the cost that what they can get at Fidelity, Vanguard, Schwab, etc. Those that do the research are smart investors and I stopped trying to convince them otherwise pretty early on because they are right and I couldn't convince myself that my bonus is more important than their retirement.

7. Most employees that I'm still in contact with are actively looking for other jobs. Of the ~10 sales managers, there were 4 that left within a two to three month period in 2019-2020. Managers leaving en masse is a bad sign.

8. Having UBS on your resume may be a hindrance outside of UBS. There's a reason most people I know at the UBS WAC are looking for jobs instead of at a new job. It took me over 9 months just to get an interview somewhere else.

If you are looking for a job in the investment industry, there are countless companies that offer more growth opportunities and better investment products in both Charlotte, NC and Weehawken, NJ/ New York, NY

headline: Employee Friendly Org
pros:
For any big org, experiences change from team to team
However, I am glad to have been part of the Data Science team in Operations. 
1. Employee Friendly. Senior management is top class. They hear you, take your feedback, give time to execute your way and also are extremely cordial.

2. Work -Life balance. This is top notch. I have seen not just for me but for people in other teams as well. Work-Life balance can be easily maintained in UBS with occasional full throttle pressure situations which is understandable. 

3. Employee growth: Trainings, shadow programs, internal job rotations etc are provided and recommended.
cons:
1. Given it is bank, some times we might work on slightly old technology and not the latest. But the risk is understandable. 

2. The logistics process can sometimes become daunting. So much risk controls and segregation of duties can prevent from quick execution.

However, I believe these cons are only there due to the nature of industry. Once we get hang of the process, eventually, things to get done.

headline: Front Office? Yes. Back Office? Please don't.
pros:
I am trying to be very honest and (one of) the fairest reviews about UBS HK on glassdoor.

1) Big-name - indeed, with UBS Investment Bank's brand, you can get an interview from almost everywhere on the street. Sales/Trading, IBD, PE, or even front-office developer role.

2) Nice Health Plan - cooperate with BUPA, really, really, generous medical plan for you and your family. 

3) If you joined UBS IB as a junior/graduate, you will have a lot of learning opportunities about their business/products/trading. Ppl are friendly and patient to teach, you can always ping them and they are willing to schedule a catch up with you. Most importantly - If you make mistakes (as a junior), no one will blame you - as they treasure graduate talents a lot.

4) UBS IB Global Markets, in terms of cash equities space, it is just doing so well in APAC with the most powerful China franchise - high touch/electronic/advisory/financing.

5) If you don't have an ambitious/large goal, quite a comfortable place to stay until 40s/50s because of work-life balance.
cons:
There are way more things to discuss when talking about cons...

1) Internal IT systems (raise tickets, travel, hr system) are just jokes - old, slow, 100% user-unfriendly (click a button and you will have to re-do everything). They never have plans to upgrade them - guess that's will be the case forever.

2) hierarchy issue is very serious in this bank - Swiss/Who speaks German surpass everyone. Front office guys generally ignore support/back office guys (it is not rude. It is just making you uncomfortable with the wordings they use). High-rank guys ignore low-rank guys.

2.1) As a result, the inter-relationships between teams (business/support/IT/management) are generally bad. Not a cooperative environment IMO.

3) They outsource many operations/supports back to India. It is quite easy for you to encounter a case that you are recommended to contact 5-6 guys and still don't find an answer to your original questions.

4) This firm lost $2B in 2011. Starting from then, it imposed a "risk" culture, which means - many compliance training, many risk talks, many procedures to follow, many calls to attend in order to reduce risk.

5) The base salary is above streetwise pay. Front office bonus can be months, while back-office bonus is in weeks (i.e. less than a month, you will get used to it)

6) Rank - I know most ppl don't care about these but I do see a bunch of Associates in ~40/50 years old. That's the general case for back-office.

headline: They claim vision-driven culture and deliver blind mundanity
pros: flexible hours and decent holiday policy
cons: pay and difficulty of use: not only did they nickel and dime (dont even ask about benefits), there was a chronic underpayment vs the street. this was largely driven from poor managment, more concerned with art basel bookings than investing in techology. worse, they have corporate-imposed restriction s on their markets business, making it impossible to compete with peers during the course of business. overall, it was a very poorly run company always tossing a bandaid on somewhere.

headline: Great place to work
pros:
Working conditions and employee benefits are really good, people are generally nice and friendly, recently the firm has been quite responsive to the developments of the job market (flex working, updates of office space, agile approach). Great focus on sustainability and Sustainable Investment give a sense of purpose. It's nice to work for a firm that is such a major player in the global landscape!
Career opportunities are quite broad as internal mobility is encouraged, so you can also reskill and upskill.
cons:
Still extremely high level of company politics, which waste time and energy from employees and management. The rank and promotions system is antiquate and often holds back young talent, making career growth a lot slower than in other industries/companies.
In theory D&I is a big topic, in practice there is still a lot of work to be done and objectives are at the bare minimum.

headline: Solid employment
pros: Really smart colleagues. Really enjoy the work environment. Culturally diverse and the company encourages inclusion.
cons:
Promotions follow seniority more frequently than talent or work quality. It can be easy to get stuck because if you change teams, you start at the bottom of the promotion rank (this is not official policy). 

Expectations of very long hours are frequent and efficiency must be high. Training is very hands on and informal.

headline: Mindset stuck in the past
pros: International atmosphere. Low racial, religion or sex discrimination. You can quickly grow, acquiring  new responsibilities, if your manager supports you.  Good internal mobility program.
cons:
Outdated business culture with extreme hierarchies. 

Management quality is generally poor:

- Challenging your manager, it’s a no go.
-  Objective performance evaluation fails with personal bias from your manager towards your persona.
- At what time you leave the office it’s a very important parameter. Doesn't matter how much you deliver or what time you started in the morning. 
- Working late, nights and weekends is highly promoted through some teams, against company rules. Very low HR representation.
- No room for out of the box thinking. Ideas are usually ignored, mocked, or stolen through escalation process.

headline: Not terrible but also not outstanding
pros:
Generally a good work life balance and wonderful friendly colleagues.
Opportunites to learn from some very talented people.
cons:
Salary and bonus not competitive. 
Wealth Management (particularly front facing and senior management) have hardly any diversity. 
Promotion process based on tenure or favouritism  instead of merit.
High performing advisors given special treatment and a license to treat everyone else in a way that is disrespectful.

headline: Fantastic Place to Work
pros: UBS is filled with great people. With over 60,000 employees, you find highly specialized members in all facets of the financial industry. The culture is incredibly collaborative where any member will take the extra time to teach you a new skill or concept and help further yourself and your career. I have been happy to work for UBS for a year and a half and plan to be here longer. There is horizontal and vertical mobility opportunities. If the financial industry is right for you, UBS is right for you.
cons: As mentioned, the firm is very large. If you want to dip your feet into many areas of the financial field, you must demonstrate that you can handle your specialized role responsibilities before you can venture to new areas within the firm. This is not necessarily a con on the firm, but it is a fact that some potential candidates do not understand or appreciate.

headline: Good for those with Bank Domain experience
pros:
1. Cab facility is good - one star for this
2. Leaves are in good numbers - a second star for this
3. Job stability and security
cons:
1. Secondary treatment by US, European counterparts
2. Europe based company, but culture is a typical Indian IT culture, where managers like appease European hire management
3. Not promising financially and professionally
4. Promotions needs a lot of lobbying
5. Don't expect a promotion at least in the first two years of joining
6. Ancient technology, i.e. Java 1.5, just imagine
7. False role promises during the hiring
8. HR activity is done by third-party, so take their promises with a pinch of salt
9. Never saw any HR interacting once you are hired, even resignation is handled by the manager
10. Don't expect learning and career growth
11. Overall join only if you want a good switch hike and like to enjoy leaves, otherwise I won't refer my enemy here

headline: - Ensuring the agreed Service Level Agreements (SLAs)
pros:
Workflow management of a regional team
- Participate in discussions/meetings with senior management and key stakeholders to ensure transparency of issues and to discuss strategy and process improvement
- Develop a strong understanding of regulatory requirements, as they relate to outsourcing, and how to meet those requirements.
- Build and maintain relationships across the firm with supporting functions, including Operations, Finance, HR, Corporate Services, Legal & Compliance, Technology, and other internal BUs, and leverage these relationships to resolve issues in order to ensure seamless and timely completion of their engagements
- Show strong emphasis towards data integrity to track and report progress of each engagement under management, to plan appropriately while ensuring risks and issues are identified, escalated and resolved
cons:
xxxxx- Ensuring the agreed Service Level Agreements (SLAs) and go live deadlines are met
- Provide project management support for the entire lifecycle of an engagement, to ensure that all project related deliverables are met (completion of calls, governance and regulatory requirements, clearance and acknowledgments from control groups, including Compliance, Tax, Legal, BU, etc.), including project status reporting.
- Demonstrated ability to think strategically and act as a thought partner with teammates, senior leadership, and key stakeholders is critically important
- Exceptional project management/team leadership skills evidenced by a track record of success leading engagements or other problem-solving initiatives requiring coordination of cross-function team members with varied backgrounds and skills

headline: Busy, Challenging, a little Chaotic...
pros:
Here are the good things I have experienced:

-Busy and challenging environment. In IT and with the pandemic, I began my employment at 110%. I was thrown right in but I had a team that was willing to help out (when they had time).
- The benefits are good compared to other larger companies I think. 
- All remote work and company is super flexible, allowing employees to work remotely at minimum until the end of the year and also not forcing folks to come back to the office if they are not comfortable.
-Progressive company and responds to current events.
-Plenty of employee resources and diversity groups.
- Town halls from global address to regional ones. These are consistent in nature and provide good updates.
-My leadership, at least, fights for employee training & development. Training resources internally are available but also allow you to go outside and find training and propose it.
- There are a bunch of unified processes and automation which seem to work pretty well.
cons:
These are some cons I have experienced:

-Onboarding in general is pretty hectic. There are multiple moments when you have no clue what to do and no direction. This occurs from HR to your own team. It seems there is no larger directive to make onboarding a more cohesive and enjoyable experience across the region or the company. Multiple times your team has no clue what is going on and HR does not know. It takes a lot of independent work and "click and find" to get everything going.
- The interview process was somewhat unorganized. At one point, I thought I was out of the running and then I get an email one day, about a month later, saying I was in the final round....
- All the different teams and their names. Teams have odd names and there is no real directory I have seen to be able to figure out what people actually do. UBS has a "Who Is Who" directory and it is cool to look at that but it does not truly provide team names and explanations about what people do. Would like to see something added that spells it out more.

headline: Avoid at all costs
pros: Salary and ability to work from home when needed.
cons:
Corporate culture is old school so most people do not like working there.
They stay there for the salary and wfh, also because there are fewer jobs outside now.
Seem to be alot of people with zero people/managerial skills in management due to the way that promotions are done on the basis of working hard for 2-3 years in a lower job. 
Those who know they are good but miss out on promotions due to having a bad manager end up leaving within 2 years.

As companies wise up to the idea that retention is better than throwing new bodies at the problem, UBS is already positioned to be the leader in financial orgs.
cons: Can see some bureaucracy, and teams can operate in silos. You will never be given things, you have to ask.

headline: Great UK business, but too closely controlled by Zurich
pros: Really top notch people work in the UK business. Good diversity, really clever with impressive backgrounds. Nice building in the City with canteen and gym. When I started in 2013 it was great because turnover was low, and people really built their careers there and stayed a long time. They moved around jobs but this gave it a great feel of longevity as a place to work.
cons: The Swiss home office micro-manages the UK, and when you add this pressure to UK regulatory scrutiny it can be a maze of rules and regulations. Then the worst is when your Swiss bosses don't understand UK rules and you get in trouble with you boss for following UK law. Far too controlled by Switzerland, which allows for little creativity or enablement in London. Also now beset by reorg after reorg so the turnover is too high to get to know people well or build a career there.

headline: Toxic and corrupt environment
pros:
1. Flexible timings (depends on your boss and team though)
2. Free transport (but the people you travel with are the most rude as they will act like children who want their house to be the first drop)
cons:
1. Toxic management, right from the MD it begins and flows down. Forget your work, even if you come to play politics and drink coffee and watch tik toks all day, you will get promoted. Otherwise you won't..forget about it.
2. No useful trainings will be guided to you, even if you ask/beg/request. They don't want you to grow.
3. Insecure people in the whole office who don't speak to anyone except to flaunt their big pay cheques. Maybe 1-2 good people are there but I have seen them leave in 1 year. Also high attrition rate. So forget having work friends or people you can smile to...no one smiles or is even happy.
4. If you don't not know Marathi (Maharastrian regional language) then you will be discriminated by you manager and team. And there is no HR action that will be taken even when reached out. So if you don't know Marathi in the Maharshtra offices then you will probably get 1-2% increment and tortured all day with taunts. Basically you will be punished for not knowing the langauge as it is always spoken on the floor and on calls as well.
5. No Diwali and Christmas bonus/gifts. It is a small thing but if startups can manage a small gesture then obviously a Swiss Bank can. But nope.
6. RACISM- if your boss is out of India (America's mainly) then get ready to face subtle racism in form of ignorance and favouritism. My last boss didn't even acknowledge my work or my existence. This is a firm where you need to cut throats in order to sit in office and spill venom.

headline: Client Service Associate
pros: I have great coworkers, I work for a great team, I have excellent earning potential as my team grows and I get licenses. The work life balance is great as my day is strictly 8-5 and nothing after, and we have lots of vacation and get all the bank/market holidays. I really like my job.
cons: It can be a bit of an old school environment depending on your branch. My branch is a bit more formal (though not nearly as formal as it could or used to be) and there is a definite delineation between genders, eg women are CSAs and men are Financial Advisors. There's very little overt sexism, but there is definitely some institutionalized sexism going on. The earning potential is great, but there is not a lot of opportunity for upward mobility in this role, although UBS has tons of career opportunities in other areas.

headline: Cyber Monitoring Analyst
pros: I can’t see any advantages
cons: Don’t even know where to start. If you want a role where there discrepancies between people are obvious, some are treated with more “privileges” than others. Where there’s absolute no compensation for working in the shifts, night shifts and even in the 12h weekend shifts, then this is the place for you! If you are used to work from home, also forget that too(they will tell you it’s possible, although two times per month, when you are doing business hours shift and there’s plenty coverage in the office) it’s the flexibility to work from home ! Also forget public holidays as you will not get any compensation for working on those days. For training, didn’t met anyone that got external training. Also allowance for working in shifts comes disguised in your base salary, so make sure you negotiate a high base salary because it will include your allowance for working in the crazy shifts.

cons: too many people in management

headline: Avoid at all costs
pros: you will learn how unprofessional people can be, and it will lower your expectations from people in general
cons:
-low pay; below industry standard. No bonuses, no raises. Whatever you negotiated--this is what you will make for the duration of your time at UBS.
-extremely unprofessional rude people. I worked in Management Consulting Group (MD was a joke, his favorites would yell at people and disrespect others--nothing will be done) and I worked with MDs and Directors across the bank--same story: just push your work on others, humiliate them, promote culture of fear and bulling--and eventually, in 10 years, you will get promoted. 
-backstabbing. If you dont know how or cannot do that--this is not a place for you. You HAVE TO be rude, push work on others, turn things to put other people in trouble, go to the highest manager and tell lies about other people--all to make sure management never looks at what you are doing 
-Zurich and London management is a joke too. They make you fill out a monthly survey. which is NOT anonymous, then a manager from London calls you to ask why you are unhappy and softly hints you--you are free to leave
-very toxic culture, stay away
-no promotions, like i said above--it takes on average 7-10 years unless you are the favorite one. They also constantly tell you at the yearend review that you are a step away from being fired, but they will give you another chance to keep your job, obviously you are not qualified for a promotion.  
-insurance is very expansive and the worst I have ever had, and I worked at other big banks and corporations

Corporate jargons galore. Uptight management and culture, even though they would like you to believe they are friendly and nice. Would never want to work for the bank again and I hope I don’t have to.  Also they want to appear to be agile but a snail is probably more nimble.

headline: Backend Developer Java (Fresher)
pros:
Cab till home.
Work life balance
Good Relocation Bonus (one time)

It all depends on the team and Project Lead.

Learning comes in phases
I was unlucky in the first six month and got really old tech stack JSP and struts. Later after change of the lead I got chance to work upon latest tech in the industry. 

Leaving Senior Management all the people are really helpful and nice. Nearly all teams have their own social activities and events.
cons:
Join only if you don't care about money and growth.

Fixed yearly bonus for EE and AO, not even 5% assuming employed for the full review cycle. 

Hike is very less mostly single digit below 10%.
The salary are not even close to what other banks offers in India.
Leaves will get lapsed at year end. No option to en-cash them.
No gifts on Diwali, New year. No other added benefits apart from salary and cabs.

Favoritism will always win over hard work, effort and talent. Everything is already decided for year end review. They are just doing it for name sake.

Senior management have very old thinking. They can push you up to any limit to get their year end goals completed, and they will not even give any credit for you. They will talk about ownership and strategy in front of you but will do nothing.

They have very old tech stack. 
Most of the tech is dying and unmanageable. There is no point in learning it, as you will not find any opportunity in the old tech.

Production release is a mess and you may not even get paid extra for doing it on weekend. They have a very complicated process for prod release and very few people are aware about it. 

Application owners in USA just want to get work done they don't think rationally on the time the effort it will take.

headline: Not a good place for support staff
pros: Good support staff and great benefits.  Good time off and 401k.
cons: Client Services Associates were expected to work with 5 plus Financial Advisors and their hundreds of clients each.  Also, filled in at reception for breaks and their days off.  With high net worth client's expecting you to be available to help at the same time.  Unfortunately,  the support staff was overstretched.  Management do not protect or fight for the support staff even when a broker is abusive and they are aware of their behavior.  Abusive FAs were just passed off on the next CSA when the CSA complained.

headline: UBS needs to evolve.
pros: Free lunches, friendly co-workers, supplemental compensation from advisors.
cons:
CSA’s are overworked and underpaid, not to mention we’re not eligible to work overtime, yet expected to get all the work done within strict business hours. No bonuses. 

Absolutely no work-life balance - UBS needs to be more flexible with work schedules & allow CSAs to telecommute or the company will loose out on quality candidates. Most companies allow at least one work from home day. Get with the times UBS.

Outdated Technology creates so much frustration and results in taking five times as long to complete tasks. Very unnecessary.

headline: Empty promises
pros: UBS has some "best in class" talent in niche functions. If you find yourself at this failing, European bank, you can make the most of it by learnings from these people.
cons: I would give zero stars to senior mgmt and company culture. This place loves to have "co-presidents" at every level ...i.e. two over paid execs, neither with any sense of responsibility to actually make decisions. The bank will continue to flounder until it ultimately gives up on US IB. Middle management does the best they can to keep it afloat by making verbal guarantees and commitments to employees and then blaming the lack of follow through come comp season on "clerical errors" by HR, promising to correct it next year. If you don't have it in writing. It is not happening. Walk away.

headline: Associate Director
pros:
Not being socially active is bit difficult to write a review on Glassdoor but I would be happy to put my words here so that people looking for opportunity with this company would get help to make decision in right direction.

I am very excited to start a new journey with UBS in coming months in one of the IT Infra function in Pune.

The technical Interview was quite well coordinated, Interviewers were kind to explain the overall Job Specification which helped me to understand the role in detail and most importantly the process just took 1 week time to complete unlike other IB firms.

Special thanks to Akshata from HR who seems to be more of Business HR since she was kind enough to explain me even the smallest detail that left me 0 questions to ask in return. Certainly she is one of the best HR I have met during my  career.
cons: If found shall surely share the same

headline: Horrible culture
pros:
Good salary & benefits
Good experience
Lots of interesting work
New dedicated building in the City
cons: I believe I got unlucky with the team at UBS. The manager and 90% of other senior people and BAs were originally from India (I was in a Front Office IT BA role in London though). The culture felt drastically different to most of other Financial Services firm in the City I worked at. Overwork, understaffing, burnout, constant attacks from management, army-like bullying are the norm. The head of the IT department came from the trading desk and he brought the cut-throat competitive desk culture into IT, where it's very harmful (I doubt it can be helpful in any business really). More of it, this place will attempt to drain all of life out of you via giving you 5 times more than you can handle. This will to make you so weak, that they can start changing your very personality. The management likes meek, obedient workers who never say No to anything, who never challenge things. Staying below the radar and only thinking about your own political interests was the only viable strategy to survive and to avoid attacks. When I felt I started becoming part of the system, I left.

Entire large teams here with just indian men. Ridiculous! You cant tell me you cant find other types of candidates in the entire country. They speak their language during meetings, cover up for each other and when a non indian joins the team, their stand offishness chases the person away. Lots of other issues like a director telling a lady “time out” cutting her off mid sentence and so on...

headline: Large company means the team and team head is important
pros: The company is progressing nicely towards being an open and fair employer, doing business in the right areas, and enforcing values that matter to the millennial eg. Community service, consideration for others, respect and inclusivity.
cons: The company is very large, so the team lead and team culture determines much of the workplace culture. If the bosses are petty, you get a petty working environment etc. In some quarters of the bank, hierarchy by age trumps meritocracy and this can be a dampener for young colleagues. Subtle bullying, especially to junior employees are not uncommon too.

headline: Stay away if you want to keep your soul
pros:
Big and mighty - shareholder and top management pioritised but not soldiers 
Appear more glamourous than a souless piority cookie cutter bank 
Easy to win clueless clients over with the name
cons:
Good people turn nasty in a cut throat culture devoid of values 
Constant headcount cuts ,everyone doing the job of 2-3 . Everyone minds their own business for self protection.
Culture of transient fame and critical shame =everyone learns to do as little as possible to stay under radar from extra work or getting any attention. 
Posturing is necessary to stay as middle Mgt. Cannot be typecast as a soldier so everyone tries to palm off their work down the food chain.
Client Advisors are told that the client promise is to have seamless transition in change of bankers. Clients are encouraged to sell out the bankers to leverage for better pricing , service or change to Bankers the management wishes to support. 
This leads to a Lack of trust between management and staff , peers and between clients and their Bankers. 

Always have to look over your shoulder to watch out for unsuspected sabotage or internal looting.

headline: Good salary if you start < 2008 - Lack of a vision for the future

cons:
Numereous social plans ruined the athmosphere. Outsourcing that was fully analyzed caused stress in operations and clients who were unhappy.
UBS also focusses more on administration on various infrastructure related issues, like end-of-life, than actually solving the issues, or even better to focus on client delivery

headline: Great company, lots of bureaucracy and cost cutting
pros:
- Access to cutting-edge financial research, market data-- you can learn anything you put your mind to. If you want to learn about UBS's  different investment platforms and model portfolios, the research is there.
- Wholesaler lunch meetings to get their perspective on the markets and various products.
- Very smart and amicable co-workers who are willing to help you with any questions you may have.
- Lots of the financial advisors can be nice on a personal level.
- Open door policy with management, you can go to them with whatever issues you have and they will do their best to help you solve them. They have lots of contacts with local attorneys, home office, and other advisors who may be able to provide some insight that was previously lacking.
- Management pays/sponsors you for your licenses and exams.
- Great name on your resume.
cons:
- Bureaucracy is huge-- can take a long time to get answers for certain client inquiries.
- Advancement is nearly non-existent-- you will discover that management and financial advisors are at odds with how they pay you. Most likely, your salary will be split between the two, and both sides are trying to operate as lean as possible. This will cause you to stay stagnant. There are reasons why this overall nice office bleeds talent. There is no room for growth or advancement in pay, no matter what they tell you. In both sides (FAs and Management) not agreeing on what to pay  you, you will stay stagnant and be told during yearly reviews that "there is less money this year for raises" or to "go to your financial advisor"  if you want to negotiate a higher pay. They also believe in a very traditional, corporate, antiquated "pay your dues" style to advancement, where you could be working there forever and a day before seeing any sort of advancement. Sure, there are some dues to pay, but this approach simply isn't the way it works in today's job-hopping world.
- Lots of cuts/going lean has resulted in many lay-offs. This has been reported on in various financial literature, as well. For instance, there is ZERO reason why a Registered Associate who is taking trades for their advisor's clients and wants to learn more about the markets should be switching on and off the switchboard. They are not being further compensated for taking on receptionist duties, or for covering various teams in this lean office when people are out sick or on vacation. We are told that we need to be "pre-approved" to work overtime and request it, when 99% of the time that's not how it goes. CSAs who sometimes stay late, stay based on NEED and aren't exactly planning on it. It's just the workflow of the day. Again, there are reasons why this good environment bleeds talent. Maybe more people should be salaried instead of hourly?
- Your experience can vary greatly depending on the financial advisor(s) you work with and their client base. 
- It is up to you  to stay on top of your team and management for advancement/pay raise opportunities when they come up.
