headline: Honest Review for Wealth Advice Center (WAC)
pros:
1. UBS brand name, people assume you're a big-time financial advisor (but your not)
2. Young team, most people here are straight out of school in their early 20s so it's fun to work here if you're young and energetic.
3.  Work/life balance: you work on an 8hr shift; no overtime.
4. A good place to start and get licensed if you have no financial background.
cons:
1. No Growth. The whole team basically handles small accounts or garbage accounts that '' real'' UBS advisors don't want.  You don't own your own book and you can't get new clients on your own. The only clients you're allowed to service and do business with are the small/ garbage accounts mentioned earlier.

2. High turn over rate: Because of the first reason, turn over rate here is one of the highest in UBS. Not a lot of people work here for over two years. 

3. NOT a finance job: Most financial advisors here have no finance background or basic knowledge of finance or economics.  And that goes for most sales managers here as well. Because all they want you to do is to sell managed portfolios and nothing else (this is the only way you get paid).  It's kind of ridiculous because how in the world a recent college grad with a non-finance related degree is going to help clients make some of the most important financial decisions? 

4. Lack of diversity: 90% white male. No female or minority in management.  Frat house environment, you have to be boys with your manager and drink the kool-aid to be promoted, personal performance doesn't really matter. Ladies thinking about working here?  You will be one of the 5 female FAs working here among 50+ twenty-year-old guys. Just imagine that...

5. Nepotism: I don't think this is a big surprise for most banks, but this place takes it to a whole new level.  You'll be working with a lot of senior management's kid here because of an inter-generation program they have, and these kids can do anything they want with no repercussion. They can miss their sales gaol and still take vacations to Europe.  And at the end of the day, they will still get promoted ahead of everyone. I've personally seen these kids got promoted ahead of a team's number one performer and sales managers are afraid of confronting them.  

6. Mediocre pay- base salary is 50k plus bonus,  normally after 1.5 -2 years you'll get promoted to a more premium team earning 60k base. However, bonuses are taxed heavily so you're not putting that much in your pocket. For the amount of $ you're bringing in and products you sold, it's really not that much...

7. Low morale:  morale used to be okay... after a lot of good managers left, morale is at its lowest. They also changed the way advisors get paid so it's harder to get your bonuses now.  At a team meeting, they even asked to rank our morale from 1-10, and no one scored more than a 4.

headline: BYO Morale
pros: It is a high net worth firm with great time off for full time employees.
cons: Every opportunity to save money is taken. Down to coffee cups and cutlery. I've seen 20 year vets at this company get laid off 5 years from retirement because of budget moves. I've seen entire teams get moved offshore regardless of the talent. Every decision comes down to numbers. UBS does not pay competitively so be sure to ask high when you come in. Part of it is the corporate world but UBS amplifies it.

headline: Marginalized staff

Company is unwilling to hire replacements to save at the bottom line and does not compensate remaining staff who pick up additional workload. For each person who left, they attempt to replace in Nashville or Poland.

headline: UBS experience

cons: located in outskirts of the city, shady area post 6 pm, difficult to get a transport , annual hike is in least single digit number and bonus is two weeks salary for base two levels( Also there are teams who dont get hike at all). No medical coverage for parents, no in house medical support in office.

headline: Typical investment bank - lean business model, long hours and high pressure
pros:
Good team - High performing and helpful colleagues. The team wouldn't survive a single day if it didn't have the people they do
Most of the traders are pleasant to work with
cons:
Hours - get in every day before 8:30 and leave anywhere between 6-11pm. You also don't know how late you will be finishing until about 5:30-6pm. Work must be finished by the end of the day so the team stays as late as possible to ensure it's done, it isn't possible to leave it until the next morning.
Heavy work load - The company reduced costs/staff so the workload is far too much for one person to handle. 
Outdated systems - systems are very slow and don't work as much as they should.  It affects clients and makes the team look incompetent 
Too much knowledge hoarding - People in the team become experts in a specific area and management does not push to spread this knowledge amongst the team. This causes trouble when that person is away/on leave

headline: Good but still not the best although elsewhere could be worst
pros: Environment is great as there are still some nice colleagues around. Very rare to have nice boss and I came across only one really good one who is more of a people management leadership rather than task oriented/statistic leadership.
cons:
1)All the while, the management has been squeezing us dry; they are always trying to reduce headcount by cutting some processes or using robots to run some tasks but the volume is always so high and robots breaks down often. 
2) I can never understand why are the management are always counting the time needed to do each tasks but are always not providing enough staff to cover the work. 
3) They are always hiring temporary staff which in turn waste alot of our time in training them up as the turnover rate is high with such unstable source of manpower. 
4) The worst thing is that they are never going to reward us; pay freezed for 4 years and bonuses of only 2 weeks. Some got none. Although there is a $900 flexible benefits per year, it is just worst overall if you have to do overtime often. 
5) After some nice colleagues and good bosses left, the team dynamics changed for the worst.

headline: Good if you're extremely lucky
pros:
Good retirement benefits. 
Low bar for entry for contract workers.
You will probably be among the most senior people as there are very few qualified people.
cons:
Too many contractors and in many cases not the best ones. This depends on the project. 
You probably spend most of your time fixing errors caused by other people and projects generally run 100% over schedule due to rework.

headline: Friendly and nice people on the ground, good work life balance
pros: People are generally very nice and friendly, and keen to help you. The firm invests a lot in people initiatives (or at least gives the perception, as whether or not you can leverage these really depends on your job or manager), supports work/life balance, very family friendly.
cons: As you would expect from a Swiss organization, lots of bureaucracy and processes. Senior managers like to form committees and gather to discuss at length, without really thinking about toe objectives to drive towards. In the Corporate Centre, lots of dead wood at the very senior managerial level - these people should be cleared out and replaced with people who are more attuned to feedback from the ground. This would help the bank become more efficient and streamlined!

headline: Director

headline: Good place to start, no long term potential
pros: UBS is big corporation where you can learn a lot about policy, process and working in Financial Services. Overall, there are good managers here and there's opportunity for growth and management makes a large effort to support internal mobility within HR.
cons: Management in UBS HR is unorganized and fleeting. It seems like every week a new senior manager is resigning which leaves the employees underneath looking for clarity, certainty and stability in their job. Lots of feeling lost within a massive organization and employees in the US feel unsupported by the management sitting overseas. There is definitely cultural differences between US and EU employees and it's difficult to feel seen when there is no senior representation in the region.

headline: Poor Management

headline: Bloated and bureaucratic

cons: The sheer size of UBS makes it incredibly hard to get anything done. Everything must be run through so many different people, which is super slow and tends to suck the juice out of any ideas. Add to that corporate politics and a very risk-averse culture, and you have a recipe for frustration.

headline: Worst work culture and employee satisfaction.
pros: If you are only for brand name , this the place for you.
cons:
It doesn't have work ethics and culture as per investment bank standard. They do a lot of wrong hires and play with employees career. Most of their employees are dissatisfied as their roles doesn't match with they had applied and promised for. 
UBS can even ruin your career by terminating your employment anytime if the project dissolves and won't pay you lay off bonus by calling it as performance issue. 

If you are only looking for brand name and salary then this the place for you but there won't be job satisfaction and respect. 

No / meager bonus for junior to mid level .

headline: second-rate Internal Audit shop

headline: Awful working place
pros: The salary is not bad.
cons: Awful strategic planning. Managers are just looking for trendy keywords to apply to what they’re doing so the can get the budget for their team in the companies internal market but don’t actually intend to do the job (like machine learning or deep learning). The internal market makes it almost impossible for teams to collaborate and you wait a huge amount of time for other people to deliver on what they’re supposed to do. There’s no budget for innovation and whichever proof of concept gets created it always ends up in the pile of ‘good to have but will never move to production’ projects.

headline: If Career Development is what you are looking for, STAY AWAY

cons: Absolutely no opportunity for career development. Bonuses are non existent. Management genuinely does not care about your well being and will overwork you but then complain that you work too much overtime and make ambiguous accusations as to why you are not meeting standards. You set goals at the beginning of the year but there are 0 KPIs involved, basically just blanket statements to screw you over at year end.

cons:
I am to give my feedback on Luxembourg. Well, in short: no Management= UBS management in Luxembourg. No decisions taken in Luxembourg. 
Ppl are promoted to managers because they are good technicians but have absolutely no people skills. These same people know they are getting away with it as long as they say yes to everything.  
Noticed two dominant features: 
- passive aggressive attitudes as no one dares to critizise since it will backlash on you. 
- Agressive male orientated approach where the highest position will exercise the authority by shouting, demoting,  
- Impossible to move internally, they are not open to change at all. They don't encourage internal change.

headline: Skilled People. Modern Work Culture. Great stress on People Skills.
pros:
1. Amazing pay if you deserve it.
2. Work culture is relaxed, modern and stress free.
3. Great focus on people skills like ethics, respectful conduct and inclusiveness.
4. Flexible work space arrangement empowers me to improve productivity.
5. Pantry area is decked up with sofas, TV, lounges and snack vending machines and  free yet good quality coffee. The last one being my favourite.
6. Work load as a developer is not too much.
cons:
1. Few managers coming from service industry background hate things like flexible work arrangements and relaxed work hours and try really hard to spoil the work culture for everyone. The management should take note that this will cause really bad results for the morale of skilled work force.
2. Tech stack is not the most latest but efforts are in place to upgrade them.
3. Food in Mumbai canteen needs improvement.

headline: Front staff and back-end support misconnect. Swiss supremacy mentality
pros: Brand name. Investments on IT. Promote internal mobility (because it’s also cheaper to get internal staffing).
cons:
Big disparity over compensation package. 
Better to be with the Front than back office. Low morale hence explain the high turnover, which result in losing of the knowledge and expertise. Unfortunately, loyal long time employees are not properly recognized- external hire getting higher compensation than one who chooses to move within org or got promoted Internally. Low morale, lead to poor performance. Vicious cycle. Non performing seniors just sticking around waiting to get their golden handshake. 

Culture- not wrong to be proud of your achievement, but should be humble enough to admit that there is actually things that can be improved. And when highlighted, they make you the owner to drive change while the rest just want leach on the benefit. 

Red tape, also too big to for any fast implementation. Stakeholders are working in silo. 

IT demands crazy budget but delivery is not always up to expectation. 

Currently facing drastic cost cutting.

headline: Stuck in The Past... by UBS
pros:
- Free tea, coffee and water (Sparkling or Still) 
- Time off/ breaks: Due to countless “Townhalls” & meetings
- Every year they strive to improve... on things that have been done 5-10yrs prior (no joke) - hindsight I guess 
- Erm, they are in tune with the latest jargon - same values/ beliefs/ principles, strategies, culture as next financial institution (the Be Agile, Collaboration, Client horse, Technology... Blue Steel!)
cons:
- Poor management (Esp middle management)
- Mediocre long term staff: First jobbers, hanging on to pension, lazy, brain dead, no innovation, lack of ambition, lack of responsibility, lack of initiative
- Bureaucratic
- Negative environment 
- Slow moving 
- Boring
... I guess if you are looking for a mediocre ride and to collect your pension, with a hint of feeling sorry for yourself moaning at lunch... YAWN! Get on with it.
SIDE NOTE: If your application is not getting through, this because the recruitment team make the decision before the hiring team even gets a sniff. Due to not so great recruiters that honestly know nothing about the field they recruit in and bias (no comment)... This is insider info/ the team I worked in lol.

headline: UBS Asset Management
pros: Benefits are above industry average. European style welfare. There's a lot of exposure. Internal mobility is encouraged. Branding is recognized.
cons: Asset management is a mess from the inside.  UBS infrastructure is built for wealth management business; so a lot of the processes at the asset management side are still very backward and manual. It's very political at management level. The multiple restructuring  only benefit the management, while the junior employees suffer. The client service team is the most overworked and least appreciated team.

It put me off the industry but in hindsight it was management that was difficult and the structure of the business rather than the role.

headline: Registered Client Service Associate
pros: You learn a lot very quickly. They have a good amount of resources but in a lot of cases you get conflicting info. There were a lot of great people who worked in my office. Even though I didn’t use it they have a great maternity leave and allow flexible work arrangements for mothers.
cons:
No room for growth, especially in branch offices. The team I worked on was awful and there was no ability to switch to a different team. The FAs I worked for were never in the office, refused to take responsibility for their mistakes and made a lot of promises (promotions, compensation) that they never kept. Management did absolutely nothing about any of the problems we had no matter how hard we tried to come to some solutions. If you end up on a bad team there’s really not much you can do. 
My branch also did not renew my 66 properly which led me to have to put in an appeal with FINRA at my new company to get the designation back.

You will face a lot of flak if you deliver independently with little supervision as it would mean PM's losing their relevance.
You will be given bad reviews in case you ask for some challenging work ( which are there in the US or Zurich office and are done my vendors).
Though it has the tag of a big bank but it doesn't operate like one.

headline: Wealth Management IT - what a mess!
pros:
Salary not bad if you negotiate well.
Firm is trying to move in the right direction but seems struggling to get there.
You can do very well if you can network and schmooze.
cons:
Weehawken office in middle of nowhere. No facilities apart from a crappy, expensive in-building restaurant and a bar that stinks.
NY commute requires you to depend on the abysmal NY Waterway ferry. If you live east of the Hudson don't even consider working there.
IT is hilariously poor, with developers being forced to use VDIs which take 15 seconds to start Word. 
Firm  is ridiculously bureaucratic and political; processes are sloooooow!

headline: Hierarchical, ego driven company, your face has to fit.
pros: They have a nice new London Office
cons: To progress or get any acknowledgement for your work its about how much noise you make about what you do rather than having made any genuine input or contribution. They are by far the biggest box ticking organisation I have ever witnessed. False corporate noise about progression, reward etc. They like to make everything seem bigger than it is, ultimately driven by the bottom line there is no fairness or honesty. Wasted 8+ years. I have taken my 25 years experience elsewhere.

headline: Decent place, but concerning future
pros: Very flexible work/life balance. For Nashville employees, the job functions are unique to the area and definitely look good on a resume. It’s interesting work that makes you feel meaningful in the industry. Great place for a college kid to put some stuff on their resume. Generally very nice people around the office.
cons: Pay below industry standard. The age old, gotta kiss up to move up applies significantly here. There is a large gap and disconnect between employees and management. Morale is not the greatest across the board, from Stamford to New York to Weehawken to even Nashville. There was a concentrated effort to keep the morale in Nashville high for a few years, which gave way to typical corporate disconnect from above. Sitting in a town hall and listening to a senior manager brag about his juiced up car was a disgrace. There is a lot of turnover, from very senior management down to entry level employees.

headline: Internal Audit
pros: Some good managers.  Short hours and high WFH flexibility
cons:
Extremely archaic process with no significant training given. 

Near complete lack of access to the resources and support available to auditors at other firms. 

Management and leadership much more concerned with semantics and appearances than audit testing and business control quality. 

No upwards or lateral mobility whatsoever.  Most employees want out and end up having to go to second-rate audit departments at other firms and or take significant demotion to leave.

headline: Quality people, but very bureaucratic
pros: hiring process is rigorous, resulting in generally very high-quality coworkers
cons:
1. Very poor IT culture outside of R&D and cutting edge investments.  If you see a very simple change that raises work quality, reduces errors, saves money and reduces employee frustration, chances are slim to none that it will ever come to pass.

2. High quality employees will burn out and leave from frustration once realizing that their tactic in many areas is to take advantage of ambitious, driven professionals by overworking them at the expense of their work-life balance rather than acting on even the simplest opportunities to improve the process and infrastructure.

cons: Compared to other banks, it is more like a prison except that people are generally polite to your face. You must never be seen to be actually doing work else you will be seen as lower caste. Everyone is trying to pawn off work on everyone else and then own the success. The few good people usually do not last.

headline: Find a good team
pros: The team I worked on was great - the advisors were supportive and gave me a lot of opportunities to make my role an analyst type position. UBS looks good on a resume especially if you can stretch your responsibilities/ do more than just admin work. If I didn’t work for this team I would have been looking for a new position earlier.
cons:
The office was very dysfunctional and unprofessional.
Our admin manager would try to disrupt teams and create problems. Management definitely does not truly care about your growth and development. They do not support you moving out of a CSA role no matter how many exams or designations you pass as I noticed with several other associates jn our office. The only “development” offered is administrative development. If you don’t take it upon yourself to learn more and teach yourself more, you will be stuck doing the same thing for extremely low pay for the rest of your life. The compensation is embarrassing and not competitive. The company / offices no longer award bonuses so it’s basically up to your FAs to dish out large percentage of their production to you

headline: Extremely Traditional company led by risk averse individuals
pros:
- location (central ZH)
- good maternity leave (6 months paid leave for mothers)
cons: UBS is led by employees who have been in the bank since they have joined the workforce (so without exposure to other business models, working cultures). It is a very risk averse culture where there is no accountability and no one likes to make a decision that might impact their comfortable salaries and bonus. Promotion criteria are not clearly defined and discretionary to management and only happen once a year where very few get promoted. Even though challenging status quo is part of the mission the minute you challenge anything you will become persona non grata. Stay far away from this place if you want to develop as a professional and grow.

headline: Worst company culture
pros: You are well remunerated and there are opportunities to move globally
cons:
Open bullying on the floor, abusive e-mails and sexism. People progress based on the cliques they have formed rather than merit and normally people who are intelligent such as Portfolio Managers and Analysts are treated badly by less educated sales staff.

Very unprofessional environment with no one taking  ownership. 

Racism and backstabbing not uncommon. HR is very inefficient and they have no interest in dealing with the issues.

This is only an observation for the Asset management division in Sydney. The investment bank is known to be a more professional environment.

cons:
- Constant change - new managers, team members cut, teams merged - it feels like a headless chicken is running HK sometimes
- Long hours for junior staff 
- Salaries are way below HK market rates for locals
- Old fashioned processes - made to perform compliance controls that seem like they are from the 1990s
- Culture is still an issue - the IB still has issues a la Kweko Adeboli and Tom Hayes - if anything goes wrong, be prepared to be a scapegoat so management can be protected
- UBS is potentially going to be banned from sponsoring IPOS due to misconduct - expect big cuts when this happens

headline: A mess
pros: It's a big company with a name people recognize in finance
cons: The organization has no direction

headline: 5 years down the drain
pros:
- Lot of vacation days
- Lot of smart people 
- Good downtown location
cons:
- Zero opportunity for promotion, its hard finding anyone that was promoted without leaving first and coming back, which is apparently the working formula to get a raise 
- Performance reviews are 1 - 5 stars, but they will never give you more 3 even if you have worked like a slave and reached all the objectives set out for you in your performance meeting at beginning of the year, just look at the UBS ticker on NYSE and you can see why nobody is getting promoted or a decent raise, not rocket science, just poor business management hidden under the guise of you not performing
- They wont fire anyone who is a perm UBS employee. Yes thats right, loooot of dead weight sitting around, one older guy who is clearly hammered at work quite often working out of Weehawken office, going home at 2pm, just riding out the train until he retires. Another guy that was taking sick days 3 or 4 times a month because they dont track them
- Management is constantly doing re-orgs, which is laughable comedy amongst the grunt workers in Nashville office, they send out a new email nearly every other week tooting their horns of who is in what new position, its like musical chairs every month, they have not a damn clue wtf they are doing 
- Technology at UBS is the most antiquated, unorganized, paper / approval heavy monster I have ever seen, people have left for this alone
- Very PC, everything so politically correct, people afraid to crack jokes and mess around, feels like your in the boy scouts or a church youth group, utterly strange from a culture perspective 
- You pay for your own parking at the office, they make the contractors take a shuttle from Nissan Stadium, which is sad and creates a culture of segregation

headline: Racism and harassment
pros: None, at least you will receive your wage
cons:
If you are not a person from mainstream culture,  prevent yoursefl from applying in the Luxembourgih branch of this company.
I had to suffer sexist and racial insults during four months. Bananas have been put on my desk several time by a collegue, without any reaction from any other employee. 
A spyware have been  installed on my personal mobile phone. 
My privacy has been exposed and commented in the open space every single day.
They humiliated me and push me into despair until I resigned. (They tried to retain me in the company, I really don't know why.)
While doing so, they explained me that I communication issues and that I shoud better accept these behaviours in a kind of "blackmail for employment".  
They protect each other because these behaviors are acceptable in that company.
Nobody deserves to be treated like this, you can find a better working environment elsewhere. Believe me.

headline: Stagnant workplace
pros: I worked in the ops dept UBS under a contract company full time for the past 2 years. While I am not directly employed at UBS, the benefits such as leaves and medical benefits are decent enough.
cons:
- same role for the past 2 years: i was doing the same task for the past 2 years with no opportunity to learn other tasks in other teams because the work load is so heavy that they are not able to sacrifice any amount of time to train staff to process other documents.
-compromising quality for quantity: mgt would rather overwork their staff than hire new staff to assist with the growing workload- and you would get blamed if you are not able to cope with the unrealistic workload that is constantly growing. They do not take into consideration that you are human and that you do get tired too. They expect you to be accurate and consistently fast at all times for every single work day. Be prepared to get questioned if you slip for just 1 day.
-favouritism abounds: only people who are considered close to the line manager would be noticed and praised regardless of merit. The mgt here is a bit blind to who is actually contributing. 
- achievements not recognised: this leads me to continue on to this point where only those who are recognised by the line manager would get acknowledged for their contributions. 
- old mindset: for a company that apparently embraces diversity( anything different etc.) and keeps harping about it all the damn time, the line managers here still utilises face time to gauge the quality/value of an employee. Bottom line is, if you dont ot, you aren't a good employee. 
Absence of work-life balance: since your line managers expects you to OT, you can bet that work-life balance is non existent. I wont even rate it a zero. It's actually a negative.

headline: Infuriating Politics, no Work-Life Balance
pros: reasonable pay,  free fruit twice a week, coffee and tea in the break room, good benefits including Multisport card and private healthcare, time off for some public and religious holidays.  at least one person quits every month, so there's always cake and sweets.
cons:
The equipment is outdated and the systems are slow, making it difficult to complete tasks in a timely manner.

The absolute worst part about this job is the upper management.  There is a 100% focus on making money (obviously), and employees do suffer because of it.  The teams are understaffed, leading to planned holidays being cancelled, and if someone is out of the office, the other people in the team are expected to do required overtime.   To leave on time is to leave early.

Employees are often encouraged to offer our ideas of how to improve the workplace, but those ideas are consistently shot down because they will cost too much time or money.

There is a palpable lack of respect that comes from the upper management and onshore colleagues, which at times boarders on harassment and racism.

Once a year, after your performance review, you are invited to sit and receive information about whether or not you will get a raise and/or bonus.  This is no negotiation.

Honestly, my advice is to stay away from this place.

headline: UBS is a great company to work for and has a great work environment
pros: Very talented people work here. They want everyone to strive to be the best. Employees help one another even if they’re on different teams. It’s a business environment but there is a good balance of fun mixed in. The office is absolutely gorgeous and very modern looking. Definitely appealing to clients as well for the employees.
cons: There seems to always be technology issues and it doesn’t feel like the company is allocating enough money to the tech department.

It will never be a good place to work with current people involved in running it.

headline: Investment Consultant

headline: Client Service Associate
pros: Generous time off, banker hours, experience looks good on resume, and entry into the industry (kinda), free coffee, occasional free lunch
cons: I had a great relationship with the office management during my internship and when I began working full-time out of college with my aspirations known to move into a program that pipelines one to become an advisor. I received numerous endorsements for two separate programs from many well regarded advisors, however HR seems spitefull of those seeking greater advancement and opportunity. There seems to be a Stark divide between the advising and support sides of the house. While eventhough advisors can recommend you for open positions, the HR would rather keep you tied on the support side and hire outside. I feel like I've wasted time pursing an opportunities that were closed by someone simply either not hire another for my position or because of the old "buy your time" card. The advisors are aging as the business is changing and many see that in order to keep up with online/discount broker firms they must adapt and bring in ambitious younger talent to seek new business and be taught the art of the relationship, but this is not allowed by HR and you are better off coming directly into UBS from the outside. My suggestion is, if you are under 40 years old do not bother looking at UBS unless you will be directly hired as a FA. Ultimately, this is leading to me to leave UBS.

headline: Highly under appreciative of hard work
pros: Very respectable firm.  Good benefits and good hours, and very reasonable PTO.
cons:
Scapegoat culture - when someone makes a mistake, they will push their blame onto someone else.  The result is that the higher paid/titled individual will get to tell their side, and the other person is blamed without being told their side of the story.  

High pressure and ultra high stress environment - multiple employees developing heart problems due to the intense stress.

Strong desire to "near-shore" compliance officers to Nashville.

headline: Hard on US employees; Firm still trying to figure it out since the crisis
pros: The firm can pay well if you are considered an "essential" employee.  Very international team, and you certainly get the sense of working for a global firm.
cons:
The heart of the firm is a Swiss Bank.  Once you've been there a few years, you'll discover that all employees are not equal; Swiss are treated well, everyone else in the US is good for as long as you might be useful.  The Risk Control area is undergoing stringent cost cutting at risk of creating problems for tomorrow (they are definitely cutting well below in Risk vs. US firms), and good senior folks are being shown the door, while Swiss employees replacing US personnel at all levels on expat contracts.   

Be very careful about being a senior hire here.   HR has fired numerous employees for "cause", usually on trumped up charges in order to avoid paying out deferred compensation and severance.  This place is only as good as your last direct deposit.

headline: Good start but can do better

headline: Great place to start a career
pros: Very good training at the entry level and the training programs are excellent.  GTP on the Wealth Management side is a 2 year rotation through the corporate offices and it gives you a sense of the behind the scenes roles supporting the financial advisors in the field.  Good people for the most part, and this is a key reason people stay at UBS.
cons: Little structured mobility or advancement is available further in one's career.  Managers hold tight to the people who work for them and you are left on your own to find your next job.  The firm is also very cheap - eliminating bonuses for admins; base salary pay is average in comparison with peers; they force a bell curve for performance reviews which limits salary increases and bonus pay.  The Swiss influence is felt and it is rigid and not sensitive to American workers.

headline: Compliance Analyst
pros: Great work life balance, great way to network and meet people, good benefits
cons: The line manager I had gives UBS a bad image. There has been a lot of turn over on the team,  people leave or the line manager finds a way to fire them. I think there is a major problem with the line manager that HR is not taking seriously. I believe the line has a connection HR where she is allowed to get away with her poor behavior and it doesn't help that their line manager is in other state making it hard to see what is really going on. The line comes into the office anytime they feel like it if they even come in at all. Often times I have experienced not knowing where the line manager was and couldn't get a hold of them because they was't online. I have experienced where you don't hear from them at all or see them in office with no email communications from them. The line has threaten not only me on the team but other team members, the line manager is a bully, talks down to you and overall has a negative impact on the team. The line manager loves to pull you into a conference room and yell at you, threaten your job and talk to you like your a child.  The line manager isn't open to hearing what you have to say, they prefer for you to not say a word and take orders. I got the impression while there that the team was scared of the line manager because when she'a around no one speaks to each other.  I have asked why haven't the other team members reported her to HR and I got the reply of "I don't want to lose my job" because they have seen her retaliate against someone. This is a terrible way to be a line manager, I have been working since I was 14 years old and never have I ever came across a manager like this one. Not every line manager at UBS is like this line manager, this one is by far the worse one I've seen and UBS needs to get rid of this line manager instead of going off what this line managers says to get rid of good employees. There is a reason why the turnover is a lot on this team.

headline: Investment banking- what you would expect
pros: If you want the classic IB experience, UBS is a good place to do it. It’s not the very top of the league tables, but in general there’s a lot of M&A and financing activity. I would say that compared to what I’ve heard about other banks, UBS is also pretty relaxed and less formal than other places on Wall Street. Depending on your group I guess your experience might be more intense and serious, but I would say the culture across the bank is pretty positive. Banking in general is a lot of work, but if you know what you’re getting into and still want to do it, UBS is a good place to get the experience you need when entering the finance world.
cons:
Junior people turn over quickly, so it can feel at times that senior leadership doesn’t invest in the development of analysts. Also within groups senior people/staffers play favorites and give all of the best projects to their favorite analysts. 

Additionally, oftentimes hard work from the junior bankers goes unrecognized. Don’t get a lot of “thank you’s” from the people that I spend 75+ hours per week doing work for.

headline: Stay away
pros: Solid vacation, great maternity plan (5 months), decent work/life balance (depending on manager and time of year)
cons:
Where to begin...to name a few:

- Flat salary: they don't even increase it for inflation. What is the point of having performance reviews if you get 0 incentive to work harder? 

- Insensitive/ignorant/discriminatory colleagues: have received rude and flat out ignorant emails from entitled financial advisors who think they are the greatest thing since sliced bread. Some people can't tell the difference between me and a colleague when we look nothing alike. 

- Terrible HR: Insensitive to real issues (like sexual harassment that happened to me...was asked "are you sure that was meant for you" and "do you think it could have been a joke?" The onboarding process (or lack there of) would probably make any new hire regret their decision to make the move here. 

- No diversity: there are always talks about making UBS a more diverse place but that's a load of bs and apparently there's a "quota" they need to fill with POCs but no transparency of who sets that quota and what efforts are being made to actually fulfill on it. All of the GTPs (basically internal trainees that spend limited time in different rotations) look the same - white, privileged, children of employees that seem to get promoted faster than others..hmm....

And the list goes on and on...my advice is to STAY AWAY, especially if you are a person of color.

headline: A farce hidden behind a facade
pros:
Strong reputation.
Lots of in-house support (HR, gym, mental health, networks etc). 
Flexible for a finacial firm (late mornings/early leave as required, work from home etc.).
Attracts lots of truly motivated and hard working people.
cons:
Compensation/pay is a joke - once they have you, you have to fight for every penny increase and bonus, and constantly have to prove yourself.
Despite talking a lot about young talent and innovation, management are extremely sluggish to change and terrible at talent retention. The younger, more talented employees come and go constantly.
They encourage a 'challenge' culture, yet I've never experienced anything less than hostility whenever I challenged status quo. 
A problem I'm sure typical of many big banks/firms: it's tough for women to rise and get the respect that men receive. Again, UBS make a big show of valuing women in the workplace, but I have experienced and witnessed quite the opposite on many occasions. Including several issues that were escalted through HR by colleagues and resulted in disciplinary action.
I was at UBS for 5 years, and was still having the same meetings about the same challenges and issues throughout. How does this place function?
The peer review system is not only excruciating, but worthless and meaningless. 
IT systems are archaic, as are processes, again likely due to the lack of youth and capacity for creativity in the firm.

headline: Overall, a great place to work
pros: Has provided me with very challenging and exciting work for well over a decade. Many opportunities to move around within the organization, the structure and reporting lines are constantly morphing, so without up and changing or reapplying for a new position, you may find yourself just gradually shifting to new projects, new direct reports, new managers, all while bringing past experience to your resume. Overall, a great place to work, and also a good deal of workplace flexibility.
cons: Many changes in strategy at senior IT organizational level, can be  disruptive. For a number of years in a row, you would have a complete overhaul of the IT organization, goals, reporting lines, job titles, which lead to confusion. Then you start getting used to it, and whammy, the org changes again.  A lot of lost productivity, they need to get a unified vision that works, and really stick with it.

headline: Great business, depressing low energy culture (Wealth Management Americas)
pros:
- Business is very good. The wealth management business is breaking records constantly (which conversely makes it more frustrating when you are not rewarded accordingly)

- UTA pass provided for employees in Utah. This is a substantial benefit if you actually use it

- Nice office with views of the city, spacious workspaces

- Convenient location in heart of SLC, close to transportation, restaurants, malls, etc

- Largely a great group of hard working, respectful people who are both qualified and engaged

- Casual fridays
cons:
- Depressing low energy environment where most people haven't gotten raises in years, and are frustrated by non-existent bonuses while the business is breaking profit records year after year

- Internal promotion culture and policies that discourage people from moving around. Among other things UBS prohibits employees from getting raises or getting promotions when moving internally

- Health insurance is quite expensive. You get to pay a substantial fee if your spouse has access to insurance and you decline it

- Very limited opportunities for growth at the Utah office. Both because of limited availability or roles, but also because of limited exposure to senior management which mostly operates out of the NYC, Stamford, and Weekhawken offices

- A general culture in UBS where a large part pf the focus is on cutting costs instead of growing and seeking excellence. Senior UBS leadership takes a deliberate passive approach towards certain significant issues that could hamper the business in the future

- Compensation used to be quite good, but now it's barely average and raises are rare. Most employees leave to go and work for smaller regional banks in the area

headline: Marketing, Comms, Events, Sponsorship - Singapore
pros: Good annual leave, flexible dollars quite on par with market standards, nice & comfortable office space, good location in Singapore. Some good and friendly people across the firm.
cons:
No work life balance for my role, others with children automatically entitled to 830-530 work hours. Line manager is pro family but unfortunately not pro without family which is sad as we have our lives too, parents, siblings, partner etc.
Line manager is fickle minded and always take on more projects which always allocates to the one without children in the department. Somehow makes me feel penalized. 
Colleagues who are higher rank have higher pay and work life balance which is totally unfair, Directors and earn $10k above but yet just flick all the time consuming, admin and logistics work to the lower rank employees. Totally no respect for such colleagues. High turnover of the contract position as attitude by higher rank colleagues are incorrect, they always expect their work to be done first or prioritized first than others, it's a shared and not a dedicated resource. Line manager always emphasize on team work but the joke is the other colleagues don't even bother attending internal
staff engagements such as lunch and learn sessions, CSR activities, Dinner & Dance to name a few. Must learn to reward accordingly, although hours spent is not everything but it definitely mean something if the employee clocks in more than 12 hours of work for 1-2 weeks consecutively.

headline: Evaluate carefully before you join
pros:
* They can offer attractive looking compensation for the right fit.
* There are some quality people on UBS team
* Powerpoint ninjas and impressive talkers rule the place
cons:
* IB and Wealth Management appear to be doing ok. Asset Mgmt is under pressure with no coherent strategy
* Quality of systems & IT is very weak -- among the weakest in large banks. Not enough thought is spent on design. Help-desk is not helpful.
* Benefits are quite weak for a large company. In certain divisions, you'll have to move your accounts to UBS. That can amount to a meaningful financial penalty. Consider with overall offer (get it in writing)
 * Some in middle management were asking staff to give them good ratings on anonymous surveys

headline: Worst employer ever
pros:
good computer equipment. 
office is just OK. open space, no worse or better than in other companies in the area
cons:
-ridiculous corporate bureaucracy
-constant non-paid overtimes (you can choose extra vacation time to compensate, but not extra money)
-no freedom in choosing PTO time due to tight release cycle
-boring work, very old or outdated technologies used in projects, and this will not change in the nearest future due to conservationism of  the whole investment banking business
-very restricting corporate policies prevent quality of technical support. for example, to release a critical fix in the software, you need to get approval of 10 managers and people you barely know at all, and explain each of them why this is needed.  this is very time-consuming, and customers (end-users) are very unhappy and blame to software engineers

headline: All was good except the job itself
pros:
- good pay
- nice colleagues
- team/company events
- free tee/coffee
- paid traineeships/education/language courses
- paid overtime
- benefits
- work-life balance
cons:
There was not enough work. Literally. I was working for 2 or 3 (during 'lucky' days)hours/day, the rest of time - dying from boredom. And they wanted to hire more people to our team!! It is not like this in every department, but I was unlucky one to work in HR for the countries with not that many employees, so we had what we had.
The company is still very hierarchical. Some team leads were actually cool and easy-going, but some were arrogant, thinking they are 'big bosses' and due to this fact better than others.

headline: Senior Registered Client Service Associate
pros: The management team was effective and looked to provide opportunity from within the office.  The office culture was professional and friendly.
cons: Working with financial advisors often involves managing an ego.  Although necessary to succeed, that ego can also be a hinderance to improving client service or work satisfaction for others.  If you decide to work with an advisor, be sure your personalities mesh.

headline: Underperforming IT
pros: It's ok if you're not a career oriented person. They offer plenty of distractions from the day to day grind
cons: If you value software, architecture, and delivering value, this isn't the place for you. Production support, project management, architecture, design, and development policies are ineffective and not current with industry standards.

headline: Big slow company. Maybe it's a good financal organization, bit the worst it corporation.
pros: Big company. Long history. Good mission on paper. Much money. Good ideas with bad realisation. Good scope of technologies that could be used in right way.
cons:
Stupid security system - you spend a lot of time to get software for work, but you can get approve for anything unsecure also.
Legal department marked that I had a problems with the law, but I haven't any and I couldn't change it.
Silly trainings at the begining.
They spend a lot of time for meetings. Managers tries to make task instead of developers and engineer must to fix it after them.
They respect only managers. I had 4 managers at the same time. And every asked me every hour "How it's going?"
Scrum? Agile? Friendly atmosphere? Forget about it.

headline: Slow and steady
pros: Large bank with deep pockets can achieve great things when it really wants to. Is focusing on modernisation and change. Global company with a presence in many countries around the world.
cons: The most valuable asset the company owned were its employees, it had an amazing wealth of knowledge and skills sadly most are gone now and the company is a mere shadow of its former self. It has invested in cheap offshore locations and many employees are now outsourced and external staff. They care little for the company, usually don't stay at the company very long and provide a low cost low quality service. By virtue of this the company has become highly inefficient and unproductive, pressure is put on the few remaining onshore full time staff who can actually get the job done. Some outsourced location are not too bad Bucharest and krakow others are deplorable Pune. Amazingly some UBS locations and teams are still able to do great work and some leaders are still great, however this is the exception rather than the rule. Overall management are hopeless they are caught up in politics and mostly only look out for themselves. The company is trying desperately to change but there are very few who lead by example if any. The UBS brand name attracts some of the best talent that the market can offer at all levels but new joiners are often given menial tasks and the quality of mentoring is often poor.

headline: Analyst

cons: Workload and long working hours. Salary and bonus are off the market as there are no mechanism to adjust annually. A number of key talents are Long overdue for a promotion and pay rise.

headline: Not a company that will inspire you

cons: No bonus and no group or team activities. Management is into power play and does not listen to the lower levels. Employees with under AD levels are constantly being ignored and heard. Management will use the excuse of company is downsizing to remove anyone who is not working the way desire.  IT is horrible..most terrifying systems i had ever seen . No 360 review at all. No work life balance and your contribution is not rewarded often. Company again using excuse of downsizing. ..but we all know they publish quarterly profits year on year. Opportunities to grow is minimal as the people on top have the say.

cons: Relatively speaking, it's a boys club. There is a clear lack of diversity within senior management (MD level) and the Switz counter partners are really driving the direction of the firm. Seeing very few minorities (African Americans and Latinos) and woman at the top, which is discouraging and reflective of deeper issues.

headline: Equity Specialist

headline: Depends who/where you work for
pros:
Good time for people in Poland

Good time for apprentices. Many teams are recruiting apprentices instead of experienced staff because it is cheaper and the cost is taken from the apprentice budget pool.

My previous Manager was flexible with working hours.
cons:
As an experienced professional, your job is safe as long as you are needed. Otherwise, be prepared for the worst. The company seems to be full of divisive or incompetent management. My own team suffers from lack of communication. Staff are expected to know new procedures / duties which are not communicated. Some team environments are extremely toxic. If you are not on good terms with the right people, they will find the smallest excuses to victimize you.

With regards to personal  development, it depends on your relationship with the Manager.

UBS has been steadily cutting staff benefits over the past 5 years. Staff discounts and sports facilities have all disappeared. Restaurant subsidies have gradually been decreased.

Staff surveys are structured in a way that negative feedback is not possible.

headline: Up's and Down's

cons: Huge segregation between IT and other 'cost centre' operations and the actual business. Not competitive on salary and particularly don't reward people who have spent a long time with the company. Struggling to retain good people and not really doing an awful lot about that (presumably because it enables a shift to lower cost locations).

headline: Only apply if Thick Skinned and MALE
pros:
Time Off-Holidays, vacation days, family care days, personal days.
The only thing I liked about the job
cons:
-Aggressive Male Dominated-Lots of slamming things around and cussing
-Don't ever cry, it will be detrimental to your survival here
-Women are looked down upon
-There is 1 person with 20+ years professional experience to every 45 straight out of college kids-they do not value old blood. I have watched tenure walk out the door with all their knowledge-even forced.
-I worked here several years ago and came back because I liked my job then and was wanting the same job-didn't get the same job and 2 familiar faces still here after many many years
-Health benefits aren't great-you would think with thousands of employees, benefits would be good. They are not. 
-You will never know your job inside and out, you only doggy paddle day in and day out-No training-tenure left 
-very hard to succeed here, especially if you are a woman
-If you are a woman, and you go ahead and take a job here, either keep your mouth shut, do as your told and never show emotion, or be as strong as the men and run with them.. if you are anywhere in between, you will be noticed and challenged until you give up and leave

headline: Many benefits, a lot of bureaucracy and hard work
pros: Great benefits e.g. fairly flexible: work at home 1-2 days a week, take long lunch breaks (not paid), all overtime written down for employees below director rank so time in lieu means I end up with a week or two of extra holiday every year, thus total 7 weeks holiday. Possibility to go part-time for most employees, very supportive of working mothers where possible.
cons: Very high expectations and high workload. Competitive and very male dominated culture. Big difference between the corporate goals of having an equal workplace, and the actual reality of the culture and attitudes. Most colleagues are great but it is hugely bureaucratic, and despite very hard work, progress is incredibly slow.

headline: Work Life

headline: It really depends on what you do...
pros: Great vacation time, great benefits
cons: Your benefit from this work experience will depend on your role and ranking. Analysts seem to benefit the most, as middle management frequently gets lost in the shuffle. Upper management can either be extremely helpful or a detriment to your career growth, depending on their location and their general disposition. They tout corporate mobility, but you are limited to your particular role for 18 months. The pay is also below industry standards. Raises are limited to once a year. Promotions are nearly impossible.

headline: Great internal opportunities
pros: There are plenty of internal opportunities to improve one's network, skillset, knowledge. Also this is a great place to understand how the bigegst wealth manager worldwide is working and functioning.
cons: They are promoting internal mobility on the paper but once in the only person that will really help you is yourself. Also you might be confronted with above average conservative staff.

headline: Intern
pros: Great learning experience. From my time with the company, the advisors really care about having you integrate into their team and are open to speaking with you and helping you continue your education within the industry. There is so much to learn, given that every client is different and each wealth management/private wealth management team serves as it's own "business". The research, between Morning Star, Bloomberg, and various wholesalers is top notch. If you are given the opportunity to be sponsored for your licenses, DO IT! Overall, this has been a great internship experience
cons: One's experience can vary greatly depending on the team they are on. Even for an internship. the salary is low compared to the competition. If you value immediate pay over a learning experience, this isn't the internship for you. Also, due to the nature of the industry, some days will not be as busy as others. Full-time hiring upon the completion of your internship will be based on your team's capacity to convert/hire you. If you are lucky, they may refer you to someone who can use you in a new, full-time role if they cannot afford to convert you upon graduation.

headline: Process Associate

Work pressure
No freedom 
Worst Management

headline: Security
pros: Wonderful place to work at. Everyone is so helpful and nice, the atmosphere is really calm.
cons: You're harassed by security to pay for parking at the Weehawken branch. Money is tight for some people and to be harassed to have to pay 150 for a spot is outrageous. They put security at places that are not on UBS property. A nearby restaurant offered free parking because they do not own the lot, its own by the town, unless the restaurant had a problem with people parking there. But the restaurant doesn't open until 5 PM, and they seemed to not mind because most people leave here at 5 PM. That is my one and only con about working here is that you are harassed by security.

Management always available at all levels to help and guide

headline: Worst place to work ever
pros: To be honest nothing is good at all.
cons: I am working in UBS from more than one year and this is my review based on my experience. Worst place to work. Worst infrastructure. Worst canteen. No dinner facility for second and night shift people. No parking place for employees for two and four wheeler. Two people sits at one desk very congested. Facility staff is not helpful. Everyone uses VM machines so performance is very very slow. Even MS Word takes more than 5 mins to open and save document. Pathetic experience. Everyone will have to work in UBS in second or night shift.

headline: Director

headline: I love working here...

cons: None for me.  I travel alot but it's all part of the role.

headline: Good job, worst HR department ever
pros:
Interesting position, quite well paid
good management, positive spirit and inducement
cons:
Human Ressources are everything exept humans:
-They can fire you just for documents reasons even though you work proactively and give your best...just for irrelvant missing documents.
Although, I discovered later that they didn't contact the employers where some documents where missing to get further informations...my two previous employers did it !
-You can't really go personally to HR as they are located...at the other side of Krakow (it is maybe because they are the most hated department in the company?).
Any request HR related needs to be submited by a portal.

headline: Private Wealth Advisor
pros: Great private wealth platform and bank will provide all the resources you need to be successful in this business.  Highly motivated employees.    Best compensation on the street .
cons: Alts platform could be better.   Only lending they will provide is against clients current assets.  Miss out on a lot of biz dev opportunities by not having a commercial bank.  technology is also years behind other banks.

cons: Typical bank, some young inexperienced people, some old school stubborn self claimed experts.

cons: very difficult to move positions

headline: Slow to evolve...and keep up with industry trends
pros: Talented, committed professionals in all core locations.
cons: Notable cultural gap between New York and European lines of business.  Slow-moving culture pushing slow-moving initatives.  Tendancy to  over-engineer technologies and solutions.  Little agility.

headline: Worst employer of my career (out of 4).  Wish I regain wasted years.
pros: This is a sales driven environment, clients be darned.  If you generate revenue, you can be well compensated.  And if you cease to serve your clients, no one will care as long as you continue to post revenue.  In fact, you can behave very badly and people will put up with it if you post revenue.  But if your revenue is less than bullet proof, look out.  They will cut your head off and come after you for every penny they can find.
cons: No HR, no orientation, no mercy, no internal help, poor benefits, retched office environment.  Need something internal?  Good luck figuring out who to talk to.  Need something for a client?  Be prepared to pull teeth and twist arms to get it done.  Navigating the IT systems?  They're a mile wide.

headline: Working at UBS
pros:
* Friendly and congenial Swiss work culture. Unlike the "in-your-face" NY-based i-bank culture.

* Very diverse work force

* Have ability to work across organizations, geographies and management levels

* Worked with many very professional, dedicated and cooperative people regardless of rank.
cons:
* Control too centralized in Switzerland. Discourages initiative-taking.

* Lack opportunity to innovate.

* Needed to strengthen IT risk management  to reduce irrational fear and management indecision. Implement risk removal, avoidance, mitigation or acceptance process.

* Have fixed mindset culture. Lack opportunities and investment to train or develop people  for different roles. People often get pigeonholed into same or similar roles,

* Corporate goal of only paying market median. Unable to  attract the best and brightest at top of salary scale. 

* Global managers reluctant to travel outside NY area, London, Zurich to better understand global environment, business and staff and end up making myopic decisions. 

* Work life balance good for US and European staff and management but poor for Asia Pacific.  In APAC, terrible conference call hours with US and Europe, i.e.  midnight calls, and having to constantly fight to be heard and influence global decision makers.

headline: Director
pros: People are some of the brightest and best in the industry.  Global reach and mobility of talent enables a glide path of development if you take it upon yourself to step up and drive your career forward.
cons: Multiple significant restructurings since 2010 and several key senior management departures all leads to confusion in teams in the overall strategy of where the division is headed and, most importantly, how do we get there.  In past years, I've loved working here.  In recent years, I see a decline in results, strategic direction and  employee morale.

headline: Following the Strategy
pros: After almost bankrupting itself and Switzerland, UBS has undertaken a strategy to limit the trading risk that almost brought it down and focus on its best attribute, Wealth Management.  This new focus has been well-communicated to (and accepted by) its employees who now fully strive to reach the objective of becoming the most profitable bank in the world.
cons: The downside to this vision is it is being rigidly, almost militantly, being pursued by senior management.  This stifles alternative thinking and suppresses innovation and collaboration.

There is no accountability for bad managers at the middle and senior level. Lack of diversity and no focus on promoting from within. Managers focus and promote those that look like themselves or who they like personally.

headline: Terrible benefits - worse technology (1995 tech!)
pros: Big bank name on the door
cons:
Wort benefits of any large company I've ever worked for and by far the worst of the major wirehouses.

Moved all employees to a high deductible health plan in 2016. UBS's monthly contribution to our plans went down, mine went up slightly, and our benefits got a LOT worse.

I pay extra for the "Plus" health plan. $3500 deductible (no copays for office visits, you pay 100% until you hit the deductible) and $6000 out of pocket max. This plan costs me $800 per month and costs UBS $103 per month.

401k match is a joke. UBS will match 100% of your payroll contributions to the Plan, up to 6% of your eligible
compensation, subject to an annual maximum match of $3,000.

Vacation days do NOT roll over.

Unfortunately, the technology we use makes the benefits look great by comparison. Most systems are built on top of systems designed in the mid to late 90's. Everything is built to run through Internet Explorer. The managed account trading platform is built with FRAMES! Frames were briefly popular in the mid-nineties before professional web designers discovered all sorts of issues and stopped using them. This is a highly profitable division of the company and is forced to use 30 year old technology!

headline: Account Vice President
pros: Global Reach and wealth managment

cons: The career opportunities are rather limited. Too much political games. Bureaucracy is also too extensive. Total compensation is also rather limited.

headline: Client Service Associate

cons: During tax season everyone wants something and it is impossible to get daily task and extra work done.

headline: Client Onboarding Analyst
pros: UBS has a very friendly environment with an emphasis on growth and challenging the status quo. Great experience for an entry level position.
cons: Some may find it difficult to move up the ladder due to so many people being on the same level (entry level), but give it time and/or gain as much experience as possible and use that to your advantage.

headline: Big Banks all the same
pros: UBS is a good brand. Take lot of pride in client data safeguarding. Reasonable flexibility for work-life balance, working from home to take care of urgencies although it depends on your group / team. some great people to work with. good avenues of internal mobility.
cons: Culture is not transparent. Lot of talking behind backs. Many meetings to move even a small thing. projects are halted or stagnated by the fear of outliers or exceptional situations so things move slow and get frustrating. Senior leadership and directions / operating models keep changing. Many times getting things done is overly process oriented and vendor dependent. No matter what you get told, your comp is not determined by what you have accomplished but what one small insignificant thing you didn't know you are supposed to do i.e., there is always a reason to penalize people.

headline: Great company
pros: great work life balance, people very helpful in your development, better culture than other banks, forever changing and innovating

headline: Working at UBS

Interesting work

headline: Overall positive experience
pros:
- career growth: opportunity to grow your career by learning from peers, internal training courses, short workshops 
- healthy environment: most of the staff treat other each well. Teamwork attitude with a focus on helping the community multiple months of the year 
- access to management: you can typically meet with senior management easily on a quarterly basis. I also feel like line manager support is good
- benefits: nice amount of time off from day 1 and decent 401k match
cons:
- Reviews/Compensation: One yearly review where the metrics to succeed are very tough. Everyone is "average" on the scale and very tough to break through the average threshold. Compensation lacks workload. You will feel underpaid for 1-2 years due to workload before you are recognized with a raise in compensation. Also, compensation discussion is yearly after reviews. You never see off cycle raises. 
Insurance: HSA model which can be difficult for families

headline: Keeping my head down, doing the best I can, with the goal of professionally growing while advancing my career.
pros: Excellent benefits.  3 weeks vacation, 8 sick days, 2 personal days when hired.  Company funded HSA which is yours whether you stay or leave the firm and is replenished every year.  Generous family leave when you have children.
cons: Micro-managed.  Severely underpaid at 50K a year compared to the market we work and peer firms.  Unless you live locally the commute is undesirable.  Severely understaffed and overworked teams, which in my time, clearly has negative impacts on morale across the teams and produces over 40% turnover in the first year of employment for new hires.  Have to stay in the role for 18 months before you can look at other career opportunities/paths in the firm.

headline: Could be better

headline: UBS TMT (London) review from an Associate
pros:
+ Excellent European telecom credentials (top 3 in the world)
+ Industry-leading clients (Vodafone, Telefonica for example)
+ Great exit opps.
+ Fantastic work ethic of the team
+ Senior team has excellent technical backgrounds
+ Collegiate work environment amongst juniors
cons:
- Notorious for long hours
- VPs can be very controlling - Associates can be stuck doing analyst work for years
- Hierarchical - junior/senior relationships need work
- Excessive / superfluous analytical work at times (especially in the context of marketing books)
- Some senior team members are difficult to work with / poor at inspiring/leading juniors

headline: Wealth Planning Analyst
pros: Terrific opportunity to get your CFP designation.  You will have access to large advisors.
cons: The company does a poor job of partnering you with an advisor to advance your career.  It can feel like you are on an island.

headline: former employee
pros: Big name, good for CV.
cons: Too big and probably expanded too much the few years before the collapsed of Lehman Bros and lots of below standard people in the company.

headline: Technical Business Analyst Intern

Good Pay
~40 work week
People are friendly

cons: At the moment, I do not have any complaints about UBS as an employer. Wealth management inherently has lower bonus potential than Investment Banking due to advisory fees compared to transnational fees.

headline: Pay attention, unless you work in Poland
pros:
UBS is still a famous name in the banking world, and gives great development opportunities, that will enable you to grow very fast.
It has the best work-life balance of all companies where I worked for
cons:
Your job is not secure anymore. UBS is working on a major project to nearshore or outsource some activities to countries like Poland, where there is massive hiring. 
If you are Polish, I would say : go ahead... You have a great and interesting future ahead of you
If not, you might end up with colleagues who live in stress and fear of loosing their job. The administrative burden has also exploded in the recent years, so if you like to get things done the quick and dirty way, maybe better not work in a bank...

hard to break management gardes to work cross platforms.

cons: The need for Series 7 license and other licensing. I found interest in the client service and events, but was not interested in securities and other investments.

headline: Good
pros: You can have a long career here.
cons: To advance you have to fight for it.

headline: Series of unfortunate and unending bad news
pros: Big name, growth in Asia
cons: There was a continuous flow of bad news over a decade, from overexposure to mortgage meltdown, to overpaying for acquisition of Paine Weber to LIBOR manipulation to London trader issue..not sure what the breakthrough is other than to look for leadership in Asia and cut down bulge bracket ambitions in the US

headline: Review
pros: UBS has  a great culture. They also provide a significant amount research and reports that serve as a great help in a support role.
cons: in the location i worked, their systems seem to always have technical issues but overall a great firm to work for.

headline: The place to be in Wealth Management
pros: Very focused business strategy. Solid grow forecast despite a challenging regulatory and market environment.
cons: Downward pressure on compensation levels for non financial advisors. Cost cutting exercises and risk of reorgs.

headline: Good culture
pros: good culture in general and decent work life balance
cons: aweful IT system and support

headline: Pays well but slow moving
pros: Pays ok and Strong market position
cons: Bureaucratic, Culture not great, Poor IT

headline: Director
pros: Good work life balance and global investment bank.
cons: Lack of transparency regarding pay/promotion and limited opportunities for career advancement or guidance from senior managers.

headline: Emerging Markets, Fixed Income
pros: Bank has one of the best platforms to engage clients and create a viable and effective solutions.  Found resources to be available when needed and management stayed engaged in support of business.
cons: Risk management is not properly managed and views revenue centers as enemies instead of partners.

headline: Associate Director
pros: Great place to work if you are looking for a great work life balance.
cons: Too much of hierarchy.  No significant salary incentives for long term employees. you see lot of talented people leaving due to this issue.

headline: Not recommended
pros: Salary is nice here, standard benefits system. Most people are nice and friendly.
cons: There is a big mess in HR department. There is a constant improvment in place which makes is impossible to relay on something. Systems that are in use, Oracle programm - HRi is a joke. There is no development plan, no career path within teams. Trainings are only internal, provided by internal people.

headline: Senior Software Developer
pros: Within IB IT, the company various teams work together as one bank helping each other.
cons: Like many investment banks, most senior management over IT does not have an IT or engineering background.   They don't invest in IT systems or IT people as much as many younger and more high tech banks.

headline: Financial Advisor (Wealth Advice Center)
pros: Great environment to work in and as long as you work hard and hit your goals, no one will bother you about anything.  In addition, if you do put in the hours above the regular 9-5, you will be paid out very nicely quarterly and with the end of the year bonus.  There is also a very fair salary that comes with the whole package.
cons: Goals change a lot and certain quarters, they will be much harder to get even if you work 2x as hard as a previous quarter and still not get paid as much.  The Wealth Advice Center division is a few years young, so they are still changing compensation structure as each year goes on.  It sometimes is unfair, as they have in the past overpaid one team, in a certain quarter, and did not pay the other teams much.  What was unfair, was that the goals were made impossible the following quarter, and no one got paid.   So in retrospect, about 18 advisors from the Prospect team made 20-25k in one quarter, and overall that much more than other advisors for the year.

headline: Bad management in UBS Krakow
pros:
The biggest Swiss Bank in the world.
Swiss culture in the bank.
A lot of opportunities within the Bank
cons:
terrible management.
huge gaps in the processes.
lack of team spirits

headline: Financial Advisor

headline: Wealth Management Intern

headline: Intern

headline: Associate Director

cons: Pace of offshoring efforts are causing problems for increasing downsized onshore operations teams. Offshoring does make sense in this environment but processes that have evolved over decades need to be fine tuned and fully understand before simply send offshore.

headline: WM London
pros: Brand, offering, office, team, international footprint

headline: Equity analyst
pros: Working with talented individuals, being able to generate interesting research findings on behalf of clients
cons: Never ending job insecurity post 2008, woeful IT, management gave the impression of being very reactive and favouring a few individuals

headline: Great experience

Very knowledgable and intelligent people

headline: Investment Banking Analyst

Receive top-notch financial modeling, market analysis and excel skills
Taught to be polished, exact and demonstrate attention to detail with all work produced
cons:
work hours are strenuous
sometimes, management is too busy to assist, have to figure out difficult problems on your own, must work autonomously often

headline: Good if they need you
pros: Benefits, pay, lots of smart people

headline: An exceptional brand to work for

headline: Great company to work for! Strong values and strong brand.

cons: Work life balance can be somewhat difficult,  but otherwise none, a very rewarding place to work for. I'm truly grateful!

Great Place to Work
Roadshow Coordinator- was a great position

headline: UBS Former Employee

headline: Registered Client Service Associate

headline: Average experience

headline: Client Resolution Specialist
pros: UBS has a Great work-life balance. It is a well recognized global company with many opportunities for employment.
cons: The compensation in Nashville is a little less than I originally hoped. You have to be in your role 18 months before you can move internally.

headline: UBS Wealth Advice Center, used to be great.
pros: Pay is alright and benefits packages can't be beat. You need to have a chess game mentality to climb up in the ranks here.
cons: Management from Merrill Lynch was brought in, in bulk along with the head Executive Director of Merrill Edge, Rich Steinmeier. There was a long transition process with these new managers. They changed the Investment Center which was mainly a service center, into a full blown sales model, complete with commission compensation, and an Investment Product guide that lists what the FAs can sell. Management runs a tight ship and trying to keep up with sales goals will burn you out. Once that happens you either need an exit strategy, or otherwise you will be fired and easily replaced by someone who will have 90 days to get a series 7 and 66, and then they begin selling products with little to no experience.

headline: Good place to work at

Talented people. 
Chilled work place with good benefits
cons: Rigid work responsibilities, not growing its employees or promoting their creativity

headline: Equity Derivatives Structuring

cons: low internal salary increases, a lot of administrative work for team leaders, narrow training range.

headline: In the very early stages of something that is going to be best in class one day.
pros: The culture is great - friendly, inclusive, encouraging. I am given a lot of rope to run with and expectations are manageable.
cons: There is an old, stale mentality of "no" or "this is the way we've always done it". This "old guard" needs to go.

headline: Good place to work

headline: Executive Director
