headline: Mixed thoughts
pros:
1) Great culture / people at the junior to mid-senior levels
2) Strong deal flow and a lot of opportunity for junior bankers to punch above their weight
3) Compensation is decent at the junior to mid levels
cons:
1) Confused, ever-changing and poorly communicated strategy
2) Internal approvals are extremely bureaucratic and made worse by a culture of constant buck-passing by the people who are required to sign-off
3) Turnover results in best people leaving
4) Management talk a big game about career development with zero action
5) Strategy is overly dependent on China

headline: Communication Lacking
pros: There are great people to learn from.  Online training is a good resource if you take advantage of it.
cons: Technology is behind some of the top banks.  Communication is very slow or nonexistent from senior managers.  If you are not in Switzerland or London it is difficult to become promoted.

headline: Awesome is the single word I have for UBS
pros: Gives chances to new Grads and investing time in them for their growth to ensure they become the future leaders of the organization

headline: Business Analyst

cons: The company is managed poorly because they promote friends instead of qualified individuals for high profile positions

headline: graduate trainee
pros: brand name and culture etc
cons: cost-cutting, competitive, offshoring to china

headline: Low advancement bonus potential in Operations
pros: There are some decent people who work there
cons: Like the title says - a lot of zeros for raise and bonus year after year

headline: Director
pros: Pays well.  Perfect place to be if the network is in place.
cons: Each area is different in the bank

headline: Oblivious senior management creates atmosphere of just do enough to not get fired
pros: The people in middle management and lower are the sole reason pleasure working at UBS.
cons: Raises do not exist below MD level; executive management is clueless and they prefer it that way; senior management very weak and pass blame down the ladder, so when time for layoffs come you know who gets hit; PaineWebber leftovers long for the days of Joe Grano and the like. The Swiss are not ideal to work for in the US. They love to tout their values and integrity, but the same small group of kook-aid drinkers are the only ones to get anywhere, don't see much integrity there. Management insists on using performance evaluations that have been cast aside by every major company, including GE who started it. Doesn't matter how good you perform, someone has to get the bad grade if too many already have high marks.

headline: Software Developer
pros: Great place to work. A lot of opportunity
cons: Very corporate world. But great if that's your goal

headline: All Around Great Company
pros: Excellent people engagement, induction & welcoming process, training and colleagues. UBS London & Zurich are wonderful establishments and I was truly happy with my time their and I hope to rejoin the firm at a later stage in my career.
cons: Technology, I was in the risk management and the system is in need of complete overhaul.

headline: Branch Service Associate / Client Service Associate
pros: Benefits, professionalism, corporate culture, and collegues
cons: Little training. Liitle room for growth and employee advancement.

headline: Overall Thoughts
pros: Good people, work from home flexibility, limited micro-management
cons: Leadership shortage, asset-gathering challenges, global model complexities

headline: Summer internship
pros: Brilliant experience working in the group technology division at UBS. Was givien a lot of responsibility.
cons: The training in the induction week was not very relevent to the work I was completing during the internship.

headline: Overall a great corporate culture.
pros: UBS has a great network. It's all what you make of it. Culturally, the people are great. Overall people are motivated and team-oriented. Essentially, the people. Also, work life balance: roughly 24 vacation days + carry overs and personal days. Not crazy hours depending on what part of the bank you work in.
cons: Budget cuts. Upward mobility for more junior employees. I think many people get frustrated as the firm seems to be penny wise....

headline: Technology Summer Analyst
pros: Lovely and kind colleagues, friendly environment, responsible line managers. It has been a really valuable experience working at UBS, I was able to contribute to the company and learn a lot of new things.
cons: Us interns needs to be proactive to find out what exact to achieve during the 9 weeks mainly through our own effort, which is not so easy as a new joiner. Though lucky enough to join a team that was suitable for my strengths and skills, still feel that I can achieve more if there was a more designated project for a group of interns.

headline: An increasingly innovative sell-side research house
pros: Innovative, disciplined approach to research
cons: None specific to UBS come to mind

headline: Used to be good, now you wonder what it's for
pros: Some very good people in trading and sales still left. The underlying ethos of the firm is good and the IB CEO is inspiring even if he is letting his senior guys run amok.
cons:
UBS investment bank can't seem to work out what's for (this is probably true of a lot of investment banks though). As a result all it does is change. Any radical idea from senior management is implemented as long as it is seen to be "change" and no one can speak up against it. As a result the franchise is being destroyed. Good people been fired on a whim or because they push back slightly on some new crazy idea. Others just see the light and leave. 

The effectiveness of the salesforce has been hit by various intiatives which seem to change year by year. You sort of get used to one, explain it to your clients and so on - and then a completely different one comes along. This devalues the franchise with the client base. Macro research is a mess, with new managers having ripped out or driven away all the good parts of it in favour of their much less capable friends. Trading is a little better, but everyone has been told not to use balance sheet so it's difficult to get a good price any more and the firm seems to be losing market share continuously.

headline: Wealth Management Intern
pros: It's an internship accessible to non-juniors and the brand name of the firm sets you up nicely for summer analyst recruitment during your junior year.
cons: The day-to-day work in wealth management is a bit repetitive and European banks are declining in general.

headline: Project Manager

headline: Huge disappointment
pros: - Great team members in the team
cons:
- Manager was not controlling at all what was going around. Teammates had no support when needed, the Manager just focused on unrealistic client's needs.When asked for help, it was swept under rug and instead we heard corporate jargon chat.
- No room for dialogue, was told to do things just because it is said so
- Long hours and huge workload, the management did not want to accept the fact the team was understaffed, instead of that more tasks were assigned
- The Manager who was based remotely was not able to conduct proper 1:1, often times rescheduling and cancelling them. When they happened it was pretty much monologue from the Manager side.
- micromanagement on each step
- "seniority" driven company - if someone was higher rank than you, sometimes it was like master - servant relationship
- my annual performance was evaluated after 4 months being there (of which 3 were probation period) by a Senior Manager I have not ever met or spoken to! The evaluation was not even confronted  with me, just  communicated.

The tasks are very monotonous and you will hardly have a chance to be a game changer due to the very cumbersome processes. The bank is driven by legal, compliance and costs cutting. No client focus and bad reputation. Most people have been in place for years (despite reorganisations) and just cannot adapt to a moving world and change their habits.

headline: Please avoid UBS Asset Management
pros: I hope to keep in touch with some of my coworkers for the entirety of my career. They have provided me with a wealth of industry knowledge, friendship, and hundreds of laughs. I will remember the company events and bizarre moments I shared with great coworkers.
cons:
UBS Asset Management is a San Andreas Fault of systemic issues.

The dysfunction is unlike anywhere I have ever experienced in my entire life. There's a terrifyingly large portion of the office that still believes it's 2007. There are no consequences for an employee breaking protocol. You’d be more likely to get fired for wearing shorts on casual Friday than for losing the company money. There have been significant cost cutbacks to make the appearance of being a responsible and forward thinking member of the banking community. The cuts have hit bone in certain departments. It’s not feasible to do any job effectively or accurately. 

Some business essential software hasn’t been updated since before the recession. You’ll use your talents to surmount these shortcomings and implement process improvements with what you have. The condescending executives, will make careless and disturbing mistakes habitually. You’ll put their confusingly immature attitudes aside and work with them anyway. You’ll even show them how to operate their own trading platforms. You’ll be rewarded at the end of the year by a conversation such as “I know UBS made $5 billion this year but you won't be seeing any of that. It’s not how it works here.”

You’ll put this aside and work even harder the next year, motivated by what you think will be a one-time disappointment. You’ve held the pieces, figuratively and literally, together for a little longer. Your mental and physical health have declined. Your friends and family will “hardly recognize” you. 

Another year has passed. There are now permanent and complex issues fixed due to your hard work and creativity. “This is it, UBS will finally show me that it values me as an employee”, you say. 

Last year’s disappointments have taught you to manage expectations. With a little luck, you’ll get a small promotion or a small raise. Heck, even a cost of living adjustment will be enough to keep you going.

Your review begins with a manager who you haven’t seen in the office for six months. The conversation begins, “I know UBS made $6 billion this year but you won't be seeing any of that. It’s not how it works here.”

If only I had listened to that Glassdoor review from years ago.

pros: Great location even if moving over the road. Interesting work on business and IT projects. Good people - most of whom are trying to do the right thing!

headline: Senior VP - Financial Advisor
pros: The culture is the best of European and American business culture it seems.  I feel as though the company works for me and am very happy to work for us as a result (that wasn't a typo).  Management and support areas are lean, but still effective - it feels like a much smaller company in terms of the problem solving and empowered cogs that run an adroitly effective machine.
cons: Client user interface is outdated versus competitors, but not for long. The fixed income desk is not as skilled analytically as the group at Morgan Stanley where I was for nearly ten years prior.

headline: Challenges everywhere
pros: Global bank, broad product range, talented people, lots of opportunities and projects to work on.
cons: cost-cutting as a way of life, legacy systems, industry under threat, more offshoring and outsourcing will likely lead to fewer opportunities in Switzerland

headline: Researcher

cons: big company, location in Poland, seems a bit rigid, lots of procedures, artificial

headline: UBS Americas
pros: more laid back than other American banks
cons: less deal flow, exposure and prestige

headline: UBS London
pros: UBS provides a well-resourced and professional environment. There are opportunities to interact with a wide variety of colleagues from varied backgrounds and nationalities.
cons: I was unfortunate to be there at the time of the various upheavals and crisises during 2010 - 2012, and the financial services industry in general has become more perilous.

headline: Intern
pros: Amazing place to work, incredible culture and to profesionals
cons: Only senior positions for full time jobs. No junior programs development

headline: Executive Director
pros:
Good Brand infrastructure and management foresight
Most people know their job well
Excellent presentation DNA from IPS
Acceptable work life balance if you stand firm on your boundaries
Good community outreach like volunteering with special needs children or underprivileged households
cons:
Staff treated as dispensable cogs in management master plan which can shift and morph every year
Does not appear that Loyalty and hard work will be rewarded ; only the "chosen" ones are annointed and protected from cross border developments which will likely shrink offshore business
Many CAs are productive and perform despite negative headwinds of weak ineffectual DHs and CTHs who go missing everytime an important decision needs to be made 
Defacto decision making is to sit on something and let the situation take care of itself so no head needs to put their head on the line.
However, these CAs are not given opportunities to develop their book because their own bosses are not favoured by senior management 
Even new leads brought on have to be given up as the weak bosses do not want confrontation with the power bases like HNW South Asia, UHNW North Asia etc 
This weak middle management is evident across all divisions and if you discern hard enough there will be a few long serving D and ED who are the backbone of expertise and know how in their specific teams (IPS,WP, etc) headed by yet another clueless head parachuted in or up in the management role by virtue of their presentation skills, ability to lunch with the top or by being so good at showmanship they are promoted into incompetence. Not many are cut out to be managers. 
Being a manager requires sacrifice and a mindset to groom all your people equitably. Most managers leave the work to the backbone one downs and happily go on junket trips or creating their own pyramid schemes Competing with their own team members for limited leads, resources, support while cherry picking best of books for themselves when good bankers leave.
Low productivity and shallow skillset from long standing Swiss staff who serve as puppet custodian Bankers with no hold over the relationships but no one has dared to make decisive redistribution of these sacred cows choosing instead to flog the peripheral books and Asian bankers.
At some point, clients are bearing too much risk on behalf of clients who have learnt for many years that it is fine to keep millions of cash in custody with UBS and still get F1 paddock tickets and hotel bookings for the whole family.
No amount of "red carpet"will change this as wrong clients were onboarded and spoilt rotten for decades to a point of no return. 

General consensus among staff is that Singapore base is treated like a stepping stone for successive leaders to gain more visibility and power thus, plans are devised for short term goals to maximise the leader's showcase before they get promoted into regional and meatier glory.

headline: WM OTC Trade Specialist
pros: good structure, many learning opportunities

If you are young, don't expect them to take you seriously. It's not a good place for young people to grow. It's more like for experienced people.

New hires are put ahead of existing teams, and they are far from being any better.

headline: A Passive Aggressive Culture To Crush your soul or force you to quit
pros:
Lots of real and genuine teammates especially at the junior level
Some good managers
Decent health coverage for emergency purposes
Apparently compared to other banks, we are consider "better" in terms of culture
Use to be a good company and friendly culture... but the last 6 to 7 years have been brutal...
cons:
Terrible structural problems. Very Low Morale. High Turnovers. Long Hours. A "poppies that stick out get chopped" mentality. 

Senior managers are really cold and calculative. Company is highly political. All the good senior manager who actually care about people were all slowly forced to quit in my department in the last 3 years, as certain political camps won out (department and geographical merging to cut costs).

A massive trickle effect downwards to manager and junior managers is easily apparent. Most are cynical managers really abusing (passively I mean) their staff, rather then fight senior managers for work-life balance or even fair compensation. Mentors often advise (be less "cheery" and avoid being "noticed" and to be "fortunate" to have a job)

An unfortunate result are genuinely nice people are literally quietly begrudging walking dead. Angry, peeved off, but desperate to keep the jobs. Senior managers takes advantage of this....

Example: Recent promotions (with 1.5-2x the responsibility) are rewarded with pay raises less then 5%. This is not an exaggeration, with 5% at the upper range (with also a very low starting base to begin with). 

I and a few colleagues have declined the promotion. But, I suppose they served their purpose of "trying to promote".

All other staff have pay raise freeze for all others (some colleagues saw no raise for the past 4 years). Therefore real earning wages has actually declined year on year.

For my market that actually is a decline of 12-16% of real income after accounting for inflation. 

Previous years 2013-2015, a strategy of "natural attrition" was employed to reduce headcount by "freezing" almost all promotions (on top of pay). 

A good point to note, that strategy was effective in pushing some folks out. But us average individuals with limited prospects in a tightening market... it is very disheartening to see good friends leave and replaced by very young, very inept graduates (if they choose to replace staff at all)

headline: Excellent Company
pros: I loved all the people with whom I worked.  The benefits were fantastic.  The hours were manageable.
cons: Some of the work was boring.  Some of the policies were unjust.  Some of my coworkers were not happy with the company.

headline: Senior Registered Client Service Associate
pros: good benefits, vacation, holidays personal and sick days
cons: youth oriented  culture not good for mature workers

headline: A great company with challenge and diversity, work on the pay rises though!
pros: I enjoy working at UBS for its professionalism, its modern and progressive image, its contribution to charity work, the challenge that the job brings and the great team that I am a member of. I have enjoyed support from both managers and colleagues in my immediate and surrounding teams. I have also been impressed with the ValueFlex benefits scheme that the firm offers to all employees.
cons: UBS should think more about rewarding the small cogs in its machine (i.e. the lowest-level employees) who keep its day-to-day business running. Record profits and an enormous bonus pool unfortunately do not filter all the way down.

headline: Flexible Work Schedule with competitive pay

headline: Not really what I would have expected...
pros: Good location. Interesting job opportunities.
cons:
The company did not insure me, so I was not even declared to the CCSS.
This is embarrassing as you are not entitled to any social security insurance if your employer does not declare you....I had to check with HR and if I had not pushed them in order for them to double-check with the CCSS, nothing would have happened.. really unprofessional and unacceptable...
Other than that, very unfriendly and unprofessional people work in that company, I can only speak for Luxembourg as I very much presume that it is different in every location. A lot of co-workers who seem completely disconnected from reality in regards to the nowadays context of globalization. Too many people working there for too long, self-absorbed, very bad communicants. Making rules easy for themselves but difficult for others. I wanted to have a nice working experience in Central Europe, you can forget about it here. Luxembourg is said to be international and multicultural, but it is really not the case.. if you come from a different working background, you are clearly not appreciated for your skills and no efforts are made to help you to adapt to your new work environment.
In the end, very bad work experience.

headline: Great company, average employer
pros:
UBS is becoming increasingly profitable as it continue to sort out its problems from the past. They have also managed to finally stay out of trouble for a while, and performance-wise, the prospects of the firm are better than ever. 

UBS is still a bulge bracket firm with a good reputation on the Street, and you get to work with top notch individuals.
cons:
None of the improvements in financial performance have translated into additional benefits, pay raises, or better bonuses UBS seems to be perpetually in cost-cutting mode. Too many people are overworked and under-compensated.  There seems to be a general lack of appreciation for employees, which in the past would have been overlooked with good compensation.

Now, don't get me wrong. Pretty much all of the big investment banks are on the same boat. If anything UBS is probably one of the better ones out there. However, comparing it against companies in other industries outside of financial services, UBS becomes increasingly less attractive as an employer.

headline: Ageist
pros: Brand recognition, great compensation and benefits, friendly and professional peers, global exposure.
cons: Top heavy organization, Focus is solely on cost cutting and offshoring. Seemingly endless redundancies.  Older workers are being singled out for dismissal and replaced with cheaper, junior externals with little to no experience. This is how the management rewards hard work and loyalty.  Extremely bureaucratic and political, with managers playing favourites, and promotions and opportunities given to people who didn't deserve them, while those who demonstrated grit and productivity were passed over. Everybody is only looking after themselves and protecting their own interests. Workers are continuously being asked to do more with less and forced to settle for working with systems and processes that are dysfunctional and create more unnecessary work.

headline: Great place to work
pros: UBS has flexible bosses and clear roles, procedures,  and policies that apply across board. There is also a lot of room for career growth.
cons: Being a financial institution there are numerous regulations that must always be kept in mind. Also being truly global. It harder to connect to all your possible coworkers.

headline: Still work to do...

headline: Summer Analyst

headline: Hard work but a great place to work

headline: Decent colleagues and friendly environment....but getting too bureaucratic

cons: Bureaucratic, very political.  Too much focus on just cost cutting and offshoring.  Too little about rebuilding a better foundation for long term cost benefits

Benefits went up

headline: Decent bank to work at

headline: Great culture

headline: Meh

headline: Intern

- No support for external training

headline: Great Place to work at

cons: they rarely give raises or reward good work. - Performance reviews are sometimes "fixed"

headline: Middle Office Analyst
pros: Coming straight out of college, this is a good paying job. Also, this was a free ticket to get to New York City
cons:
The Middle Office is where ambition goes to die. If you're looking for a job where you fix other people's mistakes all day long, run the same reports every single day, at the same time, are surrounded by people that hate management and frequently and loudly speak ill of the company, then this is the place for you. 

If you're interested in working with and learning from motivated, happy individuals, steer clear of the Middle Office completely and UBS ESPECIALLY. 

In the year that I was there, 12 people voluntarily left my team, 10 of which left the company. Turnover here is about 75-80%

headline: Trading Operations Intern

headline: Very rewarding and appealing job. Very satisfied.

headline: Good place to work
pros: Colleagues, location, hours, technology, support
cons: Bureaucracy, politics, incompetence, favoritism, sexism

headline: Balance
pros:
Employees with no rank new to the firm get 20 vacation days, 16 weeks maternity leave and two weeks paternal leave!
The higher your rank, the longer you've been with the company, the higher your vacation. 

Access to employee discounts, legal advice, therapy and counseling, mortgage rates, financial advising for employees, all free. 

A new extensive system has been put in to create a centralized form of year end evaluations so that you can accurately be tracked on your goals and performances throughout the year so you can get promotions/raises
cons:
UBS has an entire team created for issuing redundancies (layoffs). Your job is not safe unless you're making the firm money.

There is so much red tape. In the US, the general population of UBS cannot get in contact with many internal teams.
You won't talk to someone in internal benefits or internal payroll because they literally can't, their teams have been downsized so much that they can't accept your calls. It causes some serious backups when things go wrong because Hewitt and ADP can only do so much.

A lot of times promotions aren't handed out, you have to apply for an internal job with other candidates to be considered.

headline: Director
pros: Big small company, senior management very active, easy to get business done
cons: Compensation is the absolute worst!! every year bonus is down to flat no matter how well the company does.  Tenured employees get ignored

headline: Review
pros: Great working environment, offices based in central london. Small company where every one is listened to in a group of intelligent traders
cons: A small company and so not a lot in the way of socializing, and so you need to make sure you get on with every one in the office.

headline: good

headline: Interview

cons: boss was an absolute nightmare, which is the sole reason i left the company

headline: Has much room for improvement
pros: Diverse and interesting group of colleagues.
cons: Many of those at the senior level did not know how to foster a positive and congenial working environment; not as many opportunities to learn as there should be; as a global company could benefit from more collaboration across countries on company-wide policies (oftentimes policies seem disjointed).

headline: Director
pros: Not very many pros as this company abuses its workers. Terrible environment. Especially in Operations.
cons: One of the saddest work environments Ive seen in my 20+ years in Financial Services.

headline: Stay far away!!
pros:
Good pay, good benefits, very good location.
Nice buildings with good ergonomics.
cons: Very unprofessional and decadent work environment full of arrogant and backstabbing people. You cannot learn anything as nobody cares about you.. You are just a number, a lemon to be squeezed. This place is full of bootlickers, lazy and rude people. A lot of "dinosaurs" meaning employees who are working in that company for over 30 years (!!!??), and although these people have no clue about the current challenges occurring at most of other workplaces due to the globalisation, they make more harm to their colleagues, to the company and to themselves than they think. Of course, if your only concern is how to be properly dressed at a company Christmas party than the actual work and the risk to lose your job (by being eventually replaced by Indians contractors in the next few years?), then it is not surprising that the wake up call will be extremely painful in a few years when these people will be replaced by cheaper labour somewhere else! No training given, no team work. You cannot ask a question to your colleagues without being rudely pushed back to your desk . No communication. The manager does not make any performance reviews in order to properly judge your actual work. You are only judged as a worker based on what your colleagues think of you as a person and not as a professional! This is embarrassing and unacceptable. You could die in a corner and nobody would notice. Plus it is already too late that you don't get any proper feedback on how to improve your own skills and how to encourage positive communication in the team...One of the worst places I have ever seen in my career. I worked in many countries in Europe and this place is a disgrace..

headline: Wealth Management Intern
pros: Learned a lot while working here
cons: Did not seem like there was room to grow within the company

headline: Human Resource
pros: Great culture, the people are so friendly and willing to help all the time. I have build a lot of great contacts and great relationships with the people I work with as well as in other departments.
cons: There are not that many cons. The only thing is that I wish there was more transparency.

headline: Decent but other options are out there

headline: Corporate Managment is a Challenge in WMA
pros: There are some nice, talented people to work with in technology in UBS Wealth Management Americas. Financial Advisers and their staffs are very professional, interesting and successful.
cons: Horrible communication in technology. Treated employees horribly from a corporate / management communication standpoint. Everything in technology is underfunded and behind the curve for competing with other companies in this category. As with many large companies, management changes periodically (6 months, 1 year, 18 months, no longer than 2 years) so long term strategy and maintaining consistent resources is close to impossible. Contracted large technology firms is strategic at the management level but disastrous at the implementation level, especially technology development resources. Plans have been to move technology out of the NYC area to other locations for cost savings. Salaries are undercut at every opportunity.

headline: Financial Advisor

cons: I cannot think of any.

headline: depends on your group

cons: Junior guys are underpaid while some mid and most senior levels overpaid for what they contribute.  Very volatile environment with high emp turnover.

headline: Ops UBS GAM
pros: More than decent salary package. Competitive base pay with ample opportunities for overtime.
cons:
UBS now requires all US employees to move ALL household investment accounts, including retirement, to UBS. So financially speaking you are required to do business at the company store as a cost for working there, and honestly, I received better employee discounts when I worked retail in college.

The overall environment between the back and front offices is both contentious and dysfunctional. Management on both sides have implemented policies and procedures that only add to the combativeness between the two sides, and neither wants to meet the other in the middle to create a cohesive work environment. Oh, and watch out for a certain EMD PM, the guy has total disdain for anyone associated with ops.

headline: Great

cons: Organizations works very much in silos. Difficult to get access/exposure to different areas of the business. Often I found that overqualified people have modest responsibilities, while the highest ranks of the investment banks in Switzerland are filled by people with no university degrees. IT infrastructure not well maintained and documented as the bank expanded with several mergers over the years.

headline: good

headline: UBS Sales and Trading
pros: People are generally nicer than trading floor within other banks. They have a lot of events and classes for interns also, which was nice.
cons:
HR employees were not as nice as I hoped them to be. At other banks, interns have the chance to interview for other positions within the company. At UBS, that wasn't even an option. 

Also, heard a lot of complaint about the firm from current full-time employees. Usually about how people there didn't care about improving and being better traders/sales people -- in short, the employee in this case, didn't feel like he was growing at the firm.

headline: UX Designer
pros: Normal hours, larger than average pay, and for the most part, very pleasant co-workers.
cons:
If you are a UX Designer, do not take a job here. 

The only 'user' UBS management really cares about is UBS upper management. Every project is waterfall method (they call it "4D" - don't be fooled). Agile? Lean? What are those? Your superiors would not know a good design method if it slapped them in the face. 

They launch interactive projects and are confused when they don't succeed. Maybe because they are being driven by analysts who want to show they are experts in their field, with a complete disregard for if any users would be interested in what they're pushing? There is a lot of 1980s machismo going on here. 

Even basic things, like requirements gathering, are a nightmare. No one knew what they were doing until the cult-leader-in-charge would give his stamp of approval. 

Communication is also horrible. There's a lot of internal wrangling with one on one competing discussions. You will never get all the stakeholders in the same room at the same time to hash it out. Even if you did, 'you're just the UX designer' - your voice would 100% not be heard. You're like an exotic animal at a zoo surrounded by ivy league suits.

I looked back through my notes after leaving and realized that on literally every project I worked on, there was a clueless middle manager who pushed aside best practice designs I worked on in favor of his ideas, which stakeholders always hated. We would waste 3 times the time and effort working this way. This guy would also parrot any expert level advice I told him one on one and present it as his own to his superiors. I'm quite sure that's how he stays employed there: stealing others work, and creating bad ideas that he can then blame on others. And no, you'll never be in any meeting or situation where you can defend yourself. 

Remember - everything here is top down, and you're 'just the UX designer'.  Your skills, experience and training are worth nothing here. They would call you a "wireframe monkey" if they actually knew enough about design to know what that means.

cons: Cannot participate to Client meeting (due to the confidentiality of UHNW)

cons:

headline: Not up to the brand name
pros:
Good brand name and clear strategy at the top. 
Relatively stable and proud organisation offering comprehensive wealth management solutions to clients.
cons:
Bureaucratic organisation with an overly complex matrix, heavily centralised in HQ despite its global size and ambitions. 
Accountability of management is low and the decision making process convoluted, overlapping and inefficient. As a result the bank is slow to change, apart from its speech. 
More focused on processes and form than on solution and substance.

headline: Great Graduate Trainee Program

I joined UBS as a Graduate Trainee over a year ago. The program places a huge emphasis on training and development. It is a great springboard for a career in banking.
The management is exceptional - they are very supportive of GTPs and provide us with great exposure & challenging opportunities.
cons:
Promotion & pay increment is rather stagnant. 
Banking is not as prestigious as it used to be.

headline: Was decent until investment bank hit by sub-prime losses, rogue trading scandal and HUGE regulatory fines
pros: Mobility is very possible if you're coming from one of the higher performing offices because Europe and US have been bleeding good people
cons: Investment banking considered non-core to wealth management. Firm has been demoralized by rogue trader and regulatory fines - there's no "glory" or sense of pride in working here, especially if you're in the APAC or Australasia businesses. Don't bother with UBS if you're an IB true-ist. There are places with more exceptional MDs that pay better and have far more prestigious exit opportunities. At the associate and analyst level, you also get a strong sense that a lot of people above you are just there because they couldn't get out of UBS. Anyone good with exit options have pretty much left as soon as they could

headline: People make it.

headline: Great people, wrong timing
pros: If you are going to work in an international investment bank, UBS has one of the better work life balances.  Yes, you will work 10 hour + days but on the whole most people were getting home to see their families each night.  In addition, the team of people actually cared about each other and were willing to work for the greater good.
cons: Too many scandals in the past several years- rogue trader, LIBOR, FX to name a few. The actions of a few small groups and individuals across the globe had significant impact on individual compensation.  Bonuses were impacted multiple years in a row with much being deferred over 5 years.

headline: Great hourly rate for contractors
pros: UBS is one of those companies that will probably always be around. I worked for them as a Regular employee (what many call "permanent," although we all know that's a misnomer) from 2005 to 2008, and they were always very good to their employees.  Great benefits, generous vacation time, good pay--even an onsite company fitness center with yoga classes at the low cost of $40/month which was automatically deducted from your paycheck.  I returned to UBS as a contractor from Jan. through May 2011, and left for a regular role elsewhere. I would have liked to have stayed at UBS if they'd been able to place me at the time.
cons: Sometimes management can make poor decisions, as in the case of hiring the former Chief Communications Officer who was in place from late 2010 through May 2011. This person was so scattered that the Global Head of Communications got on a plane from Zurich personally just to fire her.  Unfortunately, during her short tenure, the firm lost a lot of invaluable institutional knowledge when a number of key communications people walked out the door due to her inability to lead.  But since that problem is now in the past, no cons!!

headline: Client Service Associate
pros: Coworkers, work life balance, benefits, flexibility
cons: Mobility and salary increases are severely lacking.

headline: Bureaucracy
pros: Some flexibility and work-life balance
cons: Very very bureaucratic. No room for growth, below market pay and no raises in years.

headline: Good company, very swiss
pros: friendly environment and good work life balance and good technology
cons: lots of swiss in top management, no can-do attitude, very bureaucratic

headline: Review
pros: Great place to work. Nice people.
cons: None. Great place to work. Nice people.

headline: Decent company
pros: brand name, decent benefits, decent work life balance
cons: mobility within organization, bureaucratic hurdles, frequent layoff cycles in non business areas, location of back offices is really bad - in residential areas where commuting is difficult or away from financial centers.

headline: Associate
pros: Everything at the company is great
cons: Nothing at the company is bad

headline: IT Project Manager
pros: quality of people, complexity of IT projects, international exposure, dynamic industry, competitive salaries, comfortable offices
cons: life - work balance, career progress opportunities are limited at my location, periodic reputational scandals, mistakes in investment strategy

headline: Great coworkers - atmosphere, not so much.
pros: Coworkers were some of the greatest people I've ever found. I am still very close friends with many people I worked with, although none work for UBS anymore due to downsizing and turnover.
cons: Cutting costs/headcount, relocation of middle/back office functions to the south, very low morale, little to no bonuses. Very disheartening to work for UBS at this time.

headline: finance
pros: global resources, networks, resources available
cons: not positive for women, culture going downhill

headline: intern
pros:
Good resume builder and the culture is good at the office
good experience
cons: I don't think there were any. it was good

headline: Client Service Associate
pros: Great work environment. Provided operational and administrative support to financial advisors. A very rewarding career helping clients achieve their long term financial goals
cons: Compliance issues can cause annoyances. Onboarding a new employee isn't any expeditious process. Other than that, It is a positive experince

headline: International opportunities, professional education
pros: international opportunities, professional education, cultural diversity
cons: can lag behind the market with compensation

headline: Pretty much what you'd expect from a large bank
pros: UBS is definitely known for it's people. There are a lot of great people working here and the firm has a culture that is very open to networking. Employees are encouraged to reach out to one another and collaborate. UBS also has a tremendous array of resources that employees are encouraged to capitalize on.
cons: The culture is very stiff and hierarchical to the point of inefficiency. A lot of the computer systems I needed for my role were incredible disorganized, which made nearly every task more time-consuming than it needed to be. Unless you're in the IB I would not recommend UBS as a place for young talent. A lot of back office jobs are being outsourced and hiring in sales & trading is very limited. Only the IB and wealth management really seem to be valued. UBS also seems to have a really frustrating tendency to ignore problem areas or aspects of the company that employees complain about.

headline: Lack of direction
pros: Company offers a lot of opportunities.
cons: Too many roles are alive due to the old boys club. There could be a lot of process improvements made if they got rid of these roles.

headline: A company going through some changes.
pros: Great benefits, really like the people I work with some really wonderful, smart people. I've been given some great challenges and have been given the chance to excel.
cons: Space an issue, many jobs being moved to Weehawken or Nashville.  Current re-org going on realigns people to new bosses they may never have met before.  I don't want my bonus determined by someone I don't know and doesn't know my work.

headline: Director
pros: Swiss company with work life balance.
cons: Its now in cost cutting mode. Jobs are moved to low cost locations hence if you are based in NYC or London there is not much room to grow. Also, the job reduction is done through natural attrition hence sal bump is not compared to market.

headline: Good job after undergrad but not sustainable
pros:
Good learning initially
Chance to work with few very smart people
cons:
Very bad working hours
Learning plateaus after a short time and you are mostly working on pitch books and internal memos with almost no learning
Few very unreasonable requests and people

headline: Work atmosphere
pros: Nice place to work, Excellent
cons: International organisation with different departments

headline: IB
pros: Great company to work in.
cons: A lot of staffing to juniors

headline: Great company and benefits
pros: Excellent culture, top notch facilities and an engaging management staff make UBS a first choice employer in Nashville.
cons: Long hours, pay is average, resources for career development need further development at this center

headline: Sinking Ship
pros: Good training program led by outside firm, Training the Street. Taught us how to build valuation models with advanced accounting methodolgy.
cons: Run like a slave-ship (and sinking at that). Overworked, with few pitches actually leading to deals. Bank was hemorrhaging executive talent, taking their business and contacts with them. No one respected management, making the long hours even more unjustifiable.

headline: Sales
pros: Large organization that allows you to move around as you look to  make career changes
cons: Company has been unstable, bonuses tied to overall bank performance is frustration if you perform well at the individual level.

headline: Great company
pros: Great management, great benefits and an AMAZING work place.
cons: Not enough diversity in upper management.

headline: Very stimulating experience. A lot of emphasis on personality and work rate.
pros: Nice environment. Seems a lot more collaborative than other banks and less cut throat.
cons: In the long run your earning potential is less than other similar firms.

headline: Fantastic place to work in
pros: Amazing talent, very inclusive and pro active bunch of people. Best in class which makes work very enjoyable
cons: Organisation matrix can be quite complex and were undergoing changes. Can do more for staff in terms of benefits

headline: Registered CSA
pros: Big company whose name still carries a lot of weight depending on the client and business sector. Huge global presence.
cons: Red tape and mismanagement. There is a large culture of complacency and cover your you know what. Hard for people who take initiative and are accountable to get things done.

headline: Good place to start
pros: Good benefits, opportunities for upward mobility and a great cafeteria. Not to mention a good place to start.
cons: Since it's such a big company, exposure can be difficult to come by.

headline: Ok
pros: The pay is good compared to the industry but it does get extremely boring. If you just want money for mindless work then this is what you are looking for.
cons: You are undervalued as a person and the work is remedial

headline: Excellent corporate culture with genuinely helpful colleagues to work with
pros: Excellent people to work with -- most people are professional and talented yet genuinely helpful and caring. Great teamwork mindset and it is rare to come across with people who are arrogant.
cons:
Decision making could take long ...
Due to the size and complexity of the company structure, occasional communication breakdown does occur ...

headline: Good experience
pros: Global bank with foot print everywhere in the world
cons: Not as good as in the past with management structural/cultural changes

headline: Good
pros:
Flexible hours

good team

good exposure and good opportunities

headline: Poor Culture Leads to Boiler Room Type Environment

cons: Long hours, poor pay, and micromanagement.

headline: Intern

headline: Ok

headline: UBS as an employee
pros:
I'm glad to work with UBS. UBS is  a great place to work. 

I value UBS for: work-life balance; office culture; staff education, friendly and helpful work environment.
cons: I think that the compensation should be higher, The firm does very well does but it  not reflect the salary levels.

headline: Good environment
pros: Good environment to grow. Management are very welcoming with regards to feedback.
cons: Takes about a year to convert from contact to permanent roles.

headline: Past experience working at UBS Financial Services, Inc.
pros: UBS is a globally recognized wealth management brand. This helps open doors, specially those of prospective clients. Great menu of top-tier products and services available to affluent and HNW clients.
cons: Trying to conduct an offshore (NRA) wealth management practice from a US-based branch is nearly impossible. There is little experience at the domestic-branch level for this type of business, and little interest to learn/promote it.

headline: Intern BUC
pros: Quality people around, good salary for an intern
cons: Noone have time and will to train you

headline: Analyst
pros: Internal mobility, well paid, continued learning

headline: Financial analyst
pros: Great environement, with great people. Loved the city life, however I wanted to do something for myelf
cons: The issue was the systems were soooo old that it made it impossible to do anything and the in house software was sooo bad also.

headline: Director
pros: individual roles and people generally are good to work with.

headline: High pressure in cost cutting times

flexibility to work from home
vacation allowance

-poor on boarding
-lack of family feel

-cross functional combined with size, constant re-orgs or downsizing makes it nearly impossible to get decisions made

headline: Director
pros: Might be good for people to gain experience

headline: UBS Wealth Management
pros:
- One of the World biggest Wealth Managers

- Compensation around standard for the industry

headline: UBS

headline: Was a great place to work

cons: Low pay, too much bureaucracy, too many politics, lack of leadership, poor communication, front runner in many regulatory initiatives, wrong power shift between front and back office

headline: Awesome
pros: Great Culture, Beautiful location and amazing colleagues

headline: UBS is just ok
pros:
I work in a great wealth management group, I'm the only girl in a group of 3 other guys and it a great atmosphere.
Outside of my group there is a good mix of men and women and they are all very friendly.
cons:
There is a lot of downtime if you are not licensed. Most of the work requires a license and they are hard tests. 
I found it difficult to meet other people in the company because they have you working in your group, takes a while to get to know everyone

headline: ok
pros: Salary is pretty good comparing to other industries, team is nice and there are opportunities to grow.
cons: Don't expect to have a lot of free time. you are lot of fr

headline: Great places for consultants
pros: Organised with a great team spirit
cons: Worldwide sometime makes it difficult to get things done, being that you need approval from an unknown manager based somewhere else.

headline: Good Company - Average Technology
pros: Good company. Really provide in-depth market and industry research. Great financial planning tools.
cons: Benefits are below average. Technology is also below average (aka computer software and client tools). And seems like they're always trying to cut costs.

headline: Restricted analist

Bureaucracy is inevitable in such a large institution
The offices in the center of town are older and don't boast facilities like the newer offices (who have showers, gyms, meditation spaces, relaxed sitting areas...)

headline: Equities
pros: cant think of anything. Demoralizing place to work.
cons: very poor culture. Negative environment. Horrible place to work

headline: Executive Director, Legal Department
pros: cutting-edge customer trading front-end technology, great colleagues, when they have not been replaced by long-time UBS employees; global reach, opportunities plentiful, great reputation, international issues.
cons: Working in the investment bank from 2007 through 2011, I was there as UBS tried to pare down its workforce.  Employment decisions were made purely based on cronyism, rather than merit.  Management in Legal was unsupportive.  Also, many vital legal functions were off-shored, leading to many mistakes and jeopardizing legal department effectiveness.

headline: overall not impressed, could have been better. With some good aspects
pros: Diverse job opportunities, competitive salaries, due to its size one can find technically very strong people in the company, educational/training offer (back then)
cons: As with several huge companies: administrative overhead, too many unintelligent people, management lacks skill set of managers and lacks technical knowledge

headline: Banking intern
pros:
Good work atmosphere,
Possibility to learn a lot in finance
cons: Big companies often face random management decisions from top down.

headline: good company

cons: hire more generally managers in office

headline: Wealth Manager

cons: Really hard to start from ground up, Don't start new advisors with a book of business

headline: Financial Advisor
pros: If have the write Advisors to mentor you the experience can be invaluable
cons: If you have the wrong mentor... good luck

headline: Great place to work
pros: Great people, not a lot of ego-centric personalities
cons: Very politically when it comes to upward mobility

-decent hours
-good food

-stringent, conservative, need to be a perfectionist and watching yourself at all times
-overhead from managerial flow, bureaucratic

headline: Back office Analyst Review

cons: The only people who constantly get bonuses and promotions are the front office.

headline: Associate Director
pros:
Collegiate atmosphere, 
Challenging environment, 
High calibre senior bankers, 
Increasing focus on junior banker development
Ambitious management vision

Work-life balance
Changing industry regulatory environment
Cyclical industry
High staff churn rate
Ability to compete with US banks in some product areas

Good social plan
Nice and friendly people
Ability to take your overtime in free time, flexible working hours
cons:
Unfair and not transparent bonus system 
Big differences between various departments in salaries, promotion requirements, bonuses etc

headline: Not so nice
pros: salary, environment, city, fringe benefits
cons: hierarchy, brand, values, working hours

headline: Project Manager
pros:
Some nice people
Firm Image and mission
cons:
Unprofessional management 
Cleanliness of office

headline: Intern
pros: Calm environment, helpful training and staff
cons: Tough market to break into

headline: Disorganized management and low employee morale
pros: Global bank, transferred me from one office to another without a problem.
cons: Poor compensation and low morale, constantly changing management. Senior people coming in with high guarantees bonuses, producing nothing and then leaving

headline: Blah
pros: Expanding presence in Nashville, good industry knowledge sessions
cons: Communication at times poor, fragmented office

headline: Internship
pros: The experience working over seas is a great one, I learned so many things coming from communication to finance last year.
cons: I learned so much it is hard to come up with a bad side however the working hours for any internship to me were too long and were too inconsistent throughout the interns.

headline: Good place to work
pros: Smart people that work hard.
cons: Difficult to move past Associate Director

headline: Analyst
pros: Great brand name with a solid European presence.  They pay well and are well-respected inside and outside of finance.
cons: They are a step below the best bank (MS, JPM, GS) and the morale sometimes reflects this.  Pay is also below the top shops.

headline: Associate
pros: Pretty standard investment banking, decent pay relative to other types of jobs, learn a decent amount, ability to attend meetings and work directly with senior people.
cons: Bad culture, high turnover, much lower deal flow than ten years ago, not a lender so makes it very difficult to get business, most efforts spent on pitching.

headline: Finding footing
pros: If you come in as an outsider you will recieve comparable market rate base pay.
cons: The firm is still trying to find is footing after financial crisis and a few missteps of its own ex Facebook ipo. Morale is down with divisions losing head counts,  off and on shoring jobs.

headline: Financial analyst
pros: Good classes to learn from
cons: Mgmt can sometimes be vague

headline: Depending on the division
pros:
Annual leave is good. People are nice in general. 
I was really lucky to be able to spend a great amount of time with the Trust and Fiduciary team (under Wealth Management). They are a nice bunch to work with.
cons: Slow promotion. Hard to make changes.

headline: Senior Management continuously useless
pros: Worked at UBS for 7 years and can say that Analysts have a good team spirit and the teams are full of dedicated and hard working people.
cons:
Still way too many Senior Manager who have so poor human skills that we keep on losing young talented people and keep the overly expensive guys with no real drive since their base is large and bonuses small.
Senior Management unable to receive feedbacks.
Pay below the street.
Have not understood yet that they don't pay street level so won't attract real talents.
Have not understood yet that IB does not pay more than other industry and should therefore get more in line with quality of life of other industries paying the same.

headline: executive assistant
pros: always have job opportunities within the company
cons: extended working hours and pretty high staff turnover

headline: Great Experience
pros: Excellent salary and multicultural environment
cons: Haven't learnt much from the team

headline: Good place for people who want to work hard and be recognized
pros: I worked for 16 years for UBS and can honestly say that I was never discriminated against for being a woman.  There were many times when I was the only woman in the room but I wasn't overlooked or disregarded.  I had many different bosses and, yes, some were better than others.  In general, though I thought that my contributions were recognized and that I had a chance to discuss any disagreements.  There were times when I had to go along with a decision I didn't agree with but I was listened to and I understood that another area, project or department had to take priority in that moment.
cons: The company is big, huge and has a process for everything.  Plus the processes change frequently.  There is a lot of outsourcing - even your HR rep might be from a 3rd party.  You need patience and allies to negotiate the system.

headline: Data and document specialist
pros: Friendly people. Very good work life balance.
cons: Package is not good, no pay rise.

headline: UBS IB Money Market Back office
pros: Good top grasp first air to investment banking. Many fringe benefits and very well payed.
cons: The work was standard and very monotonous. No ambitous work atmosphere. No big learning scale.

headline: Investment Banker
pros: Lean industry teams provide a phenomenal experience for junior bankers. There is also a wave of talent that has been brought in the past 2 years that should provide the much needed deal experience that is required to build a career in IBD.
cons: The recent hiring spree (~20% YoY growth) at the senior level is pause for concern though. It feels reminiscent to the hiring spree in the early/mid 2000's. There will be culture clashes as groups grow under new leadership.

headline: You need to work hard and may not always be rewarded with a promotion
pros: Salaries are very competitive and the benefits are great!
cons: Promotions beyond Associate Director are almost impossible if you work in Operations and are not already managing a team.

headline: Analyst
pros: I really enjoy working at UBS.  The company has a strong culture, stimulating work, thoughtful leadership and is a place where an analyst can get real deal experience.
cons: While there really aren't many negative attributes I could list, one thing I'd highlight is the variable and sometimes long work hours.

headline: Hollowing out a firm in decline
pros: One of the top paying companies in Switzerland for employment.  Title heavy in appearance.  Director level has annual guaranteed minimum expense payment.
cons:
Company is involved in the long term process of slowly hollowing itself out.
Investment Bank division in highly outsourced with cheap foreign contract staff. On-shored contractors are brought in on a temporary basis, rotated out frequently. Technical roles are typically off-shored (Poland, Singapore) to contract workers. Higher compensated permanent staff are targeted, laid off to facilitate the off-shoring.  Technical staff for IB and WM divisions are parked in Corporate Centre division. From my observation, the CC division is structured to run at a loss; this strategy minimizes staff salary increases and bonus payments, as attached to division profitability.
For all appearances, the Swiss government looks the other way, facilitating this Bad Actor company.

headline: Summer Internship
pros: Great no face-time culture; much better hours than most of wall street; very optimistic and friendly culture
cons: At a junior level, there's really no cons besides the typical corporate hierarchy.

headline: Hello
pros: Friendly dedicated hard working staff
cons: No cons to mention about this company

headline: Don't work in compliance...
pros: Nice people to work with. Intelligible people. Caring people. Great place to learn, get trained, and gain experience. Great for entry level (then leave).
cons: The company itself is appears awful due to the fact all decisions have to be run through Switzerland. Super cheap especially when it comes to their compliance department. They don't make counter offers...not even to their top employees. Been her four years and the CEO has had two raises (20% and 4%) while my salary has stayed the same and my work had nearly tripled. Literally only promotion per compliance team is permitted. No growth here. Compliance is not where you want to apply, not unless you take more work and pats on the back as bonus currency. Let alone many of the jobs are transitioning Nashville. Seriously they will hire less experienced people with higher titles just to bring their pay to a competitive market salary and leave the current employees dry and disappointed. And remember what I said about promotions. Essentially there is no reason to be a rock star employee here.

headline: Great company
pros: very helpful, access to upper level management
cons: intern at a small office, not as much access as working at home office

headline: Good place to start off
pros: Learning opportunities, culture, exposure to very senior people from very first day, work-life balance
cons: Salary, lack of career progression

headline: Analyst
pros:
Interesting deals
Good compensation in line with industry
cons:
Pretty bad working culture
Not the best reputation on Wall Street

headline: Financial Advisor
pros: Good benefits, good bonus. Everything is pendent upon what division you're in
cons: glass ceiling, difficult to move amongst divisions, lack of capacity

headline: Quantitative analyst in Risk
pros: Flexible hours, nice working envrionment
cons: Long term career perspective, Low Bonus

headline: Associate Director - IT Business Analyst
pros: The people supporting the business have worked very hard and have endured through a lot of industry change over over the past 7-8 years.
cons: Career opportunities are stifled and promotions are few

headline: PWM intern
pros: great experience would definitely recommend
cons: corporate structure was very strict

headline: Group Technology
pros:
Good Learning Environment
Surrounded by Talented People
cons:
Long hour work
People are quite distant

headline: UBS - It's alright.
pros: Lots of different teams so plenty of opportunity to move around. Some really smart people, who you can learn a lot from if you put in the effort to mine the information from them.
cons: You have to know people in order to get anywhere - smoozing is part and parcel of progression. It is definitely still a boys club - interviews are usually only a formality as roles are often already promised to someone before it has even been advertised. Lots of fundamental issues with processes but people don't want to hear anything about it until something goes wrong. A lot of senior managers have never actually been given management training and have no idea how to develop their teams. It's cringeworthy.

headline: Wealth Management Intern
pros: My coworkers are very friendly and helpful, and you get to meet a lot of well-connected people in your area.
cons: The position is not particularly demanding nor is it that rewarding.  It's difficult for interns to do the roles of a financial analyst or help clients since we, as college students, probably don't have certifications and/or licenses.  A lot of the work I do is really monotonous, and I find that I have several hours at work where I don't have anything to do.

headline: Authorized Officer
pros: Very Classy company with great values.
cons: Compensation is little less for the responsibilities

headline: Excellent Financial Services Company
pros: Very flexible working hours with good career development chances.
cons: Not always very international team environment.

headline: Apprentice
pros: -direct contact to clients from day one
cons: -they cut back quiet a lot in recent years

headline: Vice President
pros: This is a fantastic location and a great employer with lots of benefits and good corporate culture. The management is well organised and complainant with the strict rules.
cons: Sometimes the structure looks too big and too cumbersome. There is a certain number of duplication of functions and positions which are not really necessary given the coverage of the bank.

headline: Amazing Firm
pros: A great place to work with great opportunity
cons: It's a hard job. They're the best because they demand hard work.

headline: Good company
pros: Company culture is very good
cons: work is a bit slow

headline: Unclear strategy
pros: It may be a correct place to go if you are ranked number one at other top  5 houses. Then you can establish yourself and stay for a while.
cons: It is difficult to build a career and name inside. Difficult to understand the strategy when there is not a clear one or is permanently under review.

headline: Marketing
pros: Plenty of career and travel opportunities
cons: Slow moving company, plenty of politics

headline: Account Management, Service Management, Program Management
pros: responsibility, managing large programs, requirements management, leadership, people management. good career options, networking.
cons: admin overhead, more empowerment would be nice, high pressure, long working hours

headline: Solid company with the usual politics
pros: Job stability, as long as you're on the bread winning sales/service side. Competitive benefits package with decent vacation and sick days, several health plans to chose from. Vision and dental plans are good also, plus optional life, accidental death and long term disability insurance. Predictable 9-5 hours with no weekend work.
cons: You deal with lots of politics, like any large corporation. The guys at the top make the big bucks while we get poor bonuses and zero salary increases year after year. The company doesn't reward people who get the job done, rather you have to know who to kiss up to. Finally, they take a socialist approach to salary increases bringing the rookie salaries up to the level of senior employess, so that everyone's at the same level. A lot of BS but it would be the same or worse at another financial firm.

headline: No good
pros: Work life balance . Good insurance coverage (but getting worse)
cons: No pay increase .. Low bonus . Outdated performance rating systems . No professional training (u have tons of mandatory compliance trainings though)

headline: Credit Risk
pros: To big to fail to big to gail
cons: To big to get exposure to the management unless you are in ZH

headline: Project Manager
pros: Big Company, good salary, good Insurance
cons: If you like to work with the half of the Indian sub-continent - feel free to join.

headline: Great Place To Be
pros: High Ethics, Team Environment, Good Management
cons: Difficultly moving between branch locations

headline: Too Many Cost-Cutting Initiatives
pros: Really nice people and experienced colleagues.
cons: The single business success factor is to cut costs - compensation is not competitive, all employees are being replaced with consultants or their jobs are being relocated to Nashville, India or Poland. No talent retention.

headline: Better for an Internal not so good for an External
pros:
People treated generally with no respect to whether External or Internal
Variety of projects
Generally respectful and polite
Good skills learnt
Challenging
cons:
The question asked at the Resturant checkout "Extern?" and you nod yes only to find that your bill has just doubled or tripled :-)
Pretty much all of IT has been outsourced
All Outsourcing Consultancies are heavily reducing the maximum salary paid, therefore Switzerland ain't the lucrative option it used to be.
The "Workplace of the Future" is a pain in the rear.

headline: Compliance, Operations, Risk - worst experience ever
pros: Putting the UBS name on resume - that's about the only good thing I took away from the experience, which was a downright awful period of time in my professional life
cons:
-Ultra boring work
-Ridiculous corporate bureaucracy
-Culture of passing the buck, playing hot potato with work and projects
-Hyper-politicized atmosphere, where your main job -- regardless of function/department/location -- is to protect your own butt and defend your turf so you stay employed
-Obscenely understaffed, so your workload is double/triple what it really should be

headline: Poor pay
pros: Global Nature of the company
cons: Hard to progress. Poor pay.

headline: Lacking
pros:
Supportive of employee's personal requirements on family, location, etc. Very flexible when needed. That is the best reason to work here.
Name value - but that is shrinking overtime I have noticed, Clearly a 3rd tier bank at this point.
cons:
Senior mgmt not truthful about plans and not really in charge of the firm.

headline: Friend environment but too much cost cutting pressure

headline: UBS

headline: Director

cons: Senior management were some of the most vile people I have ever known and I've been in the industry for more than 25 years, working in London, NY and Stamford for this company. Their greed, especially around comp time, was obnoxious. I also have nothing good to say about the HR organization -- each and every one of them was a waste of space.

headline: couldn

headline: Good work environment; Terrible comp
pros: Work environment is quite good. UBS has invested in systems infrastructure over the last 2 years and that is starting to come good. Good learning opportunities. Managers open to training requests. Relatively flat organisation structure.
cons: Stingy when it comes to pay and benefits. Loyalty and hard work not rewarded. Management doesn't care when good talent walks out the door. Would rather spend far more hiring + training new candidates than try and retain existing staff.

headline: Good culture

headline: Fund accountant

headline: Positive

headline: Good place

cons: Overall backoffice and IT is rather weak. Alot of the work could hence be handeled more efficiently tomato tomato tomato

headline: UBS
pros: Great place to learn the business

headline: Director

Respectable brand, exit opportunity is nice

headline: wealth management intern

headline: Wealth Management Intern

headline: Operations Intern

cons: The program was still relatively new and therefore was partially put-together as we went. This led to a lot of under utilization of the interns and too few of opportunities to learn about the business.

cons: The bank it is today is very different from the bank it was in the past (pre financial crisis). In this era, there's a lot more growth being in technology - that said it is good to explore new opportunities in Fintech too. But if i were to start up something in Fintech, i will not be able to reap all the benefits (since it is a large firm and i cannot get the same type of shares that other Fintech startups can get)

headline: Analyst
pros: Great career launching pad (just like any investment banking job) that opens up a number of opportunities, particularly on the finance side of things. Even if you transition out of finance, the job still gives you a solid footing to where you rarely, if ever, have to justify your intelligence, competence and work ethic going forward. Generally smart, sharp and motivated bunch of people.
cons: Work/life balance is generally pretty bad, which includes late nights, early morning and mundane work (read: processing). The culture can be pretty toxic, as generally everyone you meet is looking at this option as a place to make good money and use as a stepping-stone for their next opportunity.

cons: Too laid back, sometimes lacking clear direction in what needs to be done. High number of average to below average workers

headline: Great company with many carreer opportunities

headline: Solid company

cons: Sometimes the collaborative culture can come off as bureaucratic and too consensus-driven.  Many meetings, working groups, and different experts who all have insights can make things seem to go more slowly than desired.

headline: Good working environment that is cutting cost

headline: Not a place to work in Information Technology group

headline: Good for 2 years to gain experience, but not more

Fix salary ok, but not raise, nor bonus during the restructuring years!!
Evaluation process not transparent at all.
Management taking decisions to cut off costs, despite the quality loss in outsourcing projects.

Big name which is unbeatable on CV.
Good benefits covering employee and the family too. 
Overall fair compensation scheme in line with performance and contribution.
cons:
Too big, too many doors for one problem but most of the doors are shut. 
Very slow decision making process, always take collective decision approach even on a very small matter.

headline: Disappointed that I was ever associated with this firm.

cons:

Over worked
Under paid

headline: Friendly culture, but disorganized overall

cons: Very disorganized overall, top-to-down communication is poor and often confusing messages, poor overall prospects of the firm, mass cost-cutting and outsourcing of positions

headline: expierienced professional.
pros: good attitude, good salaries, great atmosphere
cons: low bonuses, employee rotation, unprofessional middle managers.

headline: Change Group Associate Director

cons: The onboarding process was virtually non-existent when I started.  As a career switcher coming from a completely different industry it would have been nice to have a bit of structure at the get go to ramp up more quickly.

headline: Analyst
pros: Compensation in line with other buldge bracket
cons: Culture in some teams are not good.

headline: so so
pros: Good pay. Lot to learn
cons: No work life balance. Sometimes on unnecessary tasks

headline: Well run company with a laser focus on customers
pros: Management knows what it is doing.  All of the incentives are coordinated so that I do well by helping a coworker do well.  FA comp is designed to drive ethical behavior or at least not incentive unethical behavior.
cons: It's a big company and it take time to get things done, like clear an article through the review process before publishing it, but that's not a big deal most of the time.  Travel budgets are too small, even though they want us to travel more to support our coworkers.

headline: professional
pros: Most colleagues are very business professional with high standard.
cons: Pay is lower comparing to industry peers.

headline: Director
pros: reasonable work life balance. Opportunity learn about the industry.
cons: below market pay, no raises for years, performance review process not transparent and driven by in the "right circle"

headline: Associate Manager
pros: Good salary. Nice overall working conditions.
cons: Poor future planning by management.

headline: Senior Project Manager
pros:
Bright and highly motivated colleagues at every level. 
Many opportunities in various locations and in many potential areas of interest.
cons: Old fashioned personnel management structures, processes and practices. Frequent reorganisations coupled with aggressive outsourcing/low-cost location programs leave people wondering about their futures.

headline: Incredible first job experience (so far)
pros: Great work culture. Consistent deal flow. Great training program
cons: Not the same prestige as other firms

headline: It really feels like a big bank.
pros: There are many advancement opportunities if you stay with the firm over the course of several years. Plus the name is very strong on a resume.
cons: It sometimes feels like the little man doesn't matter. There is no "warm and fuzzy" feelings being tossed around but instead a very professional experience.

headline: Run
pros: Benefits are better than others on the street.   Used to be a great bank to have on your resume and a great place to build your career, not so much anymore.
cons:
Where do I start? Been here for 3 years and it's 2 years too long. Look to your left and look to your right, 2 out of 3 of your jobs are being moved to Nashville, offshore or gone completely. Cost cutting is insane to a point where they are creating huge costs to try an and cut them. People getting moved from floor to floor in Stamford just to get settled and move to NY or Nashville or the newest location of the top floor of RBS. 

Management spends 80% of their time talking about head count and how many hours their employees are working that there's no direction for actual client work. 

Internal moves are slim though growing. If you are lucky enough to land a job internally with a better department don't expect compensation. You'll get 5% if promoted only where you can 20% to go to any bank on the street. 

Overall it's a job not a career. Not a terrible place to get started but don't make it your life.

headline: it's okay
pros: Nice people, decent work environment
cons: Never stick to its plans and strategies

headline: Great learning opportunities if you're willing to get stuck in
pros:
1) Great culture (and getting better)
2) Good life work balance, flexible depending on role
cons:
1) Middle management layer disconnected
2) Lack of focus on career development, this is now changing

headline: Analyst
pros:
Great benefits
International career opportunities, the bank has a great reputation esp outside the US
cons:
Stiff and staid formal working environment
Systems can be improved

headline: Great colleagues!!!
pros: Really enjoyed my year with UBS, colleagues were great and there were always a lot of events and opportunities to meet leaders.
cons: Has less perks than some of the other Investment banks and brand recognition is worse in the US. People kept thinking i work for UPS delivering packets ;)

headline: Project Manager

good infrastructure
smart people around me
decent salary

performance assessment system unfair
chaotic organisation due to global set up
people do not count, only management objectives

headline: User Support Analyst
