headline: Toxic work environment
pros: > The company has credibility in the finance industry
cons:
> Pay is not competitive
> No investment in your career / future
> Sole focus is on cutting cost
> Switzerland employees are the thought leaders, not the US division

headline: Senior Portfolio Manager
pros: Good Base Pay and Pension Fund. Global Footprint with very international work force.Very strong Wealth Management platform but weak Investment Bank.
cons: Highly political. Forced Ranking employee evaluation system leads to everybody compeeting with each other. 20% of your peer group (by rank) has to get a 4 or 5 mark (1 being the best). Two times 4 and u are fired. This is actively used to get rid of people. Also you better get out before you are approaching 50 as those people are dumped by the truck load as well (to expensive given Swiss pension system). Loads of legacy issues from past 'sins' eat up big part of the groups profits in fines year by year with no end in sight. As a result relentless cost cutting and outsourcing

headline: Director
pros: Challenging environment from spend to people
cons: Cost cutting focus on everything

headline: HR Business Partner

cons: Too centralized, lacks entrepreneurial thinking, lacks creativity, inflexibile, risk averse in the wrong way, extremely slow moving.

headline: Nice place to work

cons: horrible back office support, compliance seem to be getting way more strict these are most likely just industry wide themes.

headline: change & infra project management

headline: Hit hard by the crisis and struggling still
pros: Big company, and with that some opportunities to move around.  Fairly young workforce who work hard and play (reasonably) hard.  Quite respectful between front office and middle office, and if you're willing to put the effort in to learn there are people willing to teach.
cons: Moral was low when I started in 2009 - understandably - but even lower when I left in 2013.  Progression was very hard outside front office, training budgets very tight, and opportunities to move out of the department were actively stopped.  It's a big company with a good history, and that counts for something on your CV, but needs to turn around a lot of it is to retain and attract talent.  Pay rises were very poor, even when you got promoted.

headline: Finance
pros: Very dynamic and responsive organisation. Top quality people and a strong and well progresed change agenda
cons: Despite the dynamism it is a big company and there is a degree of bureaucracy we all must work to overcome

headline: No diversity whatsoever- be ready to be called angry if you're black.
pros: Very clean offices, cafeteria was very convenient at a discounted price.
cons: There is no diversity whatsoever. It took four months before I saw another black person that worked for the company.

headline: oracle developer
pros: They use most up-to-date technology
cons: Working from us is not fun as most people will be in uk

headline: UHNW WEALTH MANAGEMENT - BRAZIL DESK
pros: International bank, net-working and respected bank
cons: hierarchy, not flexíble with clients and employes

headline: Decent company but difficult time to be in finance, major focus on costs but good company overall.
pros: Global reach & recognition, varied career opportunities, mostly fair compensation though very dependent on division & specific area
cons: Lack of focus on development, major focus on costs, volatility in many businesses

headline: Associate
pros: relatively nicer colleagues compared to other IB
cons: bonus is way too small. many talented people left for that.

headline: Attracting and retaining exceptional talent is lower priority than pleasing shareholders and cutting costs.
pros: Global company.  Ability to work with many people from around the world every day.  Many opportunities to learn new skills.  Coworkers are very pleasant to work with.
cons: The culture has shifted from a collaborative and can-do attitude to one of a can't-do mentality due to significantly reduced teams having to continuously say "we don't have the resources" and "we need more funding".  New organizational structure within corporate center division affecting thousands of staff.  Minimal support for new organizational structure.  Minimal evidence of benefits for new organizational structure.  Repetitive head-count reductions.  Compensation and benefits below the average of peers.

headline: Director - WM
pros: Large platform, footprint, and reach.
cons: Large organization, bad communication, inefficient systems, and too much politics.

headline: Legal entity stress testing and capital adequacy
pros: Offers good work life balance
cons: Negative energy persists due to constant reorganisation

headline: Not what a multi-national IB should be
pros: There is a great work-life balance and resume value.
cons: Tenure of employees and general motivations of the division / skill levels lacking actual fundamentals. The work-life balance comes at a cost of having colleagues who are not motivated.

headline: Support analyst
pros: global brand, different divisions exposure,
cons: may be hard to move divisions

headline: Very happy so far, but a lot of that could be luck
pros: I fell into a great position, working with super smart and overall lovely colleagues. The company is truly international, so I am able to work with many different types of people -- which really ups your personal learning & development process. The company is huge, and they are constantly reorganizing (good and bad thing) -- it's up to you to seek out opportunities, but they are there if you are willing to look and put in the effort. And yes, you have to be friendly with those in power (not suck up, just make yourself known), but politics exist in ANY company, large or small.
cons:
Not much diversity at the top, particularly in Switzerland -- it's exactly who you'd think would be running a large bank.

The Swiss are cold -- but they're Swiss. They also think about Americans negatively overall, and talk about it constantly, even to Americans.

headline: Overall, a great company to work for - solid bank, great reputation.
pros: Large company, great benefits, solid reputation.
cons: Too large of a company, lots of politics.  Do not interact with many of the departments.

headline: Great experience
pros: Heavy investment in getting folks in the door (internship, GTP training program)
cons:
Not enough continuing mentorship
Politics (as with any other big bank)

headline: UBS Wealth Management
pros: Hours are reasonable in wealth management division (8:30-5:00), if you impress the senior advisers there is an incredible upside potential.
cons: It is very hard to break through the ceiling, stiff competition and limited advancement opportunities means you really have to distinguish yourself against some top talent.  Since excellence at the job is a requirement, career decisions tend to be made on other factors.

headline: swiss banker job
pros: good salary, good working building, clean environement, high Standard,
cons: Money is in the Focus of everything, better higher further for any Price, no social working enveronement between collegs, every working colleg is a competitior, no trust between each other in the front working staffs

headline: intern
pros: best team work, broad knowledge, good salary
cons: high induvidualism, so much hierarchy inside the company

headline: Great Culture
pros:
Made up of former Merrill Lynch Brass
Committed to the advisor and the client relationship
Committed to providing access to full financial planning products/services
cons:
Slow with technology advancement
A bit forceful on financial planning
Typical wirehouse

headline: Tough, the bank is cutting back and jobs decline whilst expectations on service remain similar as they were before.
pros: people are aware it's tough
cons: Expectations out of line with what can be required

headline: Wealth Management Intern
pros: Great work environment; challenging but won't overload you with work.
cons: Lack of transparency with superiors

headline: bad outweigh good.
pros: One of largest wire house firms. Looks good on a resume. A lot of helpful training. A good place to start.
cons: Not much help. Basically give you unrealistic expectation and act shocked when goals aren't met. Unless family member works there or you are independently wealthy do not apply. They will push you out in a few years.

headline: Awesome
pros: Good working environment and senior mgt is very helful
cons: sometimes the compensation is not on par with the amount of work load

headline: Good culture in PWM; can be hectic
pros: understanding bosses, can be demanding.
cons: If there is in-fighting in your team, good luck. PWM teams usually move together; anything otherwise is like treason.

headline: Corporation first
pros: Many great people to work with. Plenty of challenges. Truly global company. Relaxed office dress code. Flexible hours. Work from home opportunities.
cons: Keep reducing staff to reduce costs. Work loads continue to increase with increasing conflicts in priorities. Lot of complicated procedures to to follow to get internal services. Internal services not properly linked.

headline: Good place for a year or two but don't stay any longer.
pros:
Good place to start a career
UBS name helps on your resume
cons:
below average compensation (salary, bonus and benefits)
weak upper management in Canada 
lack of transparency from management
lack of employee training

headline: Great people, under-compensation.
pros: Great culture and smart people.
cons: Below average compensation and legal issues.

headline: Client Resolution Specialist
pros:
Decent pay
Nice and new work environment
cons:
They don't care about advancement
Managers have been there forever

headline: Not a Bad Place to Start in the Banking Industry
pros: Collegial and professional atmosphere where people are willing to help develop young professionals
cons: Not sure pay is always 100% competitive with other bulge bracket banks and seem to be behind on some of the quality of life improvements other banks have implemented.

headline: It was O.K. The people that were there when I started were fine. Had no problems
pros: Because of a referral by a current employee, my time there was fine. Had no problems with my hours, if I had to take time off, my supervisor at the time had no problems.
cons: When a new hire came in and had no liking to the employee that referred me, she made my life a complete hell. If anyone that was loyal to the employee that referred me, she gave them a hard time and again, would be angry that everyone liked the person that referred me.

headline: I really wouldn't waste your time. The only success I have seen is if you are buying a book of business.
pros: The benefits and training are good. The firm can find solutions for pretty much any problem. Eat what you kill mentality...
cons: Management is non-existent. No help at developing business, but expect production without any direction or help. Basically they hand you a phone book and ask you to start calling people.

headline: Decent place to work if you can handle the politics
pros: Good experience.  High base pay.
cons: High turnover.  Poorly managed. Frequent job cuts and nasty politics at bonus time.

headline: people do not challenge
pros: compensation, internal mobility, geographic mobility, international
cons: obsessed by ranks, comp and people do not challenge

headline: Great Management
pros: Good working environment.  Great company to work for, good benefits.  The work life balance is nice.  I worked with a great group of people.
cons: I do not have any negative things to say about the company.  There are a lot of opportunities for advancement.

headline: BOA
pros: Great learning experience, and a job where you can develop many new skills in various areas.
cons: Can be a bit overwhelming if you are new to the industry since you are learning multiple things at once.

headline: No internal communication
pros: the people, teamwork, and sales managers
cons: upper management, misguided goals, becoming too much like Merrill Edge

headline: The management team changes all the time.
pros: better work/life balance, colaborative environment
cons: The managers used to know about the business are all gone. The new managers are very good at bluffing and taking other people's work for credit, but know nothing about the business.

headline: No loyalty and no culture.
pros: Its a paycheck week to week.  Able to develop some what of a repore with immediate colleagues and contacts locally.
cons: Almost no work life balance, culture has clearly been affected by all the regulation in the US.  There are people in pharmaceutical sales that get more perks than IBers now.  Communication largely over AOL IM type chat system, not personal and makes individuals feel like mere cogs.

headline: European culture
pros: European culture made for a comfortable working environment. Managers were supportive and involved in junior employee growth and development. Work-life balance was a priority
cons: Uncertainty around long-term future of the business in the USA, as well as negative publicity around tax scandals in Switzerland

headline: Where's the humanity? I know this is corporate America but come on...
pros: Coworkers are great, decent benefits, good amount of vacation time
cons: You're made to feel like you're a lemming. You're reviewed based on stats and numbers, not quality. There's no humanity when it comes to work-life balance. Not to mention, in the interview process they pride themselves on supporting personal growth and development, but in reality they make it nearly impossible for you to move up - or out - or achieve anything. There's no incentive to work hard, as it will get you nowhere but taken advantage of.

headline: Intern
pros: Ability for promotions, state of the art technology and great interns to work with
cons: Very long hours, very poor communication between management teams

headline: It was a good place to work at but lacked communication internally
pros: great place to start a career. People were very interested in mentoring and was able to have a lot of responsibilities early on.
cons:
Internally there was a lack of communication from mgmt to the rest of the team. 

Felt that producers were not fairly compensated at the appropriate times.

headline: Just around the corner...
pros: Good work/life balance (not in NYC), good hours
cons: Terrible communication from management and unrealistic optimism, management tries to be transparent but is afraid of totally showing their hand too early and thereby become opaque and not trusted, bad pay, overqualified for job

headline: Big, broad, bureaucracy
pros: Large enough to have areas of interest for any employee, sitting on large excess capital base so the bank will never fail, if you can make your boss look good, you will do well.
cons: Not an innovator, late to any trends in the markets, then pay top dollar for asset acquisitions, leading to inevitable failure. Regularly cited by regulatory agencies for unethical violations, senior management came from Merrill Lynch, and continue to have that old Wall St mentality of pushing high cost, high margin products across the board. Despite this, the bank fails to grow (+2% yoy top line growth) forcing regular headcount reductions to grow bottom line.

headline: Little fish in a big pond but room to develop and network within company.
pros: Network, benefit from large range of services and expertise, possibility to change within the company, work life balance.
cons: Less room to develop / career development. Political obstacles.

headline: risk analyst intern
pros: good working environment, smart and nice people to work with
cons:
little room for upward mobility
management is difficult to deal with

headline: Gets worse every year
pros: My boss is great.  Some of my co-workers are great.
cons: Overall, too WMA focused.  God help you if you need HR assistance, all self service and no one has a clue.  Very little chance of advancement unless you are one of chosen few.  A heartless organization.

headline: Good
pros: Improving culture, some high caliber people
cons: Poor pay, limited promotion opportunities

headline: Great working environment with supportive management
pros: Good training ground for fresh graduates. Challenging yet rewarding.
cons: There was not much work life balance.

headline: Managing testing activities of Advisory and Billing applications.
pros:
Flexible working hours
Good working environment
cons:
Less Salary
Difficult to get promotion

headline: okay
pros: tons of opportunities and plenty of internal movement
cons: old fashioned views. all about who you know. at times unprofessional outbursts

headline: Good company, very different per location
pros: Good company, above average salary, challenging
cons: Long hours, hierarchical, sometimes political, limited carrier opportunities if not supported by some senior

headline: Currently looking for other opportunities
pros: Business model is well defined
cons: Limited opportunity for continued growth

headline: very good team
pros: Very good company and good compenstation
cons: Long hours and limited training available and very tight deadlines

headline: Good place to start a career.
pros: Post college grad training program
cons: Compensation is not dependent on your work.

headline: Working environment
pros: great people great food fir day
cons: lots of regulation pressure and peer pressure

headline: It has been a great experience.
pros: The family atmosphere that exists at UBS.
cons: The technology is not up to date in some areas

headline: Good
pros: Supports military persons and veterans
cons: Low bonuses and long hours

headline: Operations
pros: Good work/life balance, Benefits, Career development
cons: Office politics and senior management

headline: very challenging and highly competitive environment
pros: very challenging and highly competitive environement, highly professional, open for innovation, strive for excellence, very supportive for sophistication, very interesting expert opportunities, definigtely a place to work
cons: issues with collaboration in some teams, silo mentality in some teams, internal perspectives at senior level are limited and leads to brain drain, sometimes very hierarchical

headline: Above the industry average
pros: Great work-life balance. Opportunities to help outside of job description.
cons: Vastly different in culture/enviornment from office to office.

headline: Hope you have family money before you start. Similar to Morgan Stanley or Merrill Lynch
pros: Great opportunity if you can get on a good team that wont take advantage of you or make it past the first couple years.
cons: Ability to make it past the first couple years

headline: Financial Analyst Intern
pros: The group I worked with was very easy to get along with. At first I was not too thrilled about the cold calling aspect but have since learned it is s valuable experience to have on resume.
cons: Often I would not have tasks or projects thoroughly explained to me. Towards then end of the internship when I got to work with FGAs I really had no idea what I was doing.

headline: A good place to develop at
pros: Lots of opportunities within the firm, great cimpensation, good culture which has been changing in the last years.
cons: Lots of changes at the moment.

headline: Fulltime at UBS
pros:
Good work culture
Work life balance, but largely depends on manager
Met some good people
cons:
Usual politics at work place
Hierarchical sturcture, and getting promoted can be a pain
No focus on personal development

headline: Great power handled badly
pros: Excellent benefits, opportunities broad across organization, highly talented colleagues
cons: Senior Management wants to rule from the top; very bad at listening to the field. Swiss culture heavily concentrated on form over function silliness ("clean desk" policy impedes productivity for the hardest-working employees) and Swiss still fail to grasp American culture and behavior, despite almost 15 years of owning US businesses.

headline: Great entry level position and/or career ending position; very few "lifers"
pros: Good atmosphere; good benefits; in Private Wealth Management, your team is your lifeblood...so if you find a team that you like and is successful, then you can be set for a long time.
cons: Big bank; therefore this means there are limitations to how fast you can move up vertically. Management is content to keep you content in an entry level role for as long as they can.

headline: Onboarding
pros: Sort after company that is well known for their ethical sandards
cons: Dont have any cons at present

headline: general working conditions
pros: good benefits as health insurance and multisport card, language courses for employees, many young people working there, kitchen in the building
cons: the location far from the city, many overhours, deadlines hard to meet as other teams send reports to late with errors

headline: Very nice for beginning. I had a nice start there. Quite good salary for unexperienced employee,
pros: Great atmosphere, real possibilities for promotion and development
cons: Not good enough cash, beaurocracy at office

headline: Client Associate
pros: The hourly wage was very competitive in comparison to local companies and firms around the San Jose area. The upper level management was always willing to provide me with guidance and never turned down one of my questions.
cons: The amount of responsibility that you are given is very low in comparison to the amount of responsibility that my friends were given in their internships. You really do not learn much at all that will benefit you in the future.

headline: I worked my senior year of College as a Wealth Management Intern at UBS.
pros:
High growth potential. 
Superiors care about your professional and personal development.
Ability to learn a lot in a short amount of time. 
UBS market reports and research are unmatched.
cons:
Hierarchical structure can lead to impersonal work setting. 
Superiors may not empower lower-level employees enough, leading to a frustrating barrier to work.
Lower pay than most other internships.

headline: Avoid if possible
pros:
- close to home
- not a bad cafeteria
- free coffee
- easy to spell company name
- lots of things to complain about (ok, I'm really struggling with any real pros)
cons:
- management up to at least executive directors appear to have practically no authority
- continued cuts and outsourcing policies have resulted in most technical knowledge no longer being in company and majority of those remaining are now really just administrators and co-ordinators
- what seems to be management's total lack of interest in staff and even projects, became infectious for staff at other levels

headline: Going through a change
pros: The firm has a clear picture of where they want their Investment Bank to go and what it is should look like in the future. A large restructuring has reduced the fat in the upper management. It flows like a pyramid now, not like an upside down one.
cons: Benefits are weak compared to other. Resources are limited and technology is outdated. There is still a little challenge with the transition, some employees are fighting the change.

headline: Review
pros:
- Collegial environment
- Lots of opportunity of you are on a growing team
cons:
- Employee talent pool is not that great.  A number of people at the firm are just not that good.  However, the folks in sales and trading are impressive 
- Senior Management tends to make rash decisions without regard to employee impact.
- No IT resources
- Layoff risk once you get too expensive for them

headline: Various roles
pros: Collaborative, global, diverse, culture and history, challenging problems to solve, lots of change work to keep profitable and meet strategy
cons: Extreme cost focus, quick to cut costs but slow to invest, bureaucratic slow in making decisions, inefficient

headline: Workable Location
pros: Good place to work. Good process control. Sometimes, it may feel tedious, but overall it is satisfactory to work
cons: Tedious processes - some times, it may need to be relaxed

headline: Internship Experience
pros: As an intern, I appreciated having such great mentors. Everyone here was extremely supportive. Even the fellow interns were looking to help me rather than harboring a competitive attitude.
cons: None, in my experience as an intern.

headline: Investment Banking Assistant
pros: People were nice, lots of admin training, very organized
cons: Overloaded with work and no salary increase for years, barely a bonus at all!  Wasn't worth all the work for nothing in return!  Too much red tape and approvals from upper management.

headline: Great experience working in FIG
pros: It boost personal and professional growth, while managing a decent work-life balance.
cons: Somedays you are going to work more than 12 hours, but in the end you get use to it.

headline: Summer analyst
pros: It was a very great experience. I was working in the quant team in the Shanghai Office in China.
cons: The learning curve is very deep. I was in my junior year at that time. Have to learn a lot by myself.

headline: It's good after you've got to a point
pros:
Decent balance between environment, work/life balance and compensation. 
Open and relaxed culture.
cons:
Lack of career development options (unless you engage in office politics).
Long term prospects for IT are unclear.
The management actively tries to dismantle many of the things that currently retain the better personnel.

headline: Better go the independent route
pros: Decent comp package and good Club structure.
cons: You are just the number of your production but unless you are in the top or at the very bottom do not expect training or professional opportunities.

headline: Flexibility at the cost of advancement
pros:
Flexible work schedule
People don't kill themselves with work, slow motion operation.
Decent worker bees wanting to do good work and trying to do the right things.
cons:
Too much managing up the ladder
Constant mgmt reorganization, most projects could be labeled "mgmt recycling programs"
Poor communication to staff
Annual employee survey (Pulse) results get worse every year.  They resort to begging people to complete them.
Employee morale at all time low. 
All the good people have left. 
Incompetent upper managers: Peter Principle exemplified.
Annual job reviews are a joke.  Forced rankings: you are forced to put people in the "needs improvement" category regardless of whether they deserve it.  Those poor souls get $0 bonus, $0 raises and or fired.
Project planning/funding process is hopelessly broken.
Over outsourced, 70+% of IT is gone and along with them is all their knowledge of how things get done.  The result is that everything takes forever to get done.
 
Constant media attention on illegal activities and huge fines, never ending.  
Your friends will say: "why do you still work there?"
Benefit plans get worse every year, less benefits for more money.
Less contribution to employee retirement accounts.
Reduction in severance packages, indicative of headcount reduction plans.
Moving jobs to "low cost" areas (Nashville) comes with 20% salary decrease and no re-location expense help.

headline: Excellent
pros:
I found UBS a place that presented the opportunity to grow  if you were willing to put in the time. I appreciated feeling free to bring ideas too the table. Even if they weren't accepted having the option of being heard was a privilege.
I always felt like part of a team.
cons: Unfortunately when you work for a big company, budgetary problems, have you seem as part of a group. Rather than an individual.

headline: Brief but useful time at UBS
pros:
Decent remuneration ( but could be better)
Friendly atmosphere - people of all levels are approachable and there is a good culture or mentoring / nurturing talent with in the organisation
I didn't experience too much beautocracy
Open door approach from Senior management
plenty of opportunity to interact and work with senior management
Very joined up organisation globally - teams work closely across multiple geographies
Also good collaboration front to back within the organisation and the structure is set up to facilitate this
cons:
Reputation requires rebuilding after their bad press in recent years due to trader incidents
Pay could be better
London offices need renewing

headline: Good with some exceptions and JOB CUTS !!!
pros: better on mobility, work envirnment
cons: serious cut downs specially in corporate centre, poor IT systems, red tape and hierrachy issue, lower rank employees are pushed in terms of pay and promotion. lowest paid in industry compared to peers

headline: Hiring process is wrong
pros: Nice people, global company, nice premises,
cons: Test results has priority on the selection process

headline: In troubke
pros: This is a sinking ship
cons: Hasn't sunk yet but getting there

headline: Fixed income trading
pros: Good training, good team and culture
cons: Pay below average, long hours

headline: UBS, one of the worst Investment Banks out there
pros: .- There are none that can be listed
cons: -poor management, little sense of strategic direction, no subject knowledge, poor employee retention, no sense of deliverables linked to MD objectives, staff that are left are the ones who cant or wouldn't be able to get a job anywhere else

headline: Can Be a Great or Horrible Experience
pros: Progressive approach to infrastructure and software. Many companies are stuck in the past, keeping old systems alive even though they are outdated and problematic. UBS is at least trying to remain current. Or they were when last I was there.
cons: Some amazingly bad middle managers with no regard for employees personal lives. If you get one of them expect to work until at least 7PM every day as well as be on call 24/7. Telecommuting is up to the individual managers are an all to great percentage of them are iron-fisted micro-managers so they do not allow it at all. Their approach to systems and software is at odds with their approach to people. I would not work there again.

headline: Couldn't be happier
pros: Friendly work environment with strong leadership
cons: I do not have any at this time

headline: Good name to have on CV
pros: Salary is well paid and lots of movement in the department if you wish to move internally
cons: Long hours and working culture. Management do not really communicate properly

headline: Client service associate for 3 years
pros: A lot of support from management. I worked in two different offices but got along with nearly everyone. They tend to hire very good people.
cons: Not the best position for someone looking to advance their career

headline: System Analyst
pros: Great Company to work for
cons: none I enjoyed working there

headline: Operations Analyst
pros: The hours are not bad and the people are friendly
cons: The work is mind numbingly easy and repetitive

headline: IT Risk and Control Specialist
pros:
Low workload
Lots if smart people around (doesn't mean they know the stuff work connected but the are generally smart)
cons: Hard to get proper info, People resposnible for the proces has problems to understand basic stuff.

headline: Move around to different groups to maximize knowledge.
pros: Ability to work from home, time off, work/life balance.  You make your best salary deal walking through the door do make it a good one.
cons: Operations moving to Nashville.  Limited raises, bonuses and promotions. Recommend that you transfer  into a new position every two years to maximize growth.

headline: Company Opportunities
pros: The company has greatly attributed to my growth and development.  They believe in internal promotions
cons: The constant evolution of the industry and increased regulatory scrutiny has been a challenge.

headline: Solid banking experience
pros: Good networking opportunities and fantastic experience for aspiring bankers; constant exposure to upper management figures during internship
cons: Extreme work hours, difficult to find work-life balance; hyper-competition may make career prospects difficult

headline: Friendly company
pros: Capable employees with a very friendly company culture - best managers I've ever had
cons: Difficult to progress in the light of extreme offshoring and unpractical promotion policies

headline: Intern
pros: Great company to work for
cons: None keep up the good work

headline: Inconsistent strategy but always consistently chaotic - the worst career experience of my 20+ years as a professional.
pros: You can make decent money if you have the correct rabbi as there is no adherence to the rules. Compensation is the biggest area where they play favorites. (I made a LOT of money there)
cons: Always fearing that the ax is about to fall.

headline: If chaos, high turnover, low morale and poor compensation attracts you
pros:
- Worklife balance depending on your team
- laidback
cons:
First of all UBS is not what it used to be 5 years back. You will be disappointed if you compare UBS to JP Morgan Chase, Morgan Stanley, GS and Credit suisse in terms of compensation and bonus.
- UBS pays a decent compensation which can be compared to a mid-size companies
- Benefits are not are great as it used to be and slowly its getting slashed every year
- Most the of good senior technical folks who left are not being replaced and leftover is distributed among the junior employees.The best part is that even these junior employees are not be awarded
- You won't feel proud or enjoy working here now-a-days as due to ongoing structural changes and layoffs, people are more concerned about having their job than actually doing it.
- Things might be different if your rank is ED or up

headline: Nice team, strange company spirit
pros: Salary is def. above average...
cons: Tasks were not demanding enough

headline: WM Summer Analyst
pros: Great team and mentors. Lots of different opportunities to explore.
cons: Since I worked at a satellite office, there weren't a lot of interns to interact with. Compensation wasn't very competitive either.

headline: this is a great company to work for, i really enjoy working
pros: the management are great and the opportunities are equally great
cons: the hours can be long but thats not too bad

headline: nice place
pros: nice place to work in ..good people
cons: no systems in place, needs to work on focusing

headline: Good structure in place; colleagues are friendly.

Clear direction of company. 
Good environment 
Supportive team and cohesive dynamics

headline: UBS intern

headline: OK company
pros: it's a great working environment, very familiar, very kind. Flexible sometimes.
cons: Low salaries, not too many perks,  a little unclear about positions, you are hired to do something and end up doing ten other different things. Terrible organizational strategies and philosophy.

headline: UBS Wealth Management Internship

Great company to have on resume
Got to listen in on client calls
Great networking
Worked independently
Very flexible schedule

Not enough real learning
Boring work

Some reallt talented and motivated people
More civilised than US bulge brackets
Strong infrastructures

headline: Good Company but Poor Career Development

Leading technology

Flexible working environment

poor career development
limited training dollars

headline: Experience in HR

cons: Long hours, unrealistic expectations, risky to work in back office of any bank

headline: Director
pros: It's a great working environment.
cons: None that I Can think of.

headline: 40% turnover rate
pros:
1.Many positions have great work life balance.

headline: Long term employee has seen the ups and downs
pros: Flexible work schedule depending on role and direct line management. Training and growth opportunities if employee drives those efforts for their managers. Many smart and nice people still on board trying to foster a good work environment. CEO and leadership teams are making efforts to evolve the culture but this will take years.
cons: Financial services isn't what it used to be. Spending at all levels and for some 'basics' (replacing worn furnishings at branches, consistent incentives for junior level employees) are being dispensed with. Off shoring model will prove only partially successful as it doesn't suit the industry service expectations - at the cost of the loss of legacy knowledge and expensive consultant-minded senior hires who are not invested in the success of the firm, rather their own CV building. Middle managers are no longer invested in building their teams as they, too, are afraid for their own security and have devolved to self-survival.

headline: Rollercoaster
pros:
Really smart people who are passionate about solving clients' problems
Select teams have a great vibe and are really fun to work with
Ability to learn a lot about global financial services
cons:
Extremely political, resulting in too many poor managers
Antiquated technology for most of firm.  Some teams don't know who their top 10 clients are
Except for Financial Advisors, your bonus compensation is 100% correlated to how well politically positioned your group head is, regardless of your performance output.  When I had a good group head, I got paid extremely well, even in the bad Wall Street years.  When I had a bad group head, my bonus wasn't even 10% of a good year even though my output was at the highest level
Slow to move.  Too indecisive about the type of firm they are and what on their platform truly benefits clients
HR function is basically non existent
Difficult to move around and get a well-rounded financial services experience - leads to few to no executives who are positioned to run such a large organization
Way too much turnover, and not of the people who need to go

headline: Had a crazy ride at UBS IT Audit departament.
pros:
UBS has a dynamic IT Audit organization that is open enough to provide growth oportunities for experienced technologists looking to widen their perspective.
They may allow you to take sufficient time to dig deeper into the problemas so you can offer more to the bussiness than just pointing a finger at issues.
Job provides insight into the working habits of top IT management, risk management, compliance across whole organization which you will find quite educational.
cons:
The audit cycle is paramont and eventually you have to focus primairly on finishing your audits on time and formal validity of issues, in depth approach is allowed only by excepton.
The audit reports are extensively edited by whole departament so there isn't much in terms of independence of message but I guess it is a norm in most companies.

I worked there as a Business Analyst for a central system and therefore got in touch with a lot of stakeholders and my personal network growth was kind good.
cons: The wage was under the regular market price. I guess you get better paid in many other companies. But maybe it was just this job-position that had such a bad wage. Anyway, the management lacks commitment and you rarely get any help or support from them. Furthermore you don't get much time for any education since the work-load is quite high.

headline: Java Developer at UBS Investment Bank (FX)
pros: Salary was good. People were generally very clever.
cons:
Organisation of projects was pretty chaotic - projects frequently got cancelled after significant effort had been put in.
There was no real process in place - There was a release every 3 months or so, but it wasn't very well planned and frequently targets were missed, or changed throughout the cycle. That was about it really as far as process goes.
The project I worked on was enormous, on its last legs, had zero unit testing, and was therefore totally unsuited to any refactoring. Most of our effort was spent on bug fixing. The delicacy of the code meant that implementing even the simplest new features took an age.

headline: Working at UBS

headline: Great place to work for. Best system platform be it front or bank office.
pros:
Advanced IT system platform, paperless and less manual task due to the great system
Competitive Pay and above average staffs benefit egs. swisscare credit & all rounded insurance coverage
Generally good working culture and professionalism, high caliber workers, has standard in hiring
Good work life balance across except certain team in operations. Eg: Account admin doc team worked past mid-night
Effective balance between compliance & efficiency established processes & workflow, good learning ground for fresh grad
cons:
Too little promotion headcount, many has the tenure of services and capabilities but just no headcount to promote them.
Can be very fake and political in some teams, heartless at times
Unfairness and bias within teams lead to low morale or unhappiness
Tend to penalize fast and efficient people, by giving them more work without distinct better compensation / recognition as compared to the less productive. Capable workers are take for granted.

headline: IT experiencing identity crisis and bleeding talent
pros: Great multi-cultural, multi-national environment with highly talented people.
cons:
Talent continues to leave the bank (both voluntarily and involuntarily) due to ongoing turmoil and cost reductions as IT tries to reinvent itself.  

Poor gender balance.  I get that this is a Swiss bank but women are hugely under-represented, especially in senior positions and in the European hubs of London and Zurich.

headline: Good
pros: Good working environment, and is one of the best internships worldwide, or at least in the banking sector.Employees are willing to teach you all the processes until you learn to do them appropriately. ubs is not for lacey people plus you should be aiming for a long term career in this firm
cons: There are no cons because this is the one of the best firms to work in this country.

headline: Job at UBS was okay
pros: My co-workers were nice. When I had questions they would answer them and operations was very helpful.
cons: Constant micromanagement. I would be given very little instruction and was expected to know everything with minimal instruction.

headline: Overly hierarchical, filled w politics, intrigue, deceit and resistant to change, so /so compensation / fringe benefits
pros: Very international (but still very Swiss),
cons: Bad, uncooperative internal climate very emotionally draining, filled with (well-protected) crooks, little real transparency or respect for employees.

headline: challenging but great exposure
pros: great career development and offer opportunities for internal transferral
cons: too large the organization, takes time to understand the specific responsibility of each team in a department

headline: The people and job responsibility make it rewarding. Advancement opportunity and employee moral are low.
pros: The company has good benefits and reasonable time off policies.
cons: Their business practices need a much improved moral compass.

headline: Duct-taped conglomeration of mediocrity
pros: Plenty of beaurocracy and hand-waving to hide behind and do your own thing without much scrutiny.
cons: Impossible to actually get anything done of substance since all the real talent eventually leaves.  Mediocre talent, too much focus on sales and less on substance.

headline: Associate Analyst
pros: no sales targets or other craps
cons: UBS in Shanghai uses Wipro as outsourcing. Indian heads suck.

headline: I worked there for a few years
pros: It was a good time when the market was going up.  Pay was going up, and everyone were nice and happy.
cons: It was not a good time when the market was going down.  Pay plummeted and there were layoffs galore.

headline: it was ok but could had been better
pros: loved my FAs and hours
cons: too many turn overs at the firm

headline: Software Engineers are ignored.
pros: The only pro is work life balance. For the most part you won't have a heavy work load.
cons: Too many managers. Too much involvement of Business in technical decisions. Most of the business people don't have any idea about technology but have a huge say in how an application should be designed. Software engineers who actually build these applications have no respect. Business managers and Program managers take all the credit

headline: It's who you know not what you know kind of company
pros: Large company with average benefits. Facilities were nice enough.
cons: You kept your job and was promoted based on who you knew rather than how hard you worked and what you know. A lot of politics needed and boot licking needed to work here.

headline: Large corporate, they have the infrastructure to do a lot, but sometimes that can take awhile. (TPS Reports)
pros: Great people to work with, very customer focused and high energy. Many opportunities for training, growth, and movement throughout the company. Benefits and worklife balance are truly outstanding.
cons: Jobs can be menial, repetitive, and tedious (dealing with the general public who feels entitled). Change is almost impossible to effect.

headline: Private Wealth Office is an excellent place to work if you are with the right FA
pros: Pay is largely determined by your FA and can be really generous. Management is understanding and generally less in your face than other wealth management offices
cons: Technology struggles. Each team has their own unique culture base on how the FAs run things. FAs in the private wealth office are very full of themselves.

headline: Getting there one step at a time
pros: Culture, global teams, people
cons: Bureaucratic, too many management layers, growth opportunities are restricted if you are in smaller sites

headline: Great work environment. Good People. Good Company
pros: Being a young professional right out of college the work environment here is great. Most of my co-workers were my age, young professionals looking to make something of themselves. Managers are always willing to help you and support your goals.
cons: Mobility within the company isn't that great. Unless you part of the GTP program getting to where you want (i.e. financial adviser, management, front office) isn't going to come fast. They prioritize everything for the kids in the GTP program.

headline: Not enough promotion slots in APAC
pros:
Good mobility
Family friendly
Flexible working hours
cons:
No promotion slots
Thin bonus
Small salary growth, can't even compensate the inflation
People turn over rate is too high

headline: A company with great benefits and learning experiences.
pros:
The people and culture is great. You are surrounded by friendly competent people.
The work life balance for women of higher ranks is good. Senior management is open to alternative working situations. E.g Work from home once a week, work from a UBS office in a different location for several weeks.
The culture of teamwork and integrity is prevalent. However, there are always outliers.
cons: Career development opportunities are few. Even when an employee tries to drive their own career development, effecting the change seems difficult. Lack of transparency in advancement opportunities and career paths.

headline: PM at UBS
pros: Greate freedom during work. lots of responsability. work at home. nice co workers. no fix start time for being at work.
cons: Compesation is not good. end of year rating process sucks. they have fix rates of good or bad performar and a very low promotion rate. so you have to wait long for a change.

headline: Great few years!
pros:
Culture is great, people are great. If you get into the right branch, you could really enjoy yourself. Management wants to see you succeed - refreshing! 

Benefits are great too!
cons:
Not alot of access to learn about other possibilites within the company to grow & progress. 
Pay, not great compared to the other companies on the street.

headline: Good work-life balance
pros: The work-life balance is good, good bunch of people to work with. Had a good hiring process so perms are people you can respect.
cons: Far too much emphasis on cheap outsourcing. Little apparent interest in building good pipeline of perm staff. I think for all perms (working with outsource guys) the job is more about managing poor junior staff and less about doing the job.

headline: Traditional Wealth Management
pros: Colleagues, nice work-life balance, nice culture
cons: It is difficult to move internally

headline: Just to get things done
pros: Good facility, IT and admin support
cons: Toxic culture, no personal growth prospect, being rejected a career advancement

headline: So So employer
pros: Reputable bank name and good medical benefits
cons: Not a great place to work.   More work less pay for juniors

headline: You get what you put in at UBS.
pros: A lot of availability to move around and grow.
cons: Sometimes management stays put when they should not.

headline: Satisfied employee
pros: Lots of young people, helpful, small team but the perks of a large corporation.
cons: Hard to move up once in position for a long time.

headline: Good opportunities await.
pros: I was at UBS AG for one year. I really enjoyed the people I worked with and the breadth of experience that were available to me as soon as I stepped through the door. The training is solid with assistance in either the IMC or CFA qualification if you so choose.
cons: The markets weren't kind to UBS the year that I was with them. Cut backs and redundancies plagued the bank. This greatly affected the moral of the team and subsequent departments.

headline: UBS = U've Been Screwed
pros: Solid benefits, good salary/pay if you are in the right department.
cons: EXTREMELY POLITICAL.  Bonus system that invites corruption and unfair bonus awarding.

headline: Authorized officer review
pros: flexible working. Ease to come and go
cons: Opportunities to grow were limited. Too many levels

headline: IT Manager with several years of service
pros: The staff are generally friendly, supportive, cooperative, in other words a good bunch. Work-life balance is reasonably flexible, and compensation is fair in my experience, but with wide variation apparently. Get yourself on the right IT project(s) and you can have a great experience here, but make sure your projects have business-visibility and an appropriate budget. For some, including myself, working in a highly distributed and culturally diverse environment is a bonus.
cons: In general the business regards IT as simply an expense, to be minimised. This culture can lead to frustration for any ambitious IT staff in terms of project budgets, creative opportunities, renumeration and promotion prospects. IT management lacks direction, has low visibility, and staff turnover is high.

headline: Great place to work
pros: Great work-life balance, willing to hire new grads, good training
cons: Management track is completely separate from client support track, and it's difficult to jump tracks from all accounts

headline: Unfulfilled potential and a lot of lost talent, but still a lot of good things about it
pros: Culture is generally welcoming, work-life practices are actually implemented and encouraged, benefits are good and the mindset is global. people are some of the brightest and nicest in the city.
cons: not much resource for training, still a lot of bureaucracy, and support functions have been industrialised / out sourced which is a major barrier to an effective and slick workforce. the complaint generally - and fairly - is "its not what it used to be". Has put a lot of effort into transforming, but not always in the right direction.

headline: Good Company to work for
pros: Great people and depending on the department great atmosphere to work in.
cons: The organizational structure is confusing and you have to talk to a lot of people before getting any of the answers you need.

headline: Analyst
pros: Good training, some very good people to learn from/work for,
cons: work-life balance, highly inefficient work flow

headline: Run as fast as you can!
pros: Work life balance. That's the only thing I could think of!
cons:
Layoffs every quarter, they have lost their best employees, no job security, no travel and trainings. 
Right now there is very low morale among the employees. They are tying to move everyone to Nashville and hiring all the new positions there.
Most people have got no raises from years and also bonus is as good as none.
Good work is no longer valued and they are frequent management changes.

headline: Good place to get a start.
pros: Office will support you getting licenses and certifications.  Good place to to learn and get some experience.  A lot of the long timers are very nice and helpful in sharing knowledge. Good amount of vacation time for new employees.
cons: Poor compensation. Limited amount of positions available within the wealth management division. Some of the past managers didn't make it easy for individuals to apply for other jobs and move around within the company.  Sometimes it takes forever to get something done because it has to go through so many strings of approval.

headline: Good Job
pros: Decent technology, good work life balance
cons: Culture can be unnecessarily unpleasant

headline: My experience at UBS has been mixed.
pros: UBS has an open architecture, as well as good senior management who is accessible and are good communicators.
cons: It's difficult to advance into other roles at UBS. Advancement opportunities are limited; especially after reorganizing the branch/complex/regional structure. And if you're not on a team, it's a challenge to get good support staff.

headline: Not going well at the moment
pros: relaxed working environment. people can be friendly.. but not always
cons: everything else..low career opportunities. Low upper management guidance

headline: Huge diverse firm
pros: UBS offers some good benefits, tuition reimbursement, free passes to local zoos/museums, 401k matches.  The firm is so large you can always find an area or niche that fits you.  Work life balance depends on the area
cons: Because it is so large it can be challenging to find the right request system for whatever access or tool you are seeking out.  The commute to Weehawken or Jersey City offices is terrible, if you live in NJ it is like driving into NYC

headline: Well run investment bank
pros: Interesting work, good people, reasonably well paid
cons: Long hours, reasonable politically within the group I was in but politically quite tough outside our group

headline: Good opportunity to rotate through jobs every few years
pros: The firm has really good benefits, now that they moved to Windows 7 - it is really easy to get the software to make your job easier.  The people are fun even when working their butts off.  Fun to work with people globally.
cons: There are less promotions available, lots of change currently due to restructuring, many roles are being downsized, outsourced or near shored to TN.  I have found that the managers just expect you to get the work done no matter the hours you need to put in for the day..

headline: Good large stable organisation
pros: global opportunities in a large organisation
cons: large bank and hard to make quick changes

headline: UBS IB
pros: Good people, Senior management is good
cons: Middle management is not so strong

headline: Good company!
pros: Best people, good salary and good colleagues
cons: too many positions level :(

headline: Operation Manager
pros: Good benefits, career advancement, exciting job.
cons: Early hours, fast pace environment.

headline: Behind the times and pretty much controlled from Switzerland.
pros:
Cheap cafeteria.  
Dress as casual as you want. I mean it. Tattoos and piercings and all. 
Dress as liberal you want. Wear over the knee boots, body hugging dresses, slacks ripped on the bottom due to too much length. 
Cheap transportation. Subsidized monthly ferry tickets. Cheap monthly garage parking.
cons:
NonProfessional
Poor pay. Very poor pay. 
No COLA 
All decisions come from Switzerland 
No care of employee retention 
Terrible technology
Uncertainty of job security all the time
Only see management get promoted
More ways to add work and no compensation

headline: Good
pros: Learn a lot that relates to the real world and great company overall to work for
cons: The team I worked for didn't have a healthy work environment.

headline: Great Balance : Professional and Personal Both
pros: happens to be the only one that has decent investment banking work hours, the office culture is pretty good. THe work life balance is good but might get stressed during the deal season.
cons: Its very hard to communicate with your seniors. I think there could be a more appropriate way of getting in help/guidance from your seniors something like a mentorship program.

headline: Bureaucracy, politics and empty promises
pros:
- Decent pay for London: strongly depends on what you do and at what level
- Competitive graduate training programme (with competitive starting salary)
- Good people can be found and some of them have managed to stick around for a while
- Can be a good place to learn and get experience (if you're lucky to be in the right team and get along with colleagues)
cons:
- a lot of bureaucracy and politics as in many large organisations
- plenty of empty promises and unjustified expectations
- not very glorious to be in any other department but Trading, IB or Wealth Management
- work hard, no play place (unless you're in one of the above departments)
- slow to promote (with a few exceptions), mainly based on the promotion waiting list rather than skills

headline: exciting challenging work, very professional management and staff
pros:
Full of interesting and challenging projects, and technology was surprisingly quite up to date for such a large bank.
Very professional staff and atmosphere, even during the phase when I worked there which coincided with a very difficult economic climate, and the fallout from their US crisis.
Opportunities to move laterally into banking if one wishes.
Zurich is a fantastic city in which to live and work.
cons:
not a lot.
I brought a young family, and I suppose integrating within Swiss community was the main difficulty.

headline: Disappointing ... go elsewhere
pros: Willing to give you the opportunity to try different career paths but ...
cons: Culture, technology, compensation are not its forte.

headline: Authorized Officer position
pros: Lot of exposure, interesting people to work with
cons: very hierarchical environment, but overall there are few cons. You do need to be very smart to succeed. There are no shortcuts.

headline: Working for UBS
pros: The office culture is very close-knit and diverse
cons: The internal job movement is rare; most have to leave for growth

headline: Time has changed
pros: Office in London, great people to work with
cons: Everything in the past year

headline: Great for a large FI
pros: Great benefits - support systems and lateral and upward opportunities
cons: Its a huge place and still very swiss - lots of process and rules to follow - not surprisingly given its size but something to consider before working there.

headline: A company that doesn't really care about its employees, but cares more about maintaining its reputation.
pros: Decent work-life balance, relaxed work environment, corporate perks.
cons: Poor pay and bonus, minimal growth opportunities.

headline: wonderful co-workers
pros: Vacation time is good, benefits are good. Some of the people are great.
cons: they do not value their employees. Loyalty is a thing of the past -layers of management is staggering. mistrustful environment, no pay raises for 3 years. Local management is weak, change their minds all of the time

headline: Great place to work
pros: Great atmosphere and team chemistry
cons: Not enough room for growth

headline: IB - pays well as expected but demanding
pros: Pay. Diverse culture. Meritocratic promotion process. Excellent benefits. Excellent location in the city.
cons: Constantly cutting staff. Always looking to cut bottom 10% staff through forced ranking.

headline: CSA
pros:
- Culture
- People (if you're lucky)
- The fast-pace work environment
cons:
- Transparency (or rather, the lack of) within team and management
- Lack of opportunities for lateral career advancement

headline: Amazing place to work in NY
pros: Great training, allows you to work proactively but at the same time if you need support then its there
cons: Lack of organisation at times

headline: Great people, but process is king
pros: All teams I have worked with (IT back office) were full of very good, very nice and helpful people. Many of them were also extremely dedicated, putting in the extra effort to get stuff delivered in the timelines posed by the business. All of my immediate line managers (UBS Directors, so VPs elsewhere) were down-to-earth, pragmatical people. All of them cared for their staff and were trying their hardest to develop them. The whole culture of the company encourages helpful relationships based on trust and respect. However, that is most prevalent between peers and line managers and subordinates, relationships of other kinds are not always so great.
cons:
First of all, the processes in place do not help but hinder development. L1 production support can only copy files and click "restart" buttons (and even then they make mistakes far too often), which means that dev teams get woken up in the middle of the night on a regular basis. Release process is excruciatingly painful, because of the aforementioned production support, as devs can't have access to prod. There is no notion of break glass scenarios, and mentioning it is met with immediate refusal.
Work-life balance is appalling if one wishes to get promoted. And when that happens the compensation is not nearly enough to cover for the sleepless nights.
Business has no idea how IT works and pushes back on any technical changes if they would mean longer delivery times for functional requirements. This leads to tremendous technical debts and poor quality software which is bolted on rather than built. Furthermore, business manages to forget about regulatory requirements and only highlights them at the eleventh hour, causing even more "tactical" solutions to be put in place.

headline: Good times, Bad times...
pros: The pay is fair, and most of the people here are great to work with. In my area we create a fun atmosphere with a good sense of Camaraderie. Despite the hard times, it is still a good place to work.
cons:
There is very little motivation for employees to "go that extra mile" for the firm (there used to be).
I have seen many talented people discarded while lower callibre employees be retained. This is a direct result of the flawed performance review process that enforces a bell-curve ranking system.

headline: Transparent as mud
pros: Great people to work with, across the globe. Incidents get solved; I've experienced real teamwork when it matters.
cons: Promotion and advancement don't seem to be based on merit.  Management announces some "new improvement in process" but then it's back to the same old same old. Knowledge is not valued as much as it used to be (too expensive?).   No training.  No advancement. People in Stamford beginning the exit, now that the jobs are moving to Nashville.  Depressing overall culture.

headline: Large, but unfocused. A shade of its former self.
pros: Multinational, well capitalized, good HR
cons: Promotions, lack of focus, indecisiveness

headline: Used to be great place to be, now im not so sure
pros: World class training resources available to build up relevant skills and knowledge
cons: Alot of cost cutting, headcount approvals are taking too long, people leave and arent replaced, too many reorgs

headline: Lost direction
pros: Global firm - pockets of business that are slowly changing culture.
cons: Poor management and hr policies - little interest in employee development, engagement or retention. High turnover, poor culture.

headline: Good learning opportunities
pros: Good People, Attractive Pay, Job Scope
cons: Long Hours, Stressful at times.

headline: UBS Environement
pros: The culture is amazing, and very open to new things. Many people are eager to teach. It is a Global firm so if you do well and get approved you can travel to different locations.
cons: Sometimes the depending on the job things get repetitive. If you are someone who does not like to network you may not do as well and are less likely to move up.

headline: Director
pros: nothing much to be positive about
cons:
bad management
micro managers
negative culture
no growth

headline: Great introduction to the asset management world
pros: Great company, personal growth and constant learning
cons: Not good training opportunities for interns to turn into full time employees

headline: The company has unrealistic views of where it stands among there larger wall street firms
pros: The typical benefits of working for a larger and well-known organization. Salary is competitive
cons: Very high attrition which is based on long hours and generally poor bonuses. Company sees itself as a top three firm but doesn't provide the resources to get there.  Technology and the outsourcing of tech support is a major detriment to productivity.

headline: Nine months of no work life balance.
pros:
- location (nice office)
- the recruiting process is valued  and employees are willing to give of their time
cons:
- recruiters are expected to work the hours of bankers
- I was at work at least twelve hours a day for six days a week

headline: Just OK
pros: Solid company with a good reputation. Work-life balance is nice.
cons: Lack of training. The only tools you are given are from the disinterested, checked out person who had your job before you did. The only thing anyone cares about is money and climbing the corporate ladder. There are some really slimy people working here. The company does not give cost of living raises, and most employees have not had a salary increase in 5 years. There is a huge lack of morale in the home office, and getting a competent, timly response is impossible. Not to mention the fact that half of the back office is in India now, with more to follow. The technology is a joke too. We are still on some systems from the 90s.

headline: Terrific training program in NJ Lincoln Harbor facility.
pros: Very welcoming in that they hire women and mentor them going forward. A huge help in a male dominated field.
cons: Successful acquisition of enough accounts to cover your salary before it, the salary, goes away.  Family & friends' investment money pretty essential in succeeding here.

headline: Cost reduction is the mantra.
pros:
Work life balance - there are a lot of flexibility and people do make use of it since accountability at UBS is nonexistent. 

People and team collaboration were the best thing at UBS before I left, but this is gone as most of the good people have resigned and majority of the jobs moved to cheaper locations.
cons:
UBS used to be a good company to work for, however nowadays the only focus management has is cost cutting, so management spends most of time figuring out a way to reduce costs and the staff worrying about when their jobs will be moved to a low cost location (i.e. India, Poland, Nashville-TN, etc). The current CFO is a job killer who only thinks about UBS's share price, so he and the rest of the Board can cash in their millions. 

For the past 4+ years the only thing management has focused is cost reduction - benefits are gone, and compensation is now below market, as a result the good people continue resigning in bunches everyday. The moral is so dismal that people really do not care about anything else anymore - they just come in for the pay check until they find another job.

A few years ago the Head of HR came up with a non sense employee performance measurement that destroy whatever was left in terms of moral, but he still employed by UBS so you get an idea of how bad management really is.

Career growth at UBS is a thing of the past. Management keeps saying that the jobs in the future will be more interesting, however the only thing people will be doing in a few years is managing the mess created by the offshoring people who have no clue what they are doing. In order to remediate such low quality work provided by UBS's offshore "partners", UBS has more people in Operational Risk, Internal Audit and bureaucratic functions, than actually people doing work and really advising the business and dealing with regulatory issues. If you want to deal with bureacratics who do not understand anything, UBS may be the place for you. 

In addition, a lot of Senior Management has resigned lately, but instead of promoting people who are competent and have been loyal to the firm for years UBS continues to bring people from outside, so when they tell you that there is a career growth opportunity think twice about it.

The bottom line is Management does not care about anything other than cost reduction, so if you want to spend most of your time dealing with cost/operational plans, and have stomach to say ok to everything they say that's the perfect place for you.

headline: Program Manager/Recruiter
pros: I helped run a great Internship program for Equities traders in Stamford CT and NYC. The workers are friendly and the pay was great. It is an global company so one always had the opportunity to move to other countries. It is a global company.
cons: Due to the sub prime market the global company UBS was laying off due to head count to balance the books.

headline: It ended poorly
pros: strong compant with global presence
cons: too much offshoring causing a loss of talent that is still needed

headline: Revolving Door
pros: You get to meet some great colleagues who are all in the struggle with you.
cons: Compensation lower than other bulge bracket banks, top management left while I was there.

headline: Could be better
pros: If you have the right manager behind you, then your opportunities will be good when it comes to career growth.
cons: Work life balance is very good.  Depending on the department you can work from home when necessary.  Laid back attitude in the office.

headline: Fulfilling
pros: Associate camaraderie, above average benefits
cons: Pay, hours, demanding culture required

headline: Experience
pros: Great work culture and enviroment.
cons: Temps aren't given enough credit.

headline: Great company that takes care of their people
pros: UBS does really consider your career and tries to help you advance.
cons: Sometimes challenging to cooperate with very competitive co-workers.

headline: Great company with mostly high calibre people.
pros: Good career development and training opportunities. Great management efforts on staff engagement. Generally good working culture in terms of team collaboration. Excellent company value.
cons: Too much red tape - too many levels of approval required to drive any change. Laggard in terms of technology capabilities. Too much emphasis on front office, neglecting back office (Operations and IT) resource requirements to adequately support the business. Premium paid for external hires instead of sufficient reward to retain existing talents.

headline: Great work culture.
pros: Compensation. Training, Benefits, People, Career Progression
cons: Bureaucratic management. High turnover of staff

headline: Great Opportunity
pros: Great Benefits in the company
cons: technology needs to be updated

headline: not fullfilling
pros: depending on the individual, you may learn something.  And this is putting it lightly
cons: very difficult people to work with, very aggressive. They only focus on numbers and cost cutting initiatives

headline: Director
pros: flexibility to apply for leave without guilt
cons: just follow and maintain good relations

headline: Ok
pros: Good Bank, More opportunities, Great work Place.
cons: Lot of Low Standard People..

headline: it has been a great experience
pros: the company is very understanding
cons: sometimes the traffic tends to be difficult

headline: Great Company for Advisors
pros: Supportive culture, product agnostic, responsive management, allow you to manage your practice without interference as long as you are operating ethically.
cons: Typical corporate structure. Too much of high priced management that doesn't appear to be adding any value. Too much fiddling with payouts.

headline: Beware! It's a Prison
pros:
- Base Compensation is good is you negotiate well
- Great brand name for clients
- Decent systems (though London platform is relatively antiquated)
cons:
Everyone wants to leave because:
- Bonus, what bonus? Your bonus is to be employed here! People were amazed to hear that the gross bonus pools were up - and the largest in the industry and then everyone receives zero bonuses - clearly the pool is skewed towards the very top.
- Process driven, risk obsessed culture - you will be rewarded for NOT booking business
- AML, Legal & Compliance are literally prison wardens - it is very easy to get into huge trouble here and the punishments are severe - to deter others.
- Opening accounts takes ages (3 - 6 months in London, vs. 4 weeks in Zurich) - many cases clients simply go to Zurich for the business.
- Obsessed with getting new AUM at all costs and then driving clients into low return, expensive discretionary mandates above any other business. In practice we end up with lots of clients who generate no real revenue.
- Culture of victimisation against whistleblowers - speak up, be fired
- Siloed business model - your biggest competitors will be UBS Zurich, UBS Geneva, UBS Singapore...
- Psychos for managers - please see Alec Baldwin's scenes in "Glengarry Glen Ross" - its hard to believe, but this is what our weekly sales meetings are like.

But no one can leave because:
- They hide restrictive (if legally unenforceable) provisions in their employment contracts - e.g. you cannot work for another competitor or potential competitor in the UK for 3 months after resigning! No you will not be paid during this time.
- If you are on an employer sponsored work permit - you only have 2 months to find another sponsored role - which is not possible because of the restrictive covenant.
- Don't bother going to HR - it's a "cloud" service here (I am yet to meet anyone from HR who is not in external recruitment). All HR engagement is via the intranet or by telephone.
- The only way to avoid this is to go through redundancy - so everyone is putting in their worst possible work so they can escape via the prison sewer system!

The general atmosphere is one of fear and resignation - people are literally tricked into the bank and then trapped and resigned to a life of legal slavery. If offered a role here, please watch "Glengarry Glen Ross" or "12 Years a Slave" they perfectly describes the situation within this bank.

headline: Large organisation
pros:
- work life balance 
- great career opportunities
cons:
- too many layers of management
- teams are getting segregated and the company culture is getting weaker as firm expands

headline: UBS
pros: great place to work for anyone.
cons: Not utilizing employees to the fullest potential.

headline: Zero upward mobility in Group Internal Audit
pros: Highly professional staff, decent environment, good relationships with auditees.  Work-life balance can be decent with occasional crunch periods during audits.  Opportunities to work on other audit teams as a lateral move are expanding.
cons: Upward mobility is non-existent and only for a select few (literally) each year.  Less skilled Executive Directors are hired frequently while more capable Directors can't get promoted getting one excuse after another at review time while the carrot and stick is held out to try and motivate them for another year.  Bonuses are minimal, base pay is stagnant.  Management thinks that leavers are a natural phenomenon and the root cause is meaningless unless the attrition rate goes above an average threshold.

headline: Associate Director
pros: The company encourages personal development and provided many opportunities to the juniors, which is great.
cons: Too many deal flows with different qualities, which lacks senior attention in some

headline: Mixed Experience
pros:
-Very smart group of people
-Highly professional environment
-Strong industry reputation, much better outside the U.S.
cons:
-Highly bureaucratic. Difficult to get things done
-Overly risk averse
-Good intentions on wanting to fix things, but little in the way of follow through to actually complete the fixes

headline: Very cool place to work.
pros: Great environment, good people and you learn a lot
cons: long hours, bankers that are not always in the best mood.

headline: Great learning experience
pros: Good level of pay, relatively easy to transfer across departments and lots of opportunities to develop your career. Pretty good perks like free banking and long paid maternity leave
cons: 42 hr week is standard working hours, promotions are often down to your ability to network more so than performance. They dont treat people well when outsourcing functions

headline: My first job - Fairly neutral
pros: Strong in industry. has some good people.
cons: Big bank, management is messy

headline: It used to be so much more
pros: Vacation is good.  Benefits are competitive.
cons: The bank has lost its identity.  Has become second-tier.

headline: Just a Job - not a career here at UBS
pros: Lax, managers dont really care as they can not justify high standards.
cons: Very political, no opportunities to advance - especially the case for minorities

headline: Great Experience
pros: Strong company culture and very hardworking people. Great deal flow but some struggles during the financial crisis. I really enjoyed my time working here.
cons: Strong leadership group and ample outreach opportunities. More contact with senior people would be helpful for junior employees at the firm.

headline: When it was Swiss Bank, was the best place to work.
pros: Large corporate environment with good benefits, good workers and culture. Pay was on par.
cons: Lack of clear corporate direction, lack of advancement opportunities poor, bank declining, to many managers and far too much red tape. Long working hours/days. Everyone always worried about their position being eliminated all the time.

headline: Operational Risk
pros: Friendly environment, have various talent development programs at different level
cons: Continue to restructure within the organization, cost cutting, might loose good talents when market is picking up especially for med/low level employee

headline: Mixed
pros: The company makes a strong investment in the HR function
cons: HR can be somewhat bureaucratic and more tactical

headline: Investment bank completely fell apart over the 2 years I worked there
pros: Great team when I started but most senior bankers left during the recession
cons: Work-life balance was consistent with other banks but pay was low

headline: So so
pros: Global bank with presence around world
cons: Limited career growth opportunities present

headline: almost a year within Legal department
pros: work-life balance; office culture; staff education
cons:
career growth
unfair compensation within the company at the same rank in different departments

headline: Started at ubs right out of college and stayed for 6.5 years
pros:
beer cart (even though it was cut down)
good people
work/life balance
good benefits
cons:
high turnover
poor morale
at the time i thought systems were bad (now at other banks i say they're middle of the road)

headline: UBS
