pros: the people are  truly awesome
cons: Salaries for support  staff should be higher

headline: Horrible
pros: Decent insurance. Short commute though
cons: Only care about bottom line

headline: Not the company it was
pros:
Generally a meritocratic, collegiate culture.
Comp is competitive - i.e. not the highest, but not the main reason someone would leave. 
Good flex benefits (UK), and general acceptance of informal flexible working - e.g. working from home one day a week plus if boiler needs repairing, etc
Aggressive business strategy, plus decent redundancy scheme for functions being downsized. 
New HQ building coming on-line in London / Broadgate.
cons:
Can be very hard to get a decision that sticks - feels like any decision can be reopened at any point.

IB has had lots of CEOs and strategies over past decade, which has led to lots of disjointed decision making, and hire/fire cycles. e.g. UBS has entered and exited commodities three times.

Lots of operational incidents over past years has impacted reputation of the firm (IB and wealth management).

headline: I have worked with UBS China for 2 years
pros: There are smart people in the firm. Mandatory 2 week leave. Impressive philanthropy programs.
cons: Poor company culture. No synergy, no cooperation. Lack of sustainable corporate strategy.

headline: Good market exposure in equities but career progression limited
pros: Despite the knocks to its brand, UBS remains a global force in equities. A role at UBS can give broad exposure to the market.
cons: The opportunity set for career progression has diminished as the firm shrinks.  There have been very few promotions in recent years and the upper ranks have been swelled by former colleagues of the incoming management team.  Uncertainty on the investment bank's direction will not clear, so morale is poor.

headline: Excellent company, great work/life balance
pros: The team I work with is superb. Great people, and the environment here is inclusive, tolerant, and community-centric. The management has an open door policy that allows for questions and concerns to be brought up without fear of reprisal. Lots of community initiatives, and a general feeling that the company cares about the welfare of its employees.
cons: Career growth isn't a strong suit. Raises and reviews can take a while to occur, and it's not easy to determine a path toward getting a promotion.

headline: great place to work if management can get its directtion straight!
pros: Bright, smart people make the place challenging
cons: Politics get in the way of everything!

headline: big name but nothing special
pros: ...........not a lot of pros in UBS London, it is below average.
cons: ......................a lot of bureaucracy and difficult to work because of internal processes.

headline: Decent company if you don't aim high
pros:
Work-life balance
Nice office space
Respectful management
cons:
Salary
Growth opportunities 
Silo work environment

headline: Lack confidence in management
pros: Good work/life balance, good people, firm is well-positioned for success.
cons: Management doesn't communicate clear direction and strategy for future, and refuses to invest in people, technology and lines of business.

headline: There is not much room for growth but allowed me to utilize my skills.
pros: The ability to utilize all of my skills and knowledge about various computer programs. Also the pay rate & raises were decent.
cons: There was not much room for growth within the business

headline: Great staff and company to work for!
pros: The people are very friendly, are extremely driven, and the company provides great training.
cons: There are many layoffs in the company if you are not at senior or vp level.

headline: Global firm that now has a clear message and focus delivered by managed and being executed on the ground level.
pros: Amazing culture of people, clear focus, clean balance sheet, well-defined strategy, great momentum.  The wealth management franchise is best in class which the investment bank is able to leverage.  Additionally, the investment bank is critical to the success of the Wealth Management division so the relationship is symbiotic.
cons: Swiss capital requirements are a challenge, still has some catching-up to do to be best in class in many areas.

headline: Not a bad first step
pros:
Great product support
Talented people on the Exchange floors to work with
Great benefits
cons:
Lack of training resources
Disconnect from HQ

headline: Professional, friendly and supportive
pros: Good benefits, nice people. They support women, LGBT, are cultured and although a large company feels very small and close knit.
cons: Not a lot of room for growth unless you are wiling to move where the opportunities are.

headline: Great learning experience
pros:
- good learning experience
- skilled and experienced colleagues
- good exposure to life deals
- fun work environment
- european firm and therefore a good match for everone who is not looking for american working cultures/values
cons:
- long working hours and intense work environment
- not GS or MS, hence not providing same experience
- culture suffered from recent redundancy rounds (though this might apply to others as well)

headline: Great wealth management but far less impressive investment bank and asset management
pros: Strong wealth management franchise, great brand name, less than impressive investment bank.
cons: Long working hours and low bonuses but compensated by higher base. Opportunities for internal mobility limited unless you know the hiring manager personally.

headline: Interesting position reviewing accounts for suitability purposes
pros:
Lots of training available
Friendly staff and can ask any one questions
Conduct different reviews covering many areas
Open door policy
If you get your work done on time and it is quality, you will succeed
cons:
Not easy to move up the food chain
Need fresh ideas to create different reviews
Time off is sufficient
Bonuses will not be the best out there

headline: Positive
pros:
Working with like minded driven, motivated colleagues
Collaborative environment
Great team ethos
Supportive team and managers
cons:
Flat structure 
Pay
Career development opportunities
Cumbersome systems can slow down processes

headline: Friendly but directionless
pros:
Very friendly people.
A lot of very smart people with good ideas.
Ancient tech.
cons:
No good direction, always changing course so nothing gets done.
Lots of good ideas die in black holes.
Lots of rubbish work to do, nothing very exciting.

headline: Great Bank but average Management
pros: Great Bank to work with
cons: Below Par Management and very Political environment

headline: My experience at UBS was both good and bad, depending on the situation
pros: Working in a complex environment allowed a bit more freedom to make decisions without having to go through the home office
cons: There was trickle down effect through layers of middle management with everyone wanting to "cover" themselves and shift the blame/responsibility down to the next level. Very poor process for annual evaluations with certain percentages of people being forced to be slotted into certain review levels.

headline: Great company to work for!
pros: Strong financials and growth over the last few years. Management is a key to the turn around for Wealth Management.
cons: None at the location I was in, in MI. Management and the teams were all great and very supportive.

headline: Fantastic company to work for.
pros: The culture and atmosphere are unique to the industry. Very welcoming. With the somewhat resent  turn-over in upper management, the company (and stock price) have been on the rise. UBS is back to being a "cool" firm to work for.
cons: None witnessed thus far in Wealth Management. However, the IB side is not what it used to be. BUT, that is all part of Ermotti and McCann's grand plan.

headline: FA Assistant
pros: very nice culture and fast pace
cons: lots of work to do everyday

headline: Good firm, in this environment very challenging
pros: Solid Swiss bank,  Senior management is focused on advancing the firm in a very difficult environment.  Core culture is positive, Good people,  good benefits as well as a nice place to work.
cons: Cost cutting in recent years has been brutal,  the senior management team has a very positive vision as to where the firm will be and are driving the firm in that direction, but the just lower management do not give clear direction to follow that vision.  The expectations of people are very high,  with very long working hours and no compensation to back the work expectations.  Many people have left due to the low compensation.  Overall a good place to work, once the bank gets through this rough period, it should get better, but the firm has been very cheap in that last 5 years

headline: Great company, professional culture, and good people
pros: First off, the people are a true pleasure to work with and very friendly. It is more about comradery and support and less about competitiveness. There is a very professional culture at UBS and everyone is treated with due respect. Everyone is very open to new ideas, but implementation often is hard to do. Overall, it's a great environment and a good experience.
cons: There is a lack of mobility for career advancement in the Private Wealth Management Division. No formal training program so it was more learn as you go and hope you don't make a grave mistake. Working with other departments is challenging as communication broke down quickly and resolutions are not timely.

headline: Good company, but too big and bureaucratic
pros: Potential to participate in relevant projects in big companies
cons: Too much internal focus, bureaucratic

headline: Good anyway
pros: People are nice, although professionals are quite senior they still treat me very well with friendly environment and not a special feeling at all.
cons: It depends on teams, if you get involved in a team where bosses like to talk to girls while you are just a man then you are just not lucky.

headline: Fun and driven group, but became less desirable due to attrition, layoffs and entrenched processes
pros: As a large and established company, there was a strong effort to provide opportunities for training, mobility, promotion etc. It was slightly messy, but the effort was there. Management were encouraged to mentor juniors as part of their job role. Benefits, compensation, PTO etc all very strong.
cons: Working here became a lot less fun after the Financial crash. Rolling layoffs, marginalization of software teams - offshoring and relocating teams out of the city took a toll on the desirability of UBS as a place to work.

headline: Great place to start your career in
pros: Great experience and loads of learning opportunities.
cons: Very bureaucratic, lower than industry average pay, not a lot of growth opportunities (at least in my case)

headline: Overall good, but not a place to stay long-term
pros: The vacation policy and benefits are some of the best I've seen. People in the sales and product organizations are no nonsense, straight shooters who are also very friendly. The have a respected brand name and the most productive Advisors on the street.
cons: The home office has become a politically-driven, bureaucratic mess. Managers are required to force-rank employees by titles even though functional roles may be completely different. This causes a lot of infighting as people vie for an ever dwindling piece of the bonus pie. They are also looking to define a culture in an industry where competitors already have clearly established cultures.

headline: New Financial Advisor/Back to School
pros: The compensation for a new financial advisor (trainee) is good. You basically get paid a salary to study. The health benefits are amazing, as well as the ability to manage your own investments. The particular office I was in had a great atmosphere, very team-oriented, nice people, and daily perks.
cons: As a new financial advisor (trainee), you are put in the Unregistered UBS Corporate Training program. You have 2 remote calls per week with the corporate office, and everyone is so negative. They talk down to you, and you're basically an adult in grade school (getting picked on, called out in front of everyone, threatened that they'll talk to your manager if you don't do an assignment right). They are basically re-inventing the wheel with these sales tactics. The first 7 weeks are devoted to studying for the Series 7. You are given a 24 chapter book and a set of practice tests, put in a corner, and told to study. No one really pays attention to you - you do not exist until you pass that test. I was told on multiple occasions that what you learn for the 7 has nothing to do with what your real job consists of. However, no one mentored me to actually get a feel of what I'd be doing. I thought I was completely prepared for the exam, but unfortunately, I did not pass. In that case, corporate is required to let you go.

headline: One step forward, Three steps back.
pros: I will say that the team I worked with was outstanding, and that my direct management was outstanding, given the financial crisis and other outside pressures. I am still close friends with members of that team today.
cons:
Politics at UBS, at least from the IT side of the house, are rampant. From year end evaluations and promotions to vendor selections, decisions took too long and were always under political scrutiny.

Also, its takes forever for anything to get done. The place is drowning in process. If you wanted anything to get done, you were better off doing it yourself.  That in turn created a considerable amount of frustration.

headline: What you need to know!
pros: Make sure you get into the right team where the manager is respected and the team is welcoming and positive. UBS is known to have cultural issues across generations, gender and internal ranking system.
cons:
You are expected to work long hours "that's what you sign up for", take meeting calls at all hours and then be docked annual leave for medical appointments. If you are studying or have evening lectures, managers will make it difficullt for you.
There have been wage freezes across UBS for several years, cheaper employees are brought across from support teams without pay increases. They churn through interns to save costs (higher bonuses for management).

headline: Ups and Downs
pros: Wealth Management is on the rise
cons: Form over substance sometimes and that just means somone

headline: Gone through tough times, but strong core
pros: I love my team; people are smart but down-to-earth (benefit of not being at a GS/MS/JPM), and with several new managers I'm looking forward to seeing positive changes and a rebound in numbers
cons: 2009 was a rough year - it's still haunting us, but I think only time can change that

headline: I worked in several different areas of corporate and marketing communications.
pros: I had a long, fulfilling career at UBS (and the former PaineWebber) and was consistently promoted and given progressively more responsibilities for most of my tenure there.
cons: A management change in 2009 brought in an executive team from Merrill Lynch. After that, the culture shifted to recruiting from outside, particularly Merrill alums, instead of promoting from within.

headline: general info
pros: quite neutral, stable env less turn over
cons: too big to change which made alll stuck

headline: top
pros: very high standards, professional, willing to improve
cons: Work a lot, very high pressure, fix salary

headline: Average
pros: low pressure, nice people, collegial, good benefits
cons: low pay, political work environment, attracts low quality people given low compensation

headline: it was years ago, but an excellent place to work -- prior merger
pros: great company, great experience, known in the industry; great training program
cons: conneticut was too far to travel

headline: An incredible place to work.
pros: The pay and the opportunities. Travel is wonderful and the benefits are great. Many great professionals to work around.
cons: UBS has a tough work environment. Many things going on at once.

headline: analyst
pros: close to my house save on gas and short commute
cons: layoffs layoffs layoff s outsourcing to TN

headline: Incredibly engaging and challenging
pros: Top tier talent, lots of resources
cons: Global company- very structured so it is difficult to advance quickly

headline: What's wrong with UBS
pros: Has global reach for those that want their money outside the US.Management is totally focused on ROA.Management seems to be competent.
cons: Every department seems to have their own profit center relative to year end bonuses for management.Overly concerned about short term goals(monthly) vs yearly.

headline: Very positive work env
pros: Good work culture in the team
cons: Work load is sometimes high

headline: Only Money counts, not People
pros: this bank described itself as the "largest and best wealth management firm", and indeed it is was and remains a very large and complex organisation with a very hard working culture, which survived the 2008 crisis as a real Titanic.
cons: Reality is; nearly all senior managers are in it for making as much money as possible, mostly for themselves, second for the firm, and at the very bottom for their clients. Employees and clients are "squeezed like lemons" in a military style of operation, with disregard for a healthy work/life balance or social norms.

headline: Good comp, Great people, Distant management
pros: People are really nice, very smart and tend to be some of the professional elite you would like to work with.  International opportunities for sure.
cons: The promotion, raise and bonus system is a total sham.  It's painful and it sucks, UBS needs to get on the same page as the rest of the western world when it comes to taking care of their employees.

headline: Good company, bad timing
pros: Great coworkers. The people are very meticulous, which in my experience helped to cultivate good habits. Employment with the company grants you access to a wide variety of financial resources and software. Company-wide macro and micro analyses are available for your perusal
cons: The hours can be long and management has very high standards for job performance. Professional development is more sales-oriented and less about increasing knowledge.  Can be tough to stand out in such a large organization, need to consistently go above-and-beyond in order to move forward. When I left the organization, they were in the process of laying off a sizable portion of their workforce

headline: Great company
pros:
Good welfare
Great for working mums
cons: High expectations from management on sales targets

headline: Opportunity if you can reinvent yourself
pros: Good work life balance, opportunity to work remotely as long as you do your work, pay is improving, generally good people.  Worst days are behind UBS.
cons: Turns a blind eye to blatant slackers which affects morale

headline: This is a really good company to work for. The company Invests in people development and looks after its people.
pros: Since this company's offices are located in several countries, it offers plenty of opportunities for global mobility and career development.
cons: Due to the nature of the organisation, some times decision making tends to take really long.

headline: Intern
pros:
+ Very kind people
+ Able to learn a lot
cons: - As an intern you are treated by some people as a weight for the company, not as an asset.

headline: Cost cutting
pros: Good cafeteria.... That about sums it up
cons: Cost cutting and temps everywhere. Moving tons of jobs to Nashville

headline: Good Workplace
pros:
Work Place is pretty sweet and nice
Salary is reasonable
Fringe benefits are good

Head
cons:
seen as non competitive by it's rivals

Big organisation

headline: Was a great place to work before the GFC
pros: Pleasure to work with so many highly talented individuals
cons:
Management and leadership issues remain unresolved.
Diminished importance of investment banking within UBS and relatively weak performance at the Tokyo office resulted in headcount reduction which made it even harder to compete.

headline: Very good at the start and as time goes on, still ok, but frustration w/ the inability of senior mgt to get firm forward
pros: Global company w/ heavy influence from parent, mother Switzerland!  Current management seems more stable, but still trying to remove the sins from the past.
cons:
Current new hires brought in at market while loyal hard workers get little increases and bonus flat to continued reductions as Company tries to fund increased capital ratios.  They will have a real issue w/in 2 years if they don't fix compensation overall as the seasoned professionals who have carried the load will leave to other companies willing to pay for their experience and skill set.

The whole corporate service concept is at least 50% BS and adds additional costs, removes accountability, and confuses internal people.  While they are some benefits to corporate services (centralization of certain services, legal, HR, finance, etc), the Firm's execution of this function has been poor at best.

headline: Good place to work for if you want to work for a big bank
pros:
Good work-life balance.
Good salaries.
Good colleagues.
Good support from the bank.
Good work environment.
Good place to learn.
cons: Too much bureaucracy and politics (especially a lot of politics).

headline: AML Analyst
pros: Good salary started for interns
cons: Not much advancement opportunities internally

headline: O.k. Company
pros: Open communication with management; helpful coworkers. Open door policy.
cons: Turnover is very high, it seemed like people were leaving every month.

headline: Poorly managed company
pros: A solutions/partnership based approach to client needs makes this an interesting place to work.  It's not just about the product offerings, but overall client customized solutions.  There are hard working individuals at the firm.  Nice offices and good work life balance.
cons: The pay is not competitive and the product offerings are seen as non-competitive compared to other firms. The firm reputation has taken a big hit over the years.  Management has changed over the past few years and is out of touch with the employees, leading to a poorly run organization.

headline: Management does not care
pros: Nice benefits and gym in building.
cons: Little by little , they started to cut the benefits

headline: UBS is Great
pros: Excellent people and smart, great environment
cons: I don't have much to say negative about UBS

headline: Great Internship
pros: My boss, an executive at the company, was very nice and flexible. He made the hours very easy on me. He also took a couple hours everyday to show me calculations and how to  use relevant computer programs for wealth management and mutual fund projections. I felt appreciated and I was rewarded for my accomplishments.
cons: It would have been nice if there was more of an organized plan of interns at the start of the summer instead of it being mostly improvised.

headline: Intern
pros: Friendly Environment. Even though the financial advisers are very determined, the environment is usually relaxed. Very professional environment, and very good work/life balance
cons: Hard to move up in financial management and small teams. Many small insignificant tasks that interns need to complete

headline: Change is underway
pros: New mgmt, new opportunities, good people
cons: Culture shift necessary, needs to be more business application focused and less IT ( for IT ) focused.

headline: Good experience for my resume but culture made it not worth it.
pros:
- Learned a lot with smart people
- Paid analysts well, but not mid-level employees
cons:
- Headquarters does not seem committed to investment banking in US
- The general attitude for the future of the bank is bleak. Everyone has left from my group

headline: Bad
pros: None..Nothing good about this place.
cons: Don't work here.. waste of time..

headline: No communication from managers on status of job
pros: Good company - most bosses and groups are good.   Busy.
cons: Managers within many departments are totally unhappy and never let employees know status of completed jobs,  never have a good word to say - always what not to do and not what shoulod/could be done.

headline: Be positive go to work on time and make sure to drink lots of coffee. very long days but the money pays. Be sure to
pros: Gotta love the compensation; the atmosphere; and the perks you get daily aren't terrible either. its a great job but demanding
cons: Its very demanding. very long days and no one gives a #$#! about what you have to do or how much time. get it done regardless of how little sleep you get attitude

headline: Bringing Switzerland to the US
pros: There are great people at the company, and the benefits are competitive. The work is challenging, and there is investment in employees.
cons: Where this company struggles is in trying to operate as a Swiss bank in the US. The cultural differences create a barrier and get in the way of operations. Your boss in the US may well be the CEO or the COO, but big decisions cannot ultimately be made by them - there is always a more senior boss in Switzerland who has final say, without a real understanding of the needs in the US.

headline: Financial Advisor Trainee
pros: Good, structured training program on products and services.
cons: The company organization is too hierarchal in structure.

headline: Good learning exp
pros: good brand name, get a feel for working in a global investment bank.
cons: people not driven, dedicated enough.

headline: Progressive and effective ability to bring innovation to achieve greater good
pros: growth, culture, high energy fast, ability to bring new ideas to table
cons: investment banking industry is changing became a very uncertain negative enviorment

headline: Professionally its been progressive every year but a difficult 5 years mean it is significantly behind other banks
pros: Work environment and Work life balance are very good.
cons: Compensation and recognition have been tough to get through

headline: Great work life, poor social.
pros: Great exposure. Opportunities to learn.
cons: Poor balance of work/social life.

headline: UBS wealth management is about sales and not investments
pros: The people are very nice and the environment is collegial.  Management does an excellent job bringing good people into the organization.
cons: The main financial planning tool is the Financial Goal Analysis sales tool.  This tools is misleading as the tool assumes one only loses money twice in a lifetime.  Advisors also omit the sales charges.

headline: Great entry-level position into financial services
pros: Great work-life balance and friendly employees. Job is project orientated and you gain a ton of differentiated experience.
cons: After being at UBS for two years I have had great experiences. The only thing I will say is that some of the work can become a little redundant.

headline: Great
pros: Great company to work for
cons: Must consider the financials to be competitive

headline: Nice place to work if you don't care about getting ahead.
pros: Pockets of strength include the managed municipal bond team and alternatives (hedge funds) products. Some strength in asset allocation solutions, too. Good work/life balance. Good location. Nice office space.
cons: Bonus pay is not competitive with other asset managers. The US asset management business is losing assets and revenues. Prospects for the next few years appear to be limited without some type of catalyst.

headline: Great culture and work ethic. There are a lot of opportunities for those who are willing to work and take the long view.
pros:
- UBS culture (this is not GS!)
- Opportunities for those who are willing to step up
- Everyone is encouraged to challenge
- For the most part, hard work and results are appreciated
cons:
- Facilities in London are poor although this should change with the new building
- Too many comfort zone employees who get away with coasting from one year to the next (and on the surface appear to contribute little to the business)

headline: Good company
pros: good training provided - very diversed company - multicultural
cons: very structured company - too struct

headline: Great experience with lots of useful training.
pros: Lots of useful training and good people there.
cons: Management changes frequently and culture changed in the past 3 years.

headline: Overworked and underappreciated.
pros: Talented, hard-working creative colleagues abound.
cons: Too many layers. Strategic folks oversee and micromanage the creative output.

headline: I had a very nice working experience in UBS
pros: enjoyed working with really smart people in the industry
cons: Don't think e experienced anything negative while I was there.

headline: supportive colleagues
pros: good work-life balance, well cooperative colleagues
cons: IT systems limitations and infrastructure

headline: It gave me a wonderful opportunity for learning and growth
pros: Very good company to work. Very good work life balance. Best job if you are married and needs to concentrate more on personal life.
cons: Difficult to adapt ourselves to the other company's environment

headline: Great learning platform for a junior banker
pros: lean teams = high visibility and exposure; collaborative work environment, especially at the junior level, connection to wealth management can help,
cons: typical cons associated with banking (work hours, quality of life ,etc...), bonus compensation historically below street (may have changed since departure),

headline: Financial Advisor
pros: Independence and autonomy.  Really running your own business.
cons: No training.  Little support.  Old boys club.  Only for the really rich mentality.  Common, middle class America isn't worth pursuing.  Antiquated software.  Terrible home office support.

headline: Good
pros: I recently started with UBS, and so far my experience has been better than any other company I’ve entered. My team took the time to onboard and train me,
cons: The firm is looking for the best and brightest, so the recruiting process is selective.

headline: Legal Associate
pros: Great people; bright attorneys; good corporate environment/culture
cons: Poor mentorship; very unstable environment (constant lay offs)

headline: UBS is a good place to work if you are a new employee, but not so much for a long term employee.
pros: Good benefits, but they are being scaled back.
cons: Bad work life balance, decreasing compensation levels.

headline: Perfect working envirnment, nice team with kind hearted supervisors. A perfect place to grow and learn.
pros: Competitive Salary benchamarked to the local level, full learning access to all research material, real life market event witness opportunity. And by the way, they offered me a on-Job Master named Master in Professional Developement, quite a helpful tool for the trainee to learn the ropes at the begining.
cons: Avg. more than 11hours/day in the office if no marketing assignment applied. But it's an industry reality, like the spiderman's quote, more power, more responsability.

headline: Senior Software Developer
pros: Good salary, highly technical content.  The systems involved are complex and require lots of care since there's many touch points between systems.
cons: Projects in banking are not the most exciting.

headline: Workaholic
pros: Renumeration, perks, feel important, fun
cons: High pressured, cuthroat, unfriendly, stressful

headline: Good, but rocky
pros: Most rewarding (comp, recognition, management programs) job I have ever had.
cons: Operations has gone through huge evolution and is a shell of what it once was.

headline: Salaries
pros: trying to come back on top
cons: 1 person does 10 peoples jobs

headline: Great place to work - choose your own involvement. Moving back into the light....
pros: Choose your own involvement. If you are willing to work hard & willing/want to contribute in other initiatives outside of your area then the sky's the limit. Friendly and open place for networking and building your career without needing to move firms, while avoiding become stale or institutionalised. Open to new technologies and innovation with a growing approach to true business/IT collaboration culminating in impressive results.
cons: Given the recent shifting landscape/regulation may lead to insecurity or opportunity, depending on your viewpoint. Recent continual management changes below GMD level has made the environment a large shifting landscape.

headline: U'll Be Sorry
pros: BIG,Old ,Fancy Commercials, nice logo
cons: Beaurocratic, Dishonest, Tarnished, Large setllements and fines are business as usual, Corporate shareholders interests over clients interests are paramount. A company that puts the burden and resosibility on its workforce rather than the desicion makers who are the ones truly liable.

headline: working as an offshore operation manger, so probably might not that accurate as onshore staff
pros: big inverstment bank, accumulate ED knowledge as well as workflow
cons: run into bottleneck after working for 5 years

headline: Good place to work at
pros:
- excellent organization & good atmosphere 
- the company happy to support pursuit of professional certificates
- great work/life balance; fully paid overtime
- although it is middle/back office it is still one of the best options you have in Krakow
cons: - quality of managers differs significantly, suggest you do some research on your potential boss before accepting an offer

headline: Good starting point
pros: The work/life balance is good.  Needing to stay late is not frequent, and only happens when serious issues arise.  People are also generally allowed to work from home/remote once or twice a week or as agreed on with their manager.  Coworkers are generally easy to get along with
cons: Too much senior management changes.  No stability, commitment.  Low salary.

headline: Challenging and Rewarding
pros: Great company overall.  Great benefits.
cons: In some departments: an organizational nightmare.  Too many layers.

headline: Positive culture
pros: Professional and collaborative environment, great IT platforms
cons: None except occasional late nights

headline: good people - bad managers
pros: good people to work with
cons: bad managers - don't know there own business

headline: Not a good time for the company
pros: Employees were given a lot of vacation and the benefits were good. The cafeteria was also affordable and good. For my particular role, the work/life balance was good. The company is also very conveniently located for people who take the train (compared to other businesses in Stamford).
cons: The culture at UBS is very weak. The employees don't really feel any pride that they work there. There also is a constant fear of downsizing. Even before all of the decisions to downsize, the culture was sort of cold in the sense that people eat at their desks and aren't the most open. I enjoyed my colleagues, but compared to other places I had worked, it just felt like people here weren't as keen to get to know eachother.

headline: Good Companyt
pros: Some very skilled and helpfull people
cons: No sense of accomplishment given,  always a threat of job loss

headline: Nice working environment
pros:
- warm and supportive working environment
- good work life balance 
- flat structure
- good employee benefits 
- meritocratic
- extremely multicultural
cons: - few overseas opportunities unless you are hired from a high cost location è.g. Europe

headline: low morale and no reward for hard work
pros: you will work with smart people, and depnding on your manager location can be flexible. formal and informal classes provide a chance to learn new and enhance old skill sets, and networks bring opportinities to meet others in all ranks.
cons: there is a large lack of value for talent, with the general tone saying "work hard and you will not be rewarded". There is a lack of trust within the Firm, and minimal promotions each year, even at the lower levels.

headline: Typical Financial Advisor experience
pros: UBS is a trusted name among wealthy individuals and you get access to some exclusive investment opportunities (Apollo, Blackstone, etc.) for your clients due to UBS's size.
cons: At the end of the day if you can't bring in new assets then you're out the door.

headline: a great internship to start my career.
pros: worked full time, I was thrown into the fire and learned everything from operation and advising
cons: the hourly wage was low, but I understand why it is so low.

headline: Perfect
pros: From the attached resume, please see all pertinent information needed
cons: Nothing to complain about - Staffs I came in contact with are very proffesional

headline: Ups and downs
pros: UBS still pays ok salaries. Still one of the major players in the financial industry. A truely global company that gives you a lot of cultural exposure.
cons: Reputational issues after the financial crisis. UBS was involved in all major fraud cases like LIBOR or FX manipulation and does not seem to have their operational risks under control.

headline: A great strategy to win business and intelligent people to execute it.
pros:
- You are afforded responsibility based on your ability to handle it, not on your age or tenure
- You are supported with training and mentorship to succeed
- You are compensated for performance
cons:
- It may not be clear to you what is required, you have to be a self-starter
- There is a lot of turnover and if this happens in your team (especially if it's with your managers), it can make it difficult to achieve long-term success

headline: A rollercoaster ride over 10 years, but things are not what they used to be.
pros: UBS has a truly global organisation, which reduces internal fights and makes it easier to get new initiatives off the ground. The benefits system is good. Work-life balance is pretty reasonable for an investment bank: there is no long-hours culture for example.
cons: UBS seems to be retreating into its shell following bad performance over the last recession. Mangement commitment to investment banking is questionable, and many business areas have been shut down or de-scoped. Staff are under continual pressure to justify their positions and re-organisations are frequent.

headline: UBS
pros: People are generally nice to work with
cons: Doesn't pay that well - counterparts in NJ make double what they are paid in TN

headline: Intern at Equity Research team
pros:
good learning environment to fresh new beginner in finance 
nice city(food, weather, CPI)
deep insight to a company and a sector
cons:
long working hours, and you need to be a early bird
quite compared with other teams. 
it`s slow to be promoted

headline: Intern
pros: Great people and products, well managed
cons: Projects are sparse and lack of mobility

headline: Product Management
pros: there was decent career mobility
cons: the never ending reductions in force

headline: Large company with large variety of jobs
pros: Easy to find new career opportunities
cons: Can become frustrating as you are just one small piece in the puzzle

headline: Bureaucratic, incompetent management
pros: There were many good people at the junior and lower senior levels, but most of them would leave for better employers, leaving the bottom decile performers at the firm
cons: Continual testing to memorize useless trivia about the company, management was incompetent at their work and at managing people, was often unclear how they became employed

headline: A labyrinth of a place to work.
pros: Some good people, although most of the best have left.  The people that remain would survive a nuclear blast - they are not going anywhere and likely could not even if they wanted to.
cons: Performance, stock, Swiss oversight, but other than that...  There are no real career paths on the institutional side at UBS.

headline: Great learning experience that has added to the development of my career.
pros: One of the largest financial services firms. Invaluable experience
cons: The investment bank is downsizing, leaving fewer opportunities there.

headline: we will not rest
pros: strong franchise in equity derivatives
cons: structure too hierarchical, where only senior people are decently paid

headline: Good place to start, but not much room for advancement.
pros: Great people. Strong employee moral and culture.
cons: No advancement. There is little direction given by upper management and too much middle management.

headline: A Revolving door , and a place filled with unhappy people
pros: similar to other big banks, but can't find anything worth mentioning
cons: surprisingly high turnover rate, no morale and no team work at all.  People tend to attack each other instead of help each other at work. There are changes from senior management every week - they seem always able to justify the reason for changing A to B then back to A again.

headline: Not the best investment bank
pros:
Career opportunities
Smart coworkers
Great cooperation across teams
cons:
Poor work life balance
Poor compensation
Promises not kept

headline: Very collaborative culture
pros: Everyone works together effectively and understands eachother's roles - and if not, there is the opportunity to learn
cons: Some areas of floors are pretty enclosed, which really reduces natural lighting

headline: Software engineer
pros: Good pay and good time
cons: Not quite teamworking and tech

headline: Very positive
pros: very extensive list of internal training, benefits
cons: not easy to get promoted

headline: Good
pros: Mobility is high, diversity and fun-loving culture
cons: Long hours, many layers of hierarchy

headline: A decade of feeling hopeful for the future but never quite sure of the direction.
pros: Many good people at one time, though a good portion of the good ones seem to have left for stronger firms.
cons: Stability of firm, management commitment to firm direction, seems to change for change sake not productive reasons.

headline: Investment Banking Analyst
pros: Larger "bulge bracket" investment bank
cons:
- Poor work culture 
- Disrespect for employees 
- No work life balance 
- Below street bonuses 
- Instability of the job (no more west coast banking)

headline: Best workplace ever
pros: Benefits, Team work, people, opportunities, great cooperation with onshore partners,
cons: Polish Management, communication in polish hub, constant changes,

headline: client service associate
pros: great management, helpful colleagues, friendly work environment
cons: old computer systems, everyone is willing to help

headline: Good working environment
pros: Good employer, flexible, supportive of employees
cons: Nothing really bad to say about UBS.

headline: Technology is lacking and IT management is stalled.
pros: Management is very flexible with Life, work, balance issues.
cons: No IT vision. Trapped in aged IT processes and disparate systems. No application standardization. OS platform is standardized to a fault with little or no flexibility for specific business unit challenges. PMM process has zero correlation to promotions or compensation. IT priorities change along with Upper management changes which are often. New management has little time to implement any vision as a re-org happens typically every 6-8 months. New technologies when implemented are rarely communicated. Offshoring usually eliminates younger technical staff in favor of keeping older upper management. Many layers of management some with no direct reports. Issues usually prompt a deluge of conference calls with focus on finger pointing and "witch hunts" creating a culture of "not my job" thinking.

headline: UBS is an average place to work. Low on salary, but also not a crazy amount of hours or pressure either.
pros: Good work-life balance at UBS
cons: Low salary, and laughable bonuses (if any)

headline: No complaints. I worked for UBS for 38 years. A great company to work for in my opinion.
pros: Interesting work assignments, opportunities to travel, excellent salary/benefits.
cons: None that I can think of.

headline: Great
pros: Despite the fact that it is a large company, they try to give employees autonomy
cons: Culture, very dated and old

headline: it's been a bumpy ride!!
pros: Huge company, lots of resources.  Great international assignee program that will allow you to get international experience
cons: UBS has been hit hard with the 2008 financial crisis which has really hampered the ability of the company to pay it's employees well.  Salaries and bonus lag behind competitors

headline: Not the place you want to work
pros:
Decent benefits
Good midtown NYC location
cons:
Not committed to the business
Revolving door management
Nobody wants to be there

headline: Overall supportive working environment
pros: Global opportunities, good internal education program, flexible working environment
cons: most opportunities available to employees who are willing to relocate to major hubs

headline: great place to work
pros: nice people, personnel development options
cons: slow move on salary upwards

headline: overall very good experience, lots of different tasks such as marketing and producing pitches, organizing roadshows
pros: Lots of vacation time available, fast-paced good learning environment, dynamic workforce covering a wide variety of tasks
cons: Not a very social team, long hours expected without the demand for fulfilment by work

headline: Associate Director
pros: Enjoyed my team, decent hours for wall street
cons: too bureaucratic,doesn't recognize individual success enough

headline: Good talent, nice people, terrible management
pros:
Lots of resources
People are generally nice
cons:
Poor morale especially in the IB and everyone working to support the IB.
Below market pay.
They actually demoted people to cut costs...

headline: Very good company. Work hard - get rewarded
pros: Good work/life balance, going places in banking
cons: A lot of red tape

headline: very nice
pros: very nice environment, smart people and young people
cons: long hour is the worst part

headline: Not always interesting opportunities
pros: Many different department, jobs opportunity and networking experience
cons: Since 4 years continuiing restructiring, old style management not women friendly

headline: A very hardworking company with committed employees
pros:
- Very comprehensive learning and development opportunities
- Collaborative, friendly culture - people will just chat to you in the corridors
- Streamlined processes to improve efficiency
cons: - Significant outsourcing slows down processes and creates frustration among employees

headline: Positive, great way to get a start in the industry
pros: Compensation, people are willing to help you out along the way
cons: Hierarchy, crazy hours, people tended to be favorited

headline: Lacks direction, investment banking being scaled down
pros: Still has some name recognition on the street.
cons: Morale, atmosphere, lack of flow, poor management...

headline: Good
pros: Carefulness, Professionalism, Kind, Warm, Nice
cons: Not much. They are all nice.

headline: Still recovering and focusing on risk and compliance
pros: Overall good compensation and work life balance.
cons: Strategic project are scarce unless risk and compliance driven

headline: Had great experiences working with global colleagues, but company future outlook is not bright...
pros:
- Had a lot of deal experiences working with global colleagues
- Compensation and benefits were not so bad for junior bankers
- Learned a lot of basics of financings, M&As, etc via live deals
cons:
- Work life balance was a kind of suck, but I believe this is not only true for UBS
- Outlook of investment bank business in UBS is quite bleak
- Repetitive restructuring darkened the atmosphere

headline: Generally great, approachable people, could do much better at investing in and motivating loyal staff.
pros: Great people. Fairly flat structure. Approachable management.
cons: Not enough done to motivate staff and reward hard working, loyal employees who have progressed through the organisation.

headline: Making a come back
pros: The company is working hard to make the re-organization work. Some really smart and nice people work here. Re-newed team effort with the help of new management.
cons: Management needs to remain focused on moving forward and clarify key initiatives to the rank and file below. Continue to share information and educate staff on current regs and compliance.

headline: good place to work with UBS
pros: good payers with UBS across the industry
cons: limited growth but still again depends on departments

headline: Mediocre organization killed by bureaucracy.
pros: It has a strong brand that is perceived to be world class by others so it looks good on your resume. It is returning to profitability and is too big to fail therefore there is some job stability.
cons: There is too much bureaucracy and more time is spent getting things done a certain way rather than achieving the desired result.

headline: UBS provided excellent guidance, training and support.
pros: The staff was friendly, the senior management team was effective and supportive. The organization sets a high standard and there is significant opportunity for advancement.
cons: The financial services industry has ups and downs. The cyclical nature of financial markets is an additional challenge for people entering this industry.

headline: Still looking for the right business model
pros: Still some great people within the business; Strong global footprint; Top notch Research product outside the US
cons: Restructuring still ongoing and job security a overhang; One-off operation/execution issues still impacting business and comp; Legal/regulatory issues will be around for a few more years.

headline: Lots of opportunity, but needs more mgmt guidance and direction.
pros: able to move up in the organization.
cons: mgmt changes constantly and no truly clear direction.

headline: Great opportunities offset by dated organizational design.
pros: Truly global perspectives available, vast institutional reach, world class wealth management arm inside corporate umbrella with attendant possible synergies, and new management in many functional areas which should speed transformation.
cons: U.S.-based investment banking is a work-in-progress, world class research operation has suffered cuts in personnel and stature, still migrating to regulatory and/or economic environment reality in each region.

headline: excellent training
pros: Smart colleagues, open information sharing, excellent training
cons: wall street boys club mentality, "tough guy" managers, very rigid corporate structure

headline: Good people, but poorly performing bank
pros: Enjoyed working with all the people.  As collaborative as budgets could allow. I was givewn a lot of flexibility by the head of trading to develop my models without distraction.  I was also given the unofficial ability to direct IT to implement my models very quickly and efficiently for use in production.
cons: Not enough investment in technology.  Outsourcing everything and contracting out the technology made it hard to accomplish some tasks that would otherwise be relatively easy to get done - this was especially true with regards to data/speed of data retrieval.

headline: Good work life balance
pros: Many Swiss in the bank so work life balance is well respected.
cons: The recent bad news coverage from overseas branches.

headline: I have been at UBS for 10years + so I must be satisfied
pros: Interesting People and good Benifits for employees. Has been seen to be secure in terms on employment although over the past few years has moved more towards the US business model
cons: Longer serving employees are genrally regarded and institutionlised and therfore much less likely to change companies. This can be a construed as a negative when loyalty should be rewarded.

headline: Very good company to work with
pros: Learning opportunity and growth in the company.
cons: Nothing I can think off for Cons.

headline: Tax department run like a big 4
pros: smart people, nice office great commute, good meals
cons: lots of over time, let go of really good people

headline: International Financial Service
pros: good work environment, great work ethic
cons: efficiency of back office, length of background checking

headline: Two sides of an international company
pros: Open culture, good management, most of the people i have worked with are great team players
cons: Career progression is slow, one-way international 'exchange' program where only people from headquarters get to go to other countries for short stay

headline: Internship
pros: very friendly, able to work independently, good salary
cons: long working hours, not much room for development (but ok for an internship)

headline: A more civilised Investment Bank than most.
pros: Based in a very commutable part of London. Still has a culture of putting customers fist.
cons: Not seen as a leader in the sector (Investment Banking). Can be quite conservative in it's approach.

headline: Ok company to work with
pros: The work environment was flexible and I used to get comp days off for any extra work I had done.
cons: Did not see much growth potential. Hard to get any trainings relevant to your field of expertise. Needs improvement at Management level.

headline: Good experience
pros: Very friendly, being able to attend monthly meeting with financial advisors or presentations which are very interesting. the work/life is is satisfying, even with some overtime... Good culture.
cons: No opportunities to get hired permanently after internship

headline: Great management and wonderful work environment
pros: Upward mobility encouraged, support and assistance is top notch, really know how to assist with business development and in improving client relations
cons: location and traffic are the only real downsides. parking can be a hastle and they don't reimburse for hot lanes.

headline: Interning in Investment Banking Division
pros: Nice people, good culture, decent pay
cons: Sometimes not very efficient, late hours

headline: Company in Transition
pros:
Collaborative approach to decision making - Good work environment
Global reach / capabilities
Very good electronic trading platforms - especially in Equities
Very client-centric approach
cons:
Significant turnover in management levels across the IB as well as in Support areas
Strategic reduction in staff has lagged and attrition is a concern
Focus on Career Development and Compensation has lagged since '08

headline: Horrible
pros:
- They don't work you too hard
- If you're good, you can work here indefinitely, that is, as long as they don't decide to axe your entire team
cons:
- Lack of IT practices
- Technology is from the stone age
- They hire inexperienced graduates through contracting firms who know absolutely nothing, so you learn nothing from them
- Very bad IT practices
- A place where there are more managers than there are workers
- Incredibly hierarchical
- No transparency
- Tons of paperwork to make the smallest IT changes

headline: Awesome work
pros: Brand name, Excellent work ethic
cons: Selection process, lenghty background checks

headline: Good place to work
pros: Good people, good work-life balance
cons: You may get stuck with way too many rules that end up not serving proposed objectives and slow down service.

headline: Positive experience
pros: Global reach combined with excellent training make it a good post grad starting point for gaining a strong working skill set
cons: Long grueling hours and distance from he make being in a regional office tough to progress further at the firm

headline: The bank is going down
pros: high salary and working hours not too bad
cons: lots, too much pressure, no job prospects bad culture

headline: cannot recommend as a developer
pros:
relaxed environment
there is no overwork
cons:
everything else
old technology
leader without expertise

headline: diverse work environment
pros:
Diverse work environment, great opportunity for new recruits to work with very senior management
good mentor ship programs and volunteering initiatives
cons:
role allocation not based on employee's education/skill set
too many changes in senior management
big initiatives get scrapped with changes in senior management

headline: Neutral environment, some opportunities / risks
pros: Love the European culture (4 weeks vacation is the standard) and for the most part fairly flat hierarchy structure allows access to senior management. There are pockets at UBS that are doing fairly well esp in Wealth Management and front office roles.
cons: Offshoring / outsourcing is very discouraging and lowers the quality that everything UBS used to stand for. I must say that technology is not even close to where it should be. As far as career growth, it is an absolute joke. Bonuses are not even close of where they used to be and the training is subpar.

headline: Overall great experience
pros: I worked very hard, put in long hours and was compensated for it. Great large company benefits-health insurance, matching 401k, events, etc.
cons: Even though UBS is a massive global company, career growth isn't always supported - depending upon what position you're in when you join them.

headline: UBS like many employers, looks better from outside than inside
pros:
Global reach for a bank like UBS is always good. It has also the particularity to pay better than market as UBS is just an hungry consumer and not a people riser...
Still a few fantastic professional and very knowledgeable persons (who are trying to leave the boat unfortunately)
cons:
Middle management is absolutely crap. 
They are always on the go to new project (i.e. often pre-run processes or systems or business approach in other institutions or industries) and they will always need to have an extremely formalized approach that takes for ever as mid-mgt does not decide anything...At the first hick-up, they would stop everything and find someone to blaim (usually the very last one in the chain who has no clue whats going on)...lots of evil people and cowards on top of it ...plus no vision at all... many bankers who have less knowledge than beginners sometimes.. (many people managing something they reaaaally dont understand and just try to compensate with communication - meant wind here - ridiculous indeed)
As a consequence, absolutely no people management or career enhancement...
UBS good at personal marketing, good at talking about innovation but not open to change through innovation and hence killing in the eggs is a 'national sport'
Hiring process: they want best of the best, launching job description that more than 80% or UBS employees cant even dream about accomplishing it once in their life...so they pay at high rate and later, once you are in, either you've got a very musculous tongue or you are off the page
UBS is doing good in business at the moment, but this does not impact yet career development (horizontally, vertically and/or geographically)

headline: A good company living through difficult times
pros: Very nice, knowledgeable, hard working colleagues. Can learn a lot here. International exposure: working together with colleagues in many countries on all continents.
cons: The bank is in a survival mode. It lost a lot of money. Shrinks and cuts operations. Layoffs all the time, from a very top to a very bottom. Four CEOs and four chairmans changed in 4-5 years. Every one is very bright, is an outstanding executive and has excellent ideas, every one changed strategies cardinally - but it is hard to execute and especially to tune up all the strategies so often.

headline: My best working place in life
pros:
Great people
A lot to learn
Nice office
Opportunity to work outside
Opportnuty to collaborate with best practices
Opportunity to communicate with colleagues from different countries
Opportnuty to change fields and to grow
cons: I did not find any cons during my working time

headline: International Financial Services firm
pros: Name recognition, great work environment, and global financial firm based in Europe.
cons: I believe the firm is known more for its corporate transactions vs individual.

headline: Overall, great insight into the investment bank
pros: Wonderful people who are excited about their work
cons: The company has gone through significant changes in the past six years.

headline: Terrible culture, poor management, everyone plays politics
pros:
-Compensation is ok, but bonuses are significantly less than similar bulge brackets
-Still a pretty capable bank, some decent deals and exposure 
-Analyst classes are filled out pretty well - diverse, smart people. Usually best thing about joining is the analyst network after
cons:
-Terrible management at practically every level. Everyone is looking out for themselves, do not care to develop junior staff and frequently throw them under the bus. 
-Upward movement is based more on politics than it is on merit
-No direction besides cost cutting. Senior management provides no guidance, tells their bankers to cut costs but then punishes them for not closing deals. Result is a free-for-all amongst all the bankers, severe politics to stay afloat, and no consideration for the long-term
-any major talent has pretty much jumped ship already after a series of poor management decisions and financial blowups due to poor risk management and a culture that encourages immense risk-taking

headline: Financial Advisor
pros: World class firm. Great benefits. Good experience.
cons: Lack of opportunities to move up. Pay has been stagnant. High Net worth focus contradicts with accounts who are below High Net Worth. Trading fees are very high. No online platform. European HQ views conflict with home office Americas direction. 401k match was reduced.

headline: People over Pay....
pros: Great work life balance and nice people.  They'll help you through exams and provide and great learning environment.
cons: People only get salary raises when they threaten to leave.  They should have a better reward system.  Overly bureaucratic management bring large barriers to change.

headline: Good place to work
pros: Good benefits and busy environment
cons: Financial advisors are king...they will get their way.

headline: Best job ever
pros: Great place to work overall
cons: Nothing bad to say overall

headline: Going down....
pros: UBS had a nice culture, with good scope for growth, lots of benefits.
cons: Overall company is in big trouble, reflecting on its pay and down sizing of many divisions...

headline: Too much nepotism
pros: Provide a good amount of training. UBS has a good offering of courses you can take to further your knowledge in a variety of subjects.
cons: Meritocracy is not a priority. Employees were rated subjectively with bias. Employees are evaluated by managers that do not know the duties the employee is performing.

headline: Lumbering from one accident to another
pros: - You get a shot at doing the stuff only senior folks do at other banks, because senior people leave at an amazing rate.
cons:
- The bank has had heaps pf problems in the past years, rogue traders, fired CEOs, rotating cast of senior management.
- The bank most notorious for over-hiring and over-firing (ask the FICC guys)
- The bank will soon have no FICC or Investment banking businsess to speak of, so unless you want to work in wealth management, look elsewhere.

headline: A very cultural place to work
pros: Great people to work with
cons: Upper management not on board with employees all the time

headline: Enjoyable experience, flexible and relaxed culture, felt that the feedback system could have been improved
pros: Great place to work, excellent salary and benefits, flexible and open culture
cons: Feedback system for interns could be improved some negative feedback given to me at the end was not made clear to me throughout and so I was given no chance to improve.

headline: Strong company but hard to get started in industry - very little support
pros: strong brand, great products, wealth of knowledge
cons: hard to get started in industry, very little support for new reps

headline: Frustrating... Some positives but, largely inhibitive for a top performer.
pros: Strong product/service offering, strong brand, excellent company stability / capitalization, reasonable career opportunities, seen as one of the top 2 or 3 Private Banks globally.
cons: Below industry average in remuneration, questionable middle management, obstructionist Compliance regime, some job insecurity, heavy office gossip, heavy political obstacles across the firm globally.

headline: worst place I've ever worked
pros: The desk heads are talented people.
cons: 'Industrialization' has made everything horrific.  Nothing gets done.  It's actually written in the policy that they do not give cost of living increases so most people have not gotten any raise in 5 years when the salaries are known to be below market to begin with.  There is not one person I know who is happy there.  Everyone thinks they have to be prepping for sale cause there really can be no other reason that things can be run this poorly.

headline: UBS Summer Internship
pros: Huge career opportunities for the future
cons: High level of pressure and work load

headline: Internship with duties of assisting the Manager, and Staff Assistants with client files, mass mailings, Morningstar data
pros: The culture of the office was exceptional and the staff was of the highest level of professionalism.
cons: I did not observe a downside of working for the company.

headline: High class wealth management franchise
pros: Truely client focussed .Wealth managment unit leaves no stone unturned to position itself as the best. Investment bank delivers strong advisory capability
cons:
Slow moving in taking decisions and has become too conservative
Salaries lag peers

headline: Client Service
pros: Easy to transfer to different teams or difference branches across the country. Help desk is very good. Central location, great network with HNW individuals.
cons: Outdated technology, red tape, compliance is a pain. Typical office gossip culture. Not a lot of benefits, no assistance in public transportation.

The company's business strategy is working so far, and the model is good, but there is so much transformation to be done to get the operation in line with the business that things will be uncertain for years.

headline: A true love hate relationship with UBS
pros:
The technology of this bank is outdated, between the 1990's to 2000's, and the bank is far from perfect (what company is?), however instead of looking at this from a negative point of view, I saw the positive side of it.  The nature of my position and the lack of resources available allowed me to utilize my creativity to the max, which also helped me improve my computer programming and communication skills greatly.  The people were nice, mostly open to suggestions, and seemed to appreciate my work for the departments.

Of course, the nature of my position was made possible by my boss who was fortunately very open minded.  He let me do my job independently with minimal supervision.  If I have had anything less, my viewpoints would have been very different and my creativity would have been limited.

In my particular department, there was downsizing and this occurs everywhere in every company at some point or another.  Thus, I can't put this as a con since this is a part of life and business restructure.  Again, I looked at the downsizing as an opportunity for myself and utilized my creativity to the max to help offset the lack of resources through innovation.  This is a pro because the company let me be creative, listened to my suggestions, let me execute my decisions, and overall had been very accommodating.  I know a lot of people complain about the technology there (and so did I my first few months), but there are some things we can't control.  I learned to focus on what I could control, and turned the negatives into major opportunities.
cons:
There are definitely cons to working at UBS.  Unfortunately because of these cons, this fact had pushed me into looking for new employment about 1.5 years into the company.  I am not one to criticize management or to give my personal opinion about how they should act, mainly because I do not have the full story.  But I will say this:

Although the lack of resources as I mentioned above allowed me to be creative and work smarter, the lack of resources also affected my personal growth at the company.  I had expected to have a small team working for me by the end of the 2nd year, and I still had no support.  Think about it, if you are the only maintenance and support technician on site, what happens?  You can't leave your position, ever.  There would be no way for me to personally grow at this company since any promotion would indicate I would no longer be available to support my original duties.

The lack of any salary increases also was off-putting.  Most people will say "but no one got a raise", or "you haven't been at the company that long" but we shouldn't think that way.  Everyone is different and has different achievements and time frames.  Why should I have to be at any company for even 5 years to see a promotion if my work is truly valued?  I only look at my own achievements, and if the company is not giving promotions or salary increases throughout the department despite individual contributions, there really isn't much one can do but to either take it, or move on.

headline: Experience is what you make it.
pros: Established company. Offer 401k match up to $3,000 plus company portion contribution. The company portion is a percent of your salary. Percent goes up with length of time, ex: 5 years with UBS gets you 1.5% of your salary, Employee share purchase program, 1 share for every 3 shares you purchase, vests after 3 years.  12 weeks family leave after birth of child. Average 3 weeks vacation.
cons: Low base salaries for support staff. Large corporate structure. Support staff has to put in hours worked every two weeks. No salary increases for a couple of years. Difficult to get upgraded on titles. Higher titles are given to new people coming in from outside. No overtime pay. No recognition for different individual characteristics of employees with same title as others.

headline: Bad experience

cons:
-  layoff every quarter, no job security
-  politics everywhere, people spent more time on politics than doing business (there was not much business anyway)
- no raise, no promotion, no bonus
- HR was very unprofessional and ridiculous, e.g. had to argue to get business trip reimbursed; used appointment on private issues as a "training opportunity" for their junior people
- some part of the training program was a waste of time e.g. weeks spent on learning meaning of the firm's logo
- Poor IT infrastructure
- Very bureaucratic, too many levels of management and very slow to get anything approved

headline: Not quite a nice place to work at
pros:
1. Excellent salary and benefit package
2. Good on your CV
cons:
1. Lots of redundancy made since Oct 2012 - 10,000 positions to be made redundant in 2/3 yrs' time
2. Low morale - employees have little motivation to push themselves further given that promotion and bonuses are close to non-existent for MO/BO 
3. Wasteful - people spend a huge amount of time doing things for the sake of doing them, knowing no value is added
Some senior employees (e.g. ED/MD) are dissatisfied with the IB CEO, given that he was hired directly from outside and was paid $26m to join amid turbelent times at UBS. Also, they may not work together or even work against each other in different teams/departments, thereby leading to lower revenue being made
Junior employees (e.g. NO/AO/AD) may not work together to solve issues and may hide what they know/what they do. It's understandable that one may be ingeuine at work, but being fake all the times and saying non-sensial work to be of high value is truly disgusting.

struggeling with inside-out-view: too focused on internal processes
setting up too many project and forgets about implementation

headline: Great opportunities for cross-training.
pros: Many opportunities to learn and grow in knowledge about the financial markets with offices all around the world.  I was able to hold several different positions in my tenure with UBS which continued to challenge me intellectually.
cons: This is a Swiss owned company.  Sometimes, the Swiss methods/initiatives don't 'translate' well in the US.  The markets are cyclical, so there are 'good' years and 'bad' years.  I was given a 'bonus' in UBS Stock options, which ended up being worthless when they could finally be exercised.

cons: Management in all groups at UBS Financial Services (Investment Bank) is in a meltdown.  Communication and leadership are absent.  Revolving door management because so many people are leaving.  Horrible atmosphere.  The best are leaving, leaving UBS with the bottom performers running the show. Outlook terrible, downsizing is the strategy.

cons: The rapid management changes make the working environment very difficult.  Also the frequent layoff reduced the morality of workers.  People can not concentrate on their work because nothing can be final.  Everything is subjected o change every week.

headline: very busy environment as there are lot of user demands
pros: very busy environment.benefits medical bonus etcetra
cons: for me i could not see any downside of worinig n at thois comapmy

headline: Experience counts for something
pros: There is a wealth of knowledge, information and learning opportunity. A hungry individual who is looking to learn about the finacial services industry could benefit a great deal from employment with UBS. The company encourages employees to learn through their own Business University and one to one meetings with people across departments. The diversity of people and many different interests in banking make it a great place to begin a career.
cons: There is a lot of change taking place in the bank and the environment is not quite as positive as a new joiner might hope for. There are a alot of layers of management between a new joiner and a change effort. It's hard to feel like you're contributing to a greater cause.

headline: Brand name still exists externally, but very political internally
pros: Brand name recognition by clients meaning dealflow stays strong, reputation across street still good although hit majorly by recent trading / LIBOR scandals and departing bankers.
cons:
Political organization: managing your way through the organization without taking sides is difficult.
Compensation less compared to other bulge bracket banks. Turnover rate extremely high.

headline: UBS was really great to work with but in recent years lacks leadership, morale and compensation could be better.
pros: Large international organization with great opportunities to learn a lot and be able to move around. You work hard and you can grow professionally and take on new responsibilities. Great internal development and education opportunities which one should not let pass by.
cons: Complex organization, in recent years lacks leadership and credibility vis-à-vis employees. If you are an FA or Banker you probably are doing great. But if you are in Corporate Center or Home Office you are rather viewed as a "2nd class citizen" and you feel this in every way. Overall the morale of employees could be better. Many great and experienced professionals left the organization or were let go. Company has a know-how drain in certain areas which is a concern.

headline: learning experience
pros: a lot of very bright mind in the room with you , always challenged
cons: a little katiness, and underhand  divide and conquer types

headline: at one time an awesome bank to work for - now within 3 years the IB will be done!
pros: right now - nothing - used to be a good place to work
cons: no job security - management is lost

headline: Inclusive culture, good career opportunities
pros:
- Good training
- Good opportunities internally
- Fast career progression
cons: - Shrinking IB means less internal mobility available

headline: Great place to work
pros: Great work culture, loads of space to innovate, IJPs are great.
cons: None really other than the common cons that every company has.

headline: Good place to learn investment banking but not where you want to spend your career
pros: Decent amount of transaction experience and a good brand outside of the US...certain groups have ok traction and are competitive with other bulge bracket banks...good wealth management platform with cross sell opportunities that are still relatively untapped
cons: Trying to figure out go forward business model which means little to no bonuses near term (and up to 5 year deferral periods on bonuses)...a lot of negative headlines over past 5 years (subprime, tax evasion, rogue trader, LIBOR scandal, etc) makes it tough to win business...a lot of turnover at senior ranks and throughout the organization...even if your group is doing well, they won't be immune from layoffs...employee morale is pretty low right now

headline: The golden years are over
