headline: Great business model, values employees, focus on growing employees
pros: great benefits, great culture (from the top down), opportunities for training / certifying, really values it's employees.  The focus now is not on acquiring many new employees but growing the ones that are here. Also, if you start at the bottom there are many different avenues available as you plan your career.
cons: This is a huge organization with many tiers of management and you may be reporting to more than 1 person.

headline: neverending problems
pros: good place to position yourself to leave to another company
cons: pay is below market, long hours

headline: Dying Bank, no deals whatsoever, good bankers have all left
pros:
Culture is better than most other bb banks.
Maybe a better work life balance as there aren't that many deals
cons:
The bank has lost its reputation
Exit options are limited
No job security

headline: Mediocre
pros: Good work-life balance and culture with a great bunch of people
cons: Management do not seem to have a vision particulalry aligned to the benefit of their employees, more focus on lining their own pockets

headline: A good company before 2008, now poor
pros: Decent pay, friendly colleagues, reasonable working hours
cons: Falling bonuses, hire and fire culture, poor management

headline: software developer
pros:
good salary 
 free coffee new technologies
cons: unorganized poor management  cowardness no plan chaotic

headline: Graduate training program two years
pros: Strong structure to the program
cons: Not a lot of internal mobility

headline: Good Company
pros: Great Location and solid name recognition in the industry.  Provides competitive salary and great benefits.
cons: The usual corporate issues.  Large company with many hoops to jump through to get things done.

headline: UBS
pros: Excellent facilities, constant activity, attitude of innovation, trading focus
cons: Lack of appreciation of hard working employees, inner circle not communicating with team, lack of communication in the organization, stupid activities going on counter-intuitive to good business decision-making or profit taking

headline: Great employer
pros: Large company with good reputation.
cons: Large company with a regulations hitting it from all sides.

headline: Getting out of the Equity Business...
pros: Very nice people to work with (co-workers); civilized work environment and culture.
cons: Clueless top management; too many layers in the organization; pay scale broken.

headline: Hard work, long hours, good experience; very challenging, tough people.
pros:
Good learning experiences possible
Close-knit teams; if you fit in well it feels like a family
Were genuinely trying to beat the "big boys" from the US at their own game
Focused, hungry, motivated and smart.
cons:
Limited flexibility in terms of roles
Substantial politics
Limited management focus on whether people are genuinely good or just good at looking good
Have lost many good men / women following their well-publicised issues 
Hard to see where they go from here

headline: Just ok for a financial job
pros: Good people with a comfortable work environment
cons: Management is poor, lacking vision and the ability to work with you. Not long before they will be sold off to another financial institution and changes will unfold. Lower salary compared to other firms.

headline: Shambles
pros: Generally speaking a good group of people to work with
cons: Senior Management are spending too much time trying to keep old systems and processes going. There is an incredible amount of dead wood. No-one seems willing to face the situation that the legacy IT systems now take so much maintainance, are extremely costly, and just add risk but turning the company into an IT dinosaur. They need to dump these systems as there are better and cheaper systems available off the shelf

headline: Great experience for a summer internship
pros: Knowledgeable co-workers/higher ups.  Great place in financial industry.
cons: None to really speak of.

headline: Application Developer
pros: Good working hours. People are very nice.
cons: Be warned! Especially H1B Visa holder.

headline: Tend to forget who keeps the business running
pros: good staff, ok cantina, good internal education program
cons: poor management, cutting costs at the wrong places, no salary rises even when promoted, constantly moving target (carrot-donkey-syndrom)

headline: Too Big to Function
pros: International organization with many opportunities for growth and mobility if you actively seek them out.
cons: There are so many processes in place that the day to day business can't get done efficiently and effectively

headline: Sinking ship with worst comp history on the street
pros: Cafeteria has decent food and the office at 299 Park, NY is close to the 6-train stop.
cons: Classifying this bank as a "revolving door" is generous and inaccurate. The IB is in a unidirectional decline. Deal teams are bottom feeders with very few lead left deals. Bonuses are nonexistent. Everyone is actively looking for opps outside of the bank, including the MDs.

headline: UBS
pros: good salary, and location in the city
cons: no communication, and poor knowledge

headline: Above Average Pay, Great Benefits
pros: The hours are good with little need for overtime.  The pay seems to be above average for customer service work.  The training is comprehensive.
cons: Layoffs are always around the corner.  Annual reviews are a little mysterious.  Promotions are not transparent.  Opportunities limited.

headline: very large crude carrier tries to redefine
pros: salary, interesting Job, work life balance
cons: a lot of useless managers around

headline: FICC Graduate
pros: People are nice and wiling to teach you.
cons: Executive Board is a mess and does not care about IB anymore

headline: When times are good it's a good place to work...when times are bad it can get disheartening
pros: You get to work with some brilliant people.  No two days are alike so it's never boring.  There is a decent amount of global collaboration between resources in the same department but different regions.  Not that layoffs are good but, at least, when they have to do one it affects all levels, not just staff.
cons: The pressure never lets up, it's relentless.  Base pay is OK but variable comp at the staff and middle management levels takes a  dive every time another reputation-damaging revelation is uncovered.  Company has passed a disproportionate amount for the cost of US health benefits on the backs of its employees.  Company has also done away with a benefit for older workers that would have paid half their health benefits (after 10 years of service) during their retirement years.  The push to offshore as much as possible is hurting the retention of institutional knowledge.

headline: Do not recommend if you are seeking a positive work and career experience
pros:
Great 6-week global training program with all recent graduates (internationally).  
Competitive post-undergraduate starting salary for the financial sector ($60K + $10K signing bonus).
cons: In addition to the constant layoffs, much of the best talent has voluntarily departed due to poor management and overall negative view for company future.

headline: I stayed there 5 years too long
pros: I enjoyed the work life balance and that was very hard to give up when thinking about my career.
cons: UBS never recovered from the recession.  Things just kept getting worse.

headline: It used to be a great IB
pros: Good culture compared to other IB, less backstabbing compared to American banks
cons: IB division not core anymore, only support to WM. Every year your bonus is given away to pay fines or bad investments or trading holes

headline: Satisfactory
pros: Flexible work schedule on occasion
cons: Annual downsizing damages employee morale

headline: A good training ground for the those seeking a career in finance
pros: diversity, prepared to promote from within, don't put down the axe as ruthlessly as some other firms, very smart and inspiring people to work with.
cons: don't often provide enough resources especially outside of head office.  Sometimes too patient with underperformers, not enough work life balance.

headline: Used to be a Great place to work, not anymore
pros:
UBS had lots of talented and intelligent people.
Good work/life balance depending on your department or manager
cons: Most of the "talented and intelligent" folks have now departed the firm either through lay-offs or voluntarily. There are still few, but not enough to make your work fulfilling. This has made the culture less motivating and it seems to be getting worse.

headline: Fair
pros: Work diversity and a very forward looking approach.
cons: Too much short term changes

headline: experience
pros: Interesting learning experience for research analyst
cons: layoffs of current employees while hiring new employees at the same time

headline: Everything off shored / Outsourced
pros:
Excellent Work Life Balance
Flexible Work Hours
TeleCommute
cons:
Everything being offshored and Outsourced
Poor compensation & Bonus

headline: Shutting down the investment bank
pros: Some very good people there in the trenches.   Had a decent global reach at one point and brand outside of US still OK
cons: Harvard Business School case study in how not to manage a business.  Nobody is getting paid and they have set in motion what will result in the complete shut down of the US investment bank.  Morale is a joke and nobody has any intention of staying any longer than it takes to find a new job.

headline: Good company to work for, despite the challenges posed in the media
pros: Many of the people I worked with there were engaging and easy to work with.  Management had a good sense of the employees concerns and communicated as best as could be expected, especially given the size of the company.  They are extremely active and visible in the community and gives you a positive feeling about working there
cons: There was the occassional self promotion/back stabbing that could occur at a large firm.  Some members of management were not open to being challenged, even when the issue was a legitamite concern.  However, this is not unusual and would not let this be a reason to not work there.

headline: financial services hyper experience already
pros: it is a employee centric employer which pays well above market and retains staff very well though various incentives like stocks options housing allowances etc
cons: It sucks it sucks and it sucks

headline: It was good but things are changing.
pros: Compensation is not bad.  The firm itself is very global and well organized,  Work-life balance is very good, paid vacation days increases to 25 days after 5 years, health insurance, pension, housing tax break benefits.
cons:
1. Company culture is a bit weak most likely due to high turnovers, high diversity, efficient electronic communication (rather than face to face) and globally scattered teams.
2. Layoffs have been continuing from 2008 and there are more to come.
3. Investment Bank business is losing money
4. Difficult to get a promotion if your team is global (poor recognition and representation by management)

headline: Former UBS graduate, current equity derivs
pros: Great people, good environment, frontrunner
cons: Poor systems, lacks long term vision

headline: Good people but no career progress
pros: Good people and technology With a nice working environment
cons: No personal growth or career prospect at the bank

headline: Company in transition
pros: High quality and great culture among the junior staff (associates and analysis), however recruiting similar quality moving forward is becoming more difficult.
cons: The bank has had very high turnover rates and is not bringing in large deals.  Headcount has been significantly reduced so the work hours are quite high.

headline: UBS is a terrible place to work.
pros: Decent work quality of life experience.
cons: The place has become a very depressing and unmotivating place to work over the last 4 years. Things do not seem to be getting better.

headline: Excellant  MNC environment, all the required trainings provided, they provide six sigma certification to boost profile.
pros:
good learning experience
international posting available, if interested.
they have all the facilities of disaster management
cons:
slogging hours working in Asian (APAC) region.
office located in outskirts.

headline: Associate Director - ITI
pros: flexible time, ability to work from home, alots of meeting with ppl around the globe, nice to work with people from different background - learning various cultures
cons:
1)investment banks run the company, bad decisions by one or more greedy bankers can kill depts and/or jobs. 
2)advancement comes to mostly Europeans - US employees are looked down upon
3)Too many meeting often times work needs to be done away from the office or after hours because most of your day was spend in meetings.

headline: Good good
pros: Not bad, like this firm.  But fired too many ppl
cons: Not bad, like this company

headline: Client Service Associate
pros: Extensive training and learning oportunities
cons: Once you start there as a CSA, you get stuck with the same salary and position for...ever; there's basically no growth potential; management is terrible and many times not capable of doing their job.

headline: Good company, not enough reward
pros: Good management, brilliant team atmosphere, solid foundations, good career development
cons: Lack of compensation, very strict rules around compensation, not based as much on performance across the board but in circles. If you work in an area without many good people you get more than working in a competitive area and doing more work.

headline: Restructuring wave
pros: There are lots of opportunities to enhance one's profile. Especially to pursue a career in Wealth Management.
cons: Shows the traits of a burocratic and mechanistic organization.

headline: UBS represents hard working people
pros: Substantial Challenge keeps work interesting
cons: Never ending misery due to prior losses, unethical behavior by a few

headline: Overall it's an neutral experience working at UBS
pros: Work culture is good enough work peacefully.
cons: career development is question and package remains unchanged

headline: UBS FA- positive experience
pros: Great flexibilty for FAs, a variety of products to offer clients, and good platform. Highly recognized name that can be beneficial with clients.
cons: UBS is extremely conservative and the management has a difficult time "thinking outside the box".A great deal of that can be blamed on current industry regulations but the remaining is due to the corporate culture.

headline: Stay away if technology is your passion...
pros:
- a  lot of good talented people
- relatively good working conditions
cons:
- very limited career prospects for technically skilled people
- complex organizational structure

headline: Great team, encourage further development
pros: Worked with a good team. Managers encourage you to go on courses. Encourages to further yourself in your career
cons: Could have been paid more. Hours were quite long although expected.

headline: Corporate has lost focus on what really brings success to Wealth Management - US based employees.
pros: There are many opportunites to 'shine' at UBS Wealth Management given the massive staff reductions and preponderance of issues at hand.
cons: The perception is that Corporate in Zurich takes care of it's staff and projects based in Europe.  The employees in these regions generally enjoy better compensation, benefits, support and work/life balances.  Conversely, the firm is so strongly focused on outsourcing American IT jobs (mostly to India) that it has driven a profitable business into vitual chaos and risks driving it into the red.  Consultants in India do not have the expertise or impetus to deliver the necessary support to our firm.  Failure is now abundant and the root cause is clearly the result of a poorly executed outsourcing strategy.

headline: intern
pros:
- great work environment
- unlimited growth potential
cons:
- not enough work to do
-

headline: Best company to work for, honestly
pros: culture, values, respect, career opportunities
cons: can't even think of anything negative

headline: Work your A** OFF, but compensated to work your A** off....
pros:
- Satisfied with compensation* (Please note that I am generally not too hard to please--esp given that many peers in my age group were out of work)
- Excellent benefits package
- Excellent cafeteria food
- Dinners ordered after 6PM were paid for by the firm (up to $25 dollars)
- Worked in a group with some generally good people (DEF not the norm; group specific)
- Worked in a group where weekend work was not always required (DEF not the norm; group specific)
cons:
- Consistently long work days (12hrs+; on par with investment banking hours)
- Managers' expectations would not always be 100% clear
- Days where down time was excessive; and work wouldn't begin until PM hours (leading to inevitable late nights)
- Very senior heavy group lead to junior folks being spread thin to take on time consuming grunt work

headline: Highly satisfying on many levels, but ultimately frustrating following so many leadership changes and company missteps
pros: Collegiate atmosphere and collaborative culture. UBS arguably has one of the best global models for delivering the Firm to it's clients. They also place great emphasis on work/life balance and local community activities.
cons: Too many self-inflicted losses, scandals and leadership changes have resulted in deteriorating morale, poor pay and periodic lay-offs.

headline: A well run organisation
pros: Interesting work. Varied work. Nice offices. Good location.Good infrastructure. Decent pay. Good work/life balance. A very well run organisation. Good to work for, a nice culture with some clever individuals. A good environment to learn.
cons: Seen as non-competitive by it's rivals and as such the pay reflects that. However, that is not to say that pay is not good. Top management need to be seen more and the organisation as a whole needs to be more transparent about the direction of the firm.

headline: If in Wealth Management, like most firms, the quality of your experience depends on your sales figures.
pros: Large product line to use when solving client needs; investment/lending/planning.  The company has a long history in banking.
cons: The technology platform can tend to be slow & buggy sometimes, which hinders productivity.  Some negative press the last few years affecting the formerly sterling reputation; rogue trader, credit meltdown, etc.  But you could probably say much of the same for all the large financial institutions.

headline: U and US, until they throw you fromt he bus!
pros: The brand on a global basis is quite strong. Very large Investment bank with a lot of capabilities. The bank is also Swiss which is appealing to a lot of wealthy amricans in the private wealth management space.
cons: Their management is not very good primarily due to the fact that they stil are unable to identify how they are going to grow the business and in which direction they want to take the business.

headline: Nice place to work
pros: Nice co-worker, work-life balance, great work space
cons: Not very good for entry level due to their lack of training for client service associate

headline: Everyday the firm is working to get better
pros:
- The firm is clearly taking the right steps to reposition itself as a premier global wealth/asset manager
- Unwinding capital intensive positions in the Investment Bank is of utmost importance
- Streamlining of middle and back office support is key to lower expenses
- Good people, although the firm should take advantage of the buyers market in terms of talent and acquire leading people via competitive compensation.
cons:
- Huge, bureaucratic institution
- Everything passes through Switzerland
- Slow moving, reactionary

headline: Too bureaucratic
pros:
- Lots of smart people
- Interesting businesses
- Smaller team mean easier to rise
cons:
- Too bureaucratic
- Management not open enough to new ideas
- Too great a flux of senior management.

headline: Still a great company to work for, but not the safest and stable job
pros:
Great people, very international work environment. Very good graduate trainee program that gives you great exposure. Chances available to work abroad,
Better benefits (401k matches and vacation days) than most other companies.
cons:
Being loyal to the company doesn't pay off anymore.  Horrible internal politics. Very difficult to move to other desks internally.
Compensation has been on the decline for years and has been very heavily impacted by trading losses and fines,

headline: Good global bank refocused in Wealth Management business
pros: Good culture, very international, promotes leadership and hard working bankers
cons:
Need to upgrade IT infrastructure 
Lots of silos across divisions
Lack of clear strategy due to too many senior management changes
Pay is awful

headline: Bland, troubled
pros: Some smart people on the IB side. Great ppl in the affinity groups.
cons: Super hierarchical, conservative. Grey. Sexist culture.

headline: Global career opportunities
pros:
Truly global employer with a strong home base
Eager to move on and be ahead of the game / innovative
Great for people who want to deliver
cons:
Reputation after financial crisis yet tampered
Set backs are still possible

headline: Decent place to work
pros:
- Great Benefits
- Good pay
cons: - Promotions are not always fair

headline: good culture
pros: great culture, most friendly trading desk on street
cons: you're not going to get paid at market level

headline: UBS IB has gone to hell in a handbasket and now sucks as much as it's possible to.
pros: Virtually none any more, the place isn't what it was.
cons: The investment bank is going down the tubes, thousands of people are losing their jobs. Meanwhile, those who are left have to work extra hard with poorly funded, planned and maintained systems.

headline: Challenging but Just matters is a good team and a good manager
pros:
- If team is nice its a nice place to be.
- Growth seems stagnant.
cons:
- Work-life balance gets for a toss at times.
- Global model results in late night calls and stretches the schedule

headline: great people, too much politics
pros: great network of people, awesome learning and travel opportunities, fair salary
cons: high management not listening to the employees, too much politics

headline: Working for UBS
pros: Working with some great people: experienced, knowledgeable, dedicated and willing to help when needed. The ability to work on a diverse range of projects. The chance to gain experience working on some very interesting systems.
cons: Working with some difficult people: aggressive, hostile and generally unfriendly. Poor work-life balance.  Little job security. No excess capacity to innovate and as a consequence most time and effort is spent keeping the lights on. Very risk adverse.

headline: Directionless with marginal promise of success
pros:
- Strong existing platform
- Great knowledgeable employees with strong skill sets
cons:
- Sense of strategy and direction have been lost a while back. Seems, on a recurrent basis, a new strategy props up and dissolves quickly along with the people that are part of the strategy - People running around like "headless" chicken
- Too top heavy

headline: Management blames everyone
pros: good compensation when you start (including life insurance, pension, etc)
cons:
After a few years at UBS, you realise how it's all about politics and people only care about saving themselves. expect to get blamed by everything, even worse when its out of your competence/skillset and team.
very bad handling contractors (force them to take leave then fire them while they are on leave, etc)

headline: A giant company with both good and bad legacy
pros: Well paid, willing to invest on graduate trainees
cons: Being extremely conservative on technology compared to other major IBs; people somehow prone to secure their jobs instead of striving for better quality in IT. Headquarter in Zurich has too much impact on other regions like APAC.

headline: Used to be a great  place, not any more. Top management heavy.
pros:
Training opportunities are good. 
Flexibility in working hours.
cons:
Top management is too heavy. Often driving initiatives in different directions.
5 time management systems to enter time into.
Avg salaries.
Low bonuses.
Lots of incompetent people. Thus, funnels work to few individuals. 
Outsourced a lot of work already to remote locations.

headline: Positive restructuring in senior management.
pros:
I have found the environment to be meritorious for good people with good ideas.  It is easy to look good if you want to improve things, given the large amounts of inefficient processes that need to be addressed.

The issues with the financial markets have made the company focus on promoting internally people that are looking to construct a better business.
cons: One has to accept that there are poor processes in these businesses with many legacy systems, so you have to be able to come to negotiate some parts of the organisation that lack efficiency.

headline: IT
pros: Great Management and work life balance; your contributions can really make a positive difference. I work on a great team with very knowledgeable and talented people.  My Management provide full support to get through challenging assignments.
cons: Budget cuts (like everywhere else) present challenges, but even in times of zero spend, once can achieve better system capabilities through innovation and challenging the status quo.

headline: Slow career progression
pros: Good to have a big name on your resume. Grasp the sense of being at a truly global firm.
cons: Career progression is too slow, at least at the bottom. Not fully supportive of lateral movement early in your career.

headline: Tough TImes
pros: Big company, international, brand name.
cons: Not the most mobility, bank going through tough times and lay offs make for a rough working culture

headline: Few interesting departments, very stiff culture
pros: Access to research, active portfolio advisory teams are great, client-focused
cons: Stiff culture, not a lot of diversity, difficult to see different areas of the bank

headline: On the Path to FA
pros: If you work with the right FA, you can really learn a lot.  I am preparing to start the New FA program, and have been working as a CSA.  Sometimes the FAs can be oblivious, but overall everyone works together well.
cons: Sometimes, the focus is not people based.  Obviously the overall goal is to bring in assets, but sometimes the FAs and the firm forgets that those assets belong to human beings.

headline: Good place to work
pros: Nice people, good technology and not stupid hours
cons: Not the best total comp. in the city. promotions system not fair

headline: Challenging to start during the meltdown. Great place to start, poor place to make a career.
pros: Good training. The branch manager and some brokers were helpful if you did the hard work like cold calling and brought in the clients.
cons: Corporate environment. Lots of options of the table. Making money the first, second and third priorities. Customer came in when it was convenient or when compliance dictated.

headline: Management is overrated and struggling for power
pros: Benefits are great and hours
cons: Management, lower paying then any other investment firm

headline: Times they are a changing...
pros: Global scope, diverse product scope
cons: Very unclear what hey want to be and how to get there

headline: If you want to make a career, avoid it. Company in bad shape, with very poor culture / bitter people
pros:
+ Global group
+ Good Swiss Bank (Retail + Corporate) and decent Wealth Management business (for now)
cons:
- Horrible corporate culture and ambiance, in particular in management-related functions
- Shrinking / sinking ship, with tons of legacy issues impacting current employees
- High bureaucracy
- Few bright people, overshadowed by tons of sinister individuals 
- Very hierarchical and non-meritocratic (incl. salaries)

headline: Mixed bag
pros: Company culture is good. depending on the area/team, you have a chance of keeping a reasonable work/life balance.
cons: Internal mobility is limited. Appraisal process is changing all the time, still haven't found a way to make it objective.

headline: Bulge Bracket firm with all attendant pros and cons, but access to great people
pros: The ability to network with great people internally and externally
cons: Poor middle management; overly and incompetently bureaucratic; internal rivalry and duplicity

headline: Stable, good work environment, poor compensation
pros: Stable, good work environment, work-life balance
cons: poor compensation, questionable future of firm

headline: Good place to work mostly
pros: Benefits and work/life balance. It used to take the company way to long to get rid of under achievers. This was greatly improved.
cons: Poor bonus over the last few years. The bank really needs to improve its promotion process. Very hard to move up in rank even when you receive an excellent review.

headline: This firm needs some change
pros: Good pay for entry-level and flexible life
cons: No pay increase in tough years

headline: Nd
pros: work/life balance and some people
cons:
low pay
too political
beauracracy and too many bosses

headline: Good so far..
pros:
Good work life balance
Lots to learn and ample career growth opportunities.
Work culture is also very good.
cons:
Many management changes in the past few years.
Talent retention hasn't been good.

headline: Interesting, but it's what you make of it
pros:
- Given a lot of responsibility right away
- Good Work/Life balance to study for tests (Series 7 & 66, CFA, GMAT)
- Opportunities to meet with different wholesalers from different industries
cons:
- Work can sometimes get repetitive
- Difficult to grow out of the position, unless you want to become an advisor
- No training for analysts when initially hired

headline: Registered Client Service Associate
pros: Great people to work with.  Friendly Staff and quality clients make working everyday interesting and fun.  Good Benefits with Health, Vision, Dental and 401K.  Legal too!
cons: Low salary, rare raises or bonuses.

headline: Great institution
pros: Join a team with great expectations
cons: Too many swiss employees abroad

headline: Director
pros: UBS has a global presence and in general there is a good level of colloboration among the global teams. It is a good place to get global exposure.
cons: The culture and values of the firm are key challenges. Leadership credibility is low across the organization and at all levels.

headline: Good Work Life Balance
pros:
Work life balance
Easy going colleagues
cons: Feels like they struggle to compete with the big Investment Banks

headline: politics politics politics
pros: global reach, good for career starter, there are competent people
cons: loads of internal politics, permanent job cuts and downsizing, middle managers pursuing their own agenda and protecting aggressively their own fiefs above the banks interests, more and more compliance

headline: Good place to work but too many scandals over the last few years
pros: Great work environment and opportunities, extremely interesting work
cons: Too many scandals, senior management churn

headline: Good Experience
pros: I learned a lot about people management, cost control, risk control, key performance indicators, service level agreements, offshoring, stakeholder mapping, project management, and process improvement
cons: Investment bank is downsizing considerably over the next 6-18 months.  If you can make it through it should be a decent place to be again.

headline: UBS
pros: It is a good company where you can develope a great job carreer within a profesional work environment
cons:
International
Good paid
Work Environment
Skills gained

headline: Valuations expert in financial instruments
pros: Good employer for its people.  A great bank for Switzerland.
cons: tough times are there for investment banks

headline: Analyst
pros: Great help grow and mature. Learned a great deal.
cons: Nothing is easy to get understanding.

headline: Did not learn a lot during my internship
pros:
-relaxed
-nice team
-laid back and relaxed environment
cons:
-lacking good company culture
-no structure

headline: Gone down hill since 2007 but still better than working for Tesco's ;)
pros: Work life balance. Pay is better than other industries.
cons: Senior management generally poor and self interested.

headline: Client Advisor Assistant - Not a place for the ambitious
pros:
Get to work with experienced Bankers
Good work/ life balance - not ideal if you are ambitious
cons: There's alot of them - WM business is very old school, and opportunities are few, blame culture if things go wrong.

headline: Research Analyst
pros: Long but regular hours, working with the best analysts in the street, strong cash equity business, great collaboration among colleagues, great atmosphere on the research floor (except during bonus season)
cons: poor bonus, talent mgmt could be better (what s the point of training and spending money on ppl to let them go 2 years after they start)

headline: Used to be a great place to work
pros: Great place to start your career. Their training program is one of the best on the street. Down to earth people.
cons: Recent losses have given the company a bad name.

headline: Managment in branch goal based
pros: Great co-workers very good regional managment team
cons: Bad upper managment inconsistant policy of goals vs. client service

headline: Software development in fixed income
pros: Good projects and enjoyable work
cons: Project being closed down, time for change

headline: Generally good culture depending on group you're in
pros:
- client-oriented
- autonomy with career path
- client-facing opportunities
- supportive of education & certifications
cons:
- underpaid
- pay freezes and small raises

headline: It's best days are in the past
pros: Generally a nice atmosphere with friendly people. Traders are mostly pleasant too.
cons: People are often hired and promoted for being nice rather than being good. Quality of people is hit and miss.

headline: Investment Banking Analyst
pros: Fulsome experience, significant opportunities to learn
cons: Crushing lifestyle, difficult to achieve work/life balance

headline: UBS WM is an extremely professional, efficient, rewarding and accomplished financial services institution
pros: Professional, respectful, self-motivated, customer-centric coworkers, rewarding pay and benefits, and lots of opportunities for further development, training and networking.
cons: The only downside is the size. It is difficult to network outside of your department or branch.

headline: They have lost it
pros: Good pay, good people, nice environment
cons: Senior management (IT) is drifting, going nowhere, losing it for good

headline: FX BUC Internship
pros:
- Responsibilities from day one
- Collaborative environment
- Diverse workplace
cons: - I enjoyed my internship and have nothing negative to say

headline: Brilliant people, too much bureaucracy
pros: People here are smart and nice working atmosphere.
cons: Too much bureaucracy, hard to get things done.

headline: courteous co-workers, positve working environment
pros:
decisive, diverse, 
efficient in execution, 
always aims to provide high quality services, 
competitive renumeration package,
much efforts were made to stay compliant
cons:
need to give equal opportunities to non-swiss workers,
"arrogant" senior management,
unable to protect reputation,
allowed too much redundancy to exist within the company

headline: Overall good experience
pros:
Quick money and trade clearing.
Access to many different products.
Prestige of Swiss Banking.
Great marketing brand and very visible.
Great mobile technology.
cons: The US Management does a terrible job of communicating with all of their employees, the feel is that you can call the US headquarters and ask 10 different questions 10 different times and get a different answer each and every time.  Also, top management is too involved with one particular political party and I believe that is poor judgement as our leaders represent a large diversity of employees.

headline: Operations Review
pros: There is a lot of mobility within Operations at UBS. Trade Support has a close working relationship with sales trading.
cons: Compensation has been hard hit by the crisis and current environment. Mobility to the front office has decreased substantially over the years.

headline: Associate Director
pros: laid back, easy going people, stressfree
cons: no money, networked people get promotions

headline: Maybe a good place prior to 2008
pros: big firm benefits (non-comp. benefits) - paid time off is good starting with AD ranks.
cons: Pay, pay, and did i say pay (unless you're in the right crowd with right rep or in a revenue type role you're good but everyone else you're at the mercy of a  Swiss excel formula for pay).

headline: Lack of consistent, long-term strategic plan
pros: The people were always nice in the investment bank.  Once you know where you fit in, most people will help you navigate the bureaucracy.
cons: Lack of career growth, planning, execution, or support.  Most people do not change positions or move upwards.  The lack of movement creates stagnation and dearth of new ideas.  Hard to change when no one is thinking out of the box.

headline: Diverse work environment with a global presence
pros: UBS has a very strong name brand and a global presence. As one of the world's largest wealth managers, it offers great employee benefits and 401k matching contributions. While certain groups may not meet the same level of diversity the firm boasts as a whole, UBS is recognized as a market leader in every financial hub around the world.
cons: UBS tends to have a very conservative work environment. Management is very concerned with maintaining the brand image and reputation. Domiciled in Switzerland, UBS tends to adhere to much higher risk standards than most of its competitors.

headline: UBS Internship
pros: Great culture, nice people, good working hours roughly 9-6
cons: Work is not so challenging for interns

headline: Network engineer
pros: Overall compensation is good compared to other places.  Work hours are long but there are rewards.  Flexible hours including working from home is supported.
cons: There is limited growth for network engineers. Promotions are very hard to get after a certain level.  Management needs to respect and treat all employees fairly.

headline: Pathetic work/life balance, average compensation benefits.
pros: You might be lucky if you are in those departments of the bank which are the basic drivers of business like Weath Management. Not much scope if you are in the investment banking dept.
cons:
Working on old and crap homegrown frameworks and technologies! Management expects you to work for 50+ hours regularly. On our team there had more managers than developers but the expectations to deliver was like they were developers too. Everyone seems to want to become a manager and no one wishes to write code. Heavens forbid if you are in the Investment Banking IT dept. The Investment Banking business as of now is a non profitable business area, so expect meagre pay raises and bonuses. Absolutely not worthy of an investment bank. Don't take up a job in the Investment Banking IT dept unless they pay you extremely well for sacrificing on a decent work/life balance working on old technologies.Full time employees in the team were leaving regularly every few months. Most of the work is done by the offshore vendors' onsite resources who are offcourse much cheaper.

Mgmt had layed off a couple of full timers on the team (offcourse as a larger decision to increase shareholder wealth). Was pretty brutal. You get taken into a meeting room, are told the news and are asked to leave the premises then and there. Doesn't matter if you have been working there for 6 months or 3 years, you won't get to say good bye to your colleagues.I guess it is the "Wall Street" culture, so can't blame one company for that.

headline: Bureaucratic European bank
pros: Talent is sporadic.  Top contributors rise to the top and will really shine.  Senior management in Equities is the best its been in years.
cons: Navigating the deadwood and bureaucracy can be overwhelming and stifiling.  Too much turnover and strategic changes.

headline: Poor company culture and incompetent middle management
pros:
- Worked with a few talented individuals who are equally disgruntled by the poor culture
- Competitive salary for back office employees
cons:
- Middle management micromanages, lies, threatens and mistreats their subjects
- Employees are overworked (constantly work nights and weekends) and undervalued
- Excessive and unnecessary politics and in-fighting between FTEs and consultants (even at entry-level)
- Top management discourages honest feedback 
- Low company morale breeds many disgruntled employees and leads to poor performance

headline: Overall good company
pros: Good environment, nice colleagues, competitive salary, good brand name
cons: Lousy boss, poor career growth opportunity

headline: not too bad
pros: nice people, relaxed, helpful people
cons: not much opportunities to  grow, slow growth, some are too hung up on rank

headline: Great place to work !!
pros: Good work environment and very fast paced
cons: Many policies change a lot of times not always in the best interest of the business

headline: Project Manager
pros: Work-life balance, Friendly Peope/good culture
cons:
Old building
damaged reputation/brand
limited training available

headline: Wealth management is not what it was 10 years ago
pros: Looks great on a resume
cons: Poor work environment. Lots of time wasted by employees.

headline: Good company
pros: Good team, good opportunities, satisfied
cons: Concerns about job security at the moment

headline: bad place to work
pros: if you are happy person and want to keep this way - keep away from switzerland
cons: grumpy, unhappy people - particularly management

headline: Great company, very little training though
pros:
Decent working environment
Relatively relaxed hours
Consensus-based approach
cons:
Devolved and fragmented decision making process
Little on the job training

headline: Great introduction to the banking world
pros: UBS is a good bank to work for if you're looking for work / life balance. They're going through some big restructuring changes so there's not much opportunity at the moment but still they are treating their staff well and keeping everyone well informed
cons: Not so great training opportunities, possible because of the markets over the last few years. The need to improve process and technology to really move forward and I hope they see this in the next few months

headline: UBS, has alot of potential, always disapoints
pros: There is great talent, alot of room to ascend
cons: Tend to underpay, and systems are awful

headline: Enriching though stressful experience
pros: Senior management very supportive and encourage learning
cons: The hours can be long and the work can be stressful if not handled properly

headline: It used to be a great place
pros:
People-oriented culture
Flexible working conditions
Used to be a good brand
cons:
Little-to-no training, development
No investment in internal people, little to no future
Hire from outside
No more People-oriented culture
Employees are just pawns waiting to be outsourced

headline: very good experience
pros:
Excellent exposure
Worked on bleeding edge stuff
Great people
Nice work environment
cons:
Company going through some shaky times..
Empl

headline: Currently unable to retain or attract talent, too much turnover
pros: Large organization with a lot of opportunities across functions and international opportunities
cons: Too much turnover, loss of culture, team spirit and morale.  Instead of fostering organic growth and promote within, everyone is trying to protect their own interest instead of working towards the advancement of the team/department/company... It's difficult to work towards a common goal when no one has security within the Company at any level.

headline: It was the best of times it was the worst of times
pros: I really enjoyed the people I met there and the network of financial professionals I built for myself.  I was able to grow as a professional here, they provided great training.  There are many opportunities for growth and mentoring available.
cons: They offered me a new position several times and then took it away because of budget reasons.  This was extremely frustrating and disappointing, especially because it was officially offered to me.

headline: Work hard and don't expect a "Thank you!"
pros: Many advantages as a global company
cons: too many strategy changes during the last years

headline: Management inspires the employees and works hard to communicate their visions and goals. Great place to work.
pros:
Great management
100% commitment from top down to improve UBS Americas
Client focus
Great support for employees
Minimal bureaucratic interference
cons: Technology platform is dated due to years underinvestment, but recent commitments and massive investments have been made to make UBS competitive.

headline: Accountant
pros: nice atmosphere, good job opportunituies
cons: too high staff turnover in the Zurich branch

headline: Summer Intern
pros: Open culture and helpful MD and analysts
cons: Very tired job sometimes not very efficient

headline: Nice place to work at the time, but environment has changed
pros:
Good healthcare benefits
Lots of diversity networks
cons:
Low salary
Long hours
Culture of "talking" rather than "doing"

headline: Opportunities to experience multiple locations.
pros: With so many locations you can move around to different locations.
cons: Management varies greatly across divisions and teams.  Getting a good manager is the luck of the draw as there is no real standard around management.  While employees are reviewed managers are not.

headline: Lots of transition
pros: Some very smart people, interesting clients, global access, strong presence in Asia, especially China.  Outstanding wealth management franchise.  Strong in asset management too.
cons: Not committed to investment banking.  Too much change in leadership - talent at that level is not that strong.  Completely risk-averse which makes it difficult to make money in a market where some risk is essential.

headline: Relationship Manager
pros: Nice colleagues, great working environment
cons: Decreasing trust of clients and decreasing staff moral due to cutting jobs and outsourcing to Eastern Europe and India

headline: Investment Banking Analyst
pros: Still a well established banking platform in Asia
cons: Consistent underperformance across IB divisions

headline: Lackluster experience at a failing financial institution
pros: Still a reputable name in the industry
cons: Little deal-flow, low morale, sub-par pay

headline: look for something better
pros: Nice place to work fresh out of school
cons: This company is a revolving door

headline: Once a great place to grow an IT a career...no longer the case.
pros: Great work/life balance can be achieved.
cons: Cost cutting on a massive rise.  Without significant new opportunities, career advancement typically doesn't happen from within.

headline: Workplace Cultural Fit Adaptation and The Competitive Advantage
pros: Globalisation has made this worldwide organization into a more collaborative and diverse, informed workforce that seeks to deploy a framework that goes beyond normal efforts to help accomodate, assimilate, and accelerate any new hires, internally or externally. Recently, the relationships between people and systems were managed through a close coupled environment allowing the individual employee the capacity to work at the specific task in which they specialize but there was always the growing potential to shifting to a loose-coupled environment to allow the possibility of progressive employee improvement and contribution beyond internal agility and individual flexibility in the workplace.
cons: Conversely, the competition among wealth management businesses and increased regulatory climate has forced this large organization to seek a cultural fit with its employees that defines how they feel about the organization's attitude as a whole and how they communicate with each other. A more peripheral vision and alignment of key stakeholders( read employees) as well as the pay and reward mechanisms of the current culture can and should nurture the fundamental changes needed to effect a change that will involve employee self-accountability and commitment to succeed.

headline: Eh, so so
pros: Plenty of intelligent people to learn from
cons: Lots of greed and plenty of people removed from the real world

headline: Use to be a nice place.
pros: Number of paid offs and mandatory two week vacation. Respected brand name and good medical benefits. Work life balance still better than other finance organization.
cons: Extremely bureaucratic with tardy process. Management is putting lots of pressure on delivery with minimum resources. Yearly review process is complex and non transparent.

headline: UBS rocks but not always and could
pros: Great upper management, good working environment.
cons: Little people have little value.

headline: Technologically deficient and bureaucratic
pros: Entry level positions offer good salaries and benefits.  Fantastic if working directly with clients in branches or offered position directly into the Investment Banking segment (not good in lower corporate office functions - advancement rare and not based on performance despite what all the intranet sites say).
cons: Rigid hierarchial structure that stifles the improvement of internal procedures that, if structure were flattened, would create cost efficiencies and more transparency.  Instead, higher positions (higher in salary and name, but certainly not because of efficiency which is ironic for a Swiss firm) are maintained and lower positions cut or outsourced when a quarter gets too tight.

headline: Good environment
pros: Many nice peoples and enjoy the working environment
cons: A lot of peoples keep walking around

headline: Fast career progression
pros:
- Top 3 banks in the world
- Excellent pension fund
- Worldwide career opportunities
- Swiss made
cons: I think that the turnover in any managing positions should be increased in order to improve the dynamic of different teams and divisions

headline: Great bank to work for!
pros: Working hours, career potential and rewards - all great
cons: Have not had any bad experiences yet

headline: Decent place to work, but has a confusing organizational structure
pros: Has one of the best base compensation plans, work-life balance, and offers excellent international exposure.
cons: Company has complex and confusing internal organizational structure, highly bureaucratic processes, and numerous overlapping IT systems providing similar functionality.   Staff are expected to execute multiple roles and support for staff outside of the front office is poor.

headline: Great global for to work for, however, challenged by bad media headlines and lack luster profits.
pros:
Good people.
Strong name recognition.
Internal mobility for strong performers willing to try new challenges.
cons:
Headquarters is in Weehawken, New Jersey.
Pay needs adjustment.
New management team (that joined from Merrill Lynch in 2009/2010) is naive.

headline: A good company to work for
pros: Good work culture and talented people
cons: A bit bureacratic these days

headline: UBS WMIT
pros: work life balance, good pay
cons: too much legacy n process

headline: Downhill
pros: Work life balance can be good.  Accommodating management.
cons: Performance reviews are a farce - objectives are set and can be met while performance reviews are relative to your peers.  This leads to subjective reviews where management favorites are rewarded.  Culture is poor as employees who are part of a cost center are viewed as a liability as opposed to value add to the organization.

headline: Could be more structured
pros: Met a lot of people. easy to talk to higher-ups because they will make time for you
cons: Not a very structured program. a lot of free time

headline: Great Job
pros:
Can make a lot of money if you perform well
Nice work environment
Jeans everyday and free beer on fridays
cons: Ruthless bosses can cut you quickly

headline: in general good culture and client oriented
pros: nice people, culture is very client oriented
cons: inefficient system, limited visibility if in a satellite office

headline: Just started
pros: great company, laid back and very persistent in the field of wealth management and financial services.
cons: So far no cons, still somewhat new to the job.

headline: Getting on the right foot
pros: Recent turnover means there are often opportunities for junior people to take on larger roles. While this is not applied across the board, someone who is sharp and opportunistic can often make things happen for themselves.
cons: By the same token, high turnover means that bankers do not have as much traction with clients relative to their competitors. Frustratingly, those people who build the strongest relationships all seem to leave after some time, leading to the perception that the firm has a rotating door.

headline: A very supportive company.
pros: Room for advancement, training programs
cons: Base salary tends to be low for support staff

headline: Salary UBS CH Zurich Business Analyst
pros: environement, salary, bonus, cash, vacation
cons: reputation, ubs, bank, burokratie, l

headline: Some good and some could be better!
pros:
Good package
Helpful managers
Rotation across relatively doable
cons:
Old and legacy systems
You don't really get a feeling of organizational culture

headline: Great company when I first started, much has changed
pros: Great entry level position within the marketing department. Most of the work revolves around project and relationship management. Given the brand, it can be a little tough to truly push the envelope for getting marketing collateral created. However, when big projects are completed and you [hopefully] get feedback on how it helped an FA build their business, it can be extremely rewarding. Great colleagues help to make the work environment less stressful
cons: Pay is definitely not competitive with the rest of the financial services industry (verified with numerous friends, ex-colleagues and recruiters with knowledge of similar job roles within the industry), too much emphasis is placed on pleasing the FA and not necessarily remaining compliant with Firm/industry regulations, career options within your department can be limited

headline: A little chaotic but a rock solid stable bank
pros:
Rock solid stable bank with great capital ratios and international presence
Customers love the brand and like doing business
Some very good people
cons:
Bureaucratic processes sometimes lead to confusion
Unable to take a consistent long term view
Management has changed man times - leading to changing strategy and focus

headline: Worked as analyst in the Investment Banking Division, Hyderabad -India
pros:
UBS is a well known global brand name which definitely boosts the professional credentials. 
Access to variety of databases and opportunity to work for some of the biggest transactions in the investment banking space
cons:
Very clinical approach for positions at analyst levels which hardly gives any flexibility to employees
Long working hours and repetitive work

headline: Play the game and you will go far !
pros: Lots of opportunity to move, and if you play the game you can progress. Probably the best place I have worked for training and courses and if you want to take on more work they will heap it on you, but you have to perform, and as long as you fit the profile you will go far.
cons: Its all about playing the game @ UBS. You make the right noises to the right people you will go far. They take you for granted after a year or two so if you haven't been promoted or looked after in that time I would say move on. This was probably the worst firm I have seen for management self promotion, and people being entirely self motivated for their own gain and to hell with everyone else.

headline: This is a company in rapid decline
pros: There were a lot of positive things about this company before 2007, but sadly I don't have anything positive to say about this company today.
cons:
1) The only lever available to the company is "reduce costs". The current staffing level is beyond "cut to the bone"/at the stage of "removing limbs".
2) Vast amounts of talented people (quants, front office, IT, control functions) have either walked out the door or wiggled into getting laid off. Management is disconnected from the reality of the work that is required to keep the company running and constantly dumps more onto staff without concern for people's existing workload. This is not how you make a challenging and stimulating environment.
3) UBS has an uncanny ability to be in the press constantly for one or more scandals/lawsuits.
4) The execution of the stated culture and values is disingenuous.
5) Practically everyone I spoke to when I resigned told me they were also looking for another job.

headline: Little intrinsic motivation & employees not valued
pros: Salaries are on the high end of scale compared to remaining industries in Switzerland. As a global player, there are a lot of opportunities to gain international experience and further your career.
cons: Greed and lack of respect for employees are the predominant factors in the corporate culture. Performance review process and talent management programs are not transparent and hence of little true value.

headline: General info on UBS CH
pros: The workers are friendly if you can speak German and get into a good crowd. The pay is quite good. Some of the managers are very good. Try to move to other countries whilst with UBS, it's easier to get promoted in UK and USA than in CH or Asia.
cons: The HR recruiting department are incompetent, otherwise HR quite good. Most Swiss employees are very narrow minded and only lookout for themselves and other Swiss people. Some managers are terrible and have little management skills or courses to their name.

headline: The FA's are great, but the internship program itself is lackluster.
pros: The atmosphere is great; can't beat working in a skyscraper in Downtown Chicago. The people are also really quality.
cons: The intern gatherings were mostly seminar styled gatherings, and there isn't much of an opportunity to meet more than a few interns over the course of the internship. It would be better if the interns could be gathered every once in a while for the sake of mingling.

headline: Review of UBS culture and compensation
pros: Review of UBS culture and compensation
cons: low compensation and low morale

headline: Overall positive culture, collegiate rather than confrontational
pros: good work life balance there
cons: Perceived less compensation than competitors

headline: Terrible Company with no exit opportunities
pros: Nothing good about this company, avoid it at all costs
cons: MD was a jerk, no exit opportunities and no bonuses

headline: Pride and Prejudice
pros: This bank is still one of the biggest asset managers in the world. For people interested in Banking in the entire variety in products and clients this is still the place to be. There is also a "free lunch", because due to the natural flows and strengths, many things are easier to assail than for most of our competitors.
cons: After several moral and actual setbacks, this bank (even more than the rest of the industry) bank a firm that mainly deals with risk aversion, compliance frameworks and process adherence. The amount of administrative overhead added the last couple of years seriously inhibits the agility, and many many things cannot be done any longer or take forever to accomplish.

headline: Analyst in UBS Summer intern
pros: Great, storngly recommended for all that are interested
cons: None from my point of view

headline: Competitive Bank with aggressive staff
pros: Bank has good connections, and business partners.  The connection into wealth management add numerous advantages.  Its trying to improve its risk structure in the right direction
cons: Overly aggressive atmosphere with competing teams of people for same job.  Systems are bad with efforts being made to improve.  Connectivity of systems is very limited.  To much upper middle management.

headline: Great place for highly motivated and ambitious up and comers
pros: Management supports mobility and career development. There are always new opportunities and those who are hungry will get them
cons: The firm has been going through rough times which has taken a toll on hard working employees. There seems to be a fair amount of turnover at the management levels.

headline: Learnt from boss a lot
pros: Learnt from boss a lot, and he is very kind.
cons: didnt get to know other employees

headline: Great opportunities
pros:
- Work/Life balance
- Great transversal career opportunities
- Competitive salary
- Very structured (HR, career development, presentation templates, IT tools)
cons: - Difficult to quickly implement ideas

headline: VERY UNSATISFYING AND CONFUSED
pros: European, strong presence in Australia
cons: Doesnt understand risk well, very silo based,inflexible, old boys network of croneyism

headline: Interesting and challenging career opportunities
pros: Challenges, environment, culture, team, career opportunities
cons: work-life-balance, challenging industry, volatile market environment, insecure future

headline: Great!
pros: Opportunity to learn and grow professionally and personally. Ability to work from home when necessary. The people, the work environment, the global community, learning to appreciate the different cultural work ethics and how they interact with and affect those in the US.
cons: The hours can sometimes be brutal. Some people are concerned only about their careers to the detriment of their working relationship with others. The line manager "silo" mentality can be challenging to work with. The banking industry's general tendency toward criminal behavior at the upper management level when the government relaxes its enforcement of regulations.

headline: Happy To Be Here
pros: great company to work for
cons: declining industry fundamentals not a positive

headline: Six managers in four years doing the same work
pros: Used to pay well, don't now
cons: Secretive, cut positions without regard to quality, Swiss salespeople broke US laws

headline: Awesome!
pros: Lots of chances to learn, interact, apply knowledge and influence and improve processes. Great dynamic environment where things happen and change all the time.
cons: Preoccupation with protecting risk to the company, but lacking clear communication to affected parties what needs to be done. Sometimes, a bit too much change for people to follow as well. Career progression can also depend a lot on where in the organization you currently are. Most doors are open for people who are already in the front-line or in sensitive IB areas.

headline: Executive assistant
pros:
1. higher pay
2. different business 
3.learning more IB
cons: 1. less warm of people here

headline: Overall it was a positive experience but I found the decision-making process very bureaucratic.
pros: Team-based environment and cross-functional support were the positive aspects of working at UBS. As a junior advisor, I found it extremely helpful to have a team of product experts and other advisors involved in my client meetings. It was a great way to learn from more seasoned colleagues.
cons: The training session when I first started was very ineffective in my opinion. I learned how to do perform my daily tasks largely on-the-job.

headline: Operation Specialist
pros: I enjoyed working with my co-workers. I learned so much at this job.
cons: Trained young people to take employees positions who was there for 10 years or more

headline: Lots of restructuring means clever people leave.
pros: Relaxed atmosphere (team dependent), interesting work Seem to care about career progression for employees.
cons: Poor requirements given for projects. Restructuring often leads to orphan projects.

headline: It's been one of the most inspiring houses to have worked as an analyst..
pros: Great minds, global team coverage, smart sales people.
cons: Too London centric, had reputational issues in recent years.

headline: UBS to work or not to work
pros: The company seems to be on the right direction strategy wise. focusing on their wealth management and limiting the investment banking unit. they bringing and promoting the right poeple
cons: The company still have a lot of internal controls, especially in the Finance department. Furthermore, the company is not integrated well in regards to the services they provide to clients. each unit is working alone without proper communication and cooperation with other units ti achieve efficiency and better costumer service.

headline: Opportunity with hard work

headline: Interesting but cut throat

salary
work interesting
goods team work
work like balance is correct
follow the sun support
middle management layer good
decent canteen
cons:
politically charged especially at the moment becuase of cuts
chaotic at best of times. Overall lack of good process management

headline: Great experience, good culture
pros: UBS Investment Bank has emerged as a major IB player in the last 7-10 years. Especially they have a very strong market position in Asia including M&A and capital markets. UBS is known for its great culture with emphasis on teamwork. They go the extra mile to take care of their employees
cons: UBS has was hit hard by the financial crisis then then rogue trader. Business outlook has been negatively effected. Also on a more employee level, there is not as much training opportunites as the US firms

headline: UBS is a good and pleasant workplace
pros: UBS is a good and pleasant workplace
cons: some processes too slow and bumpy

headline: Quality Assurance Test Engineer
pros:
Good work life balance.
Great people.
Good work environment.
cons:
Need to manage own growth.
Supportive at one's own risk.
Helps if one has mentor.

headline: Could be a lot better if mgt improved...
pros: If you can find a solid team to join and work out revenue sharing agreement with them it can be much better. Don't count on help from the management for this.
cons:
Associate staff gets paid like crap and are overworked & underappreciated. 

No help from management for career progression.

headline: Lack of leadership and massive bureaucracy leads to paralyzed IT Operations teams.
pros: Nice people, pretty good culture, active in local community.
cons: The nice side covers quite a lot of back-stabbing and character assassination.  Also, the lack of strong, clear vision and leadership results in a paralyzed work force, not just in IT but throughout the Bank.

headline: Great company
pros: Great location in weehawken, easy commute from manhattan.
