headline: Two month in UBS
pros: Great experience, quickly bonded with the 5 members of my team. Workload was extremely manageable and actually enjoyable, salary is good
cons: most of time i have to work after till 9 pm...........no time for myself except on weekend

headline: Fantastic - Great experience and enjoyable
pros: Dynamic, financially rewarding, well-structured and fantastic training ground
cons: Competitive among peers and talent pool is extremely large. Makes it difficult to be outstanding.

headline: They used to be one of the best but has changed drastically
pros:
Swiss Culture - Friendly people in general
Health Benefits (some plans pay 100% after co-pay)
Work-Life balance YMMV (Different teams have different views on this)
cons:
- Morale is very low at the moment
- Management too busy trying to save their own jobs
- Lack of focus on employees
- Little or no internal mobility
- No tuition re-imbursement
- Internal training has gone down to near 0

headline: Great company in its heyday... but things have changed
pros: - overall quite satisfied. with regard to comp, responsibility, conditions etc
cons:
- hit or miss with line managers. bad line managers seem to be tolereated and they create an acidic environment 
- performance revoiews and forced ranking. very nasty politics going on
- culture has been diluted and now resembles nothing of what reallymade UBS a great place to work. very sad really...

headline: UBS loosing its reputation as attractive employer
pros: Pension fund agreement still attractive compared to competitors
cons: Constant re-organisations absorbe tremendous resource capacity, not leaving much to focus on actual business and customers

headline: UBS Investment Center
pros:
UBS has a strong brand
Can get licensed (Series 7, 66)
Easy work and 8:30-5:30 hours
Most co-workers are enjoyable and young
cons:
Horrible work environment, no room to grow and horrible pay.  Morale is extremely low.  
This is a call center and is the bottom of the barrel at UBS.  The Investment Center takes everyone's trash and management is full of Yes-Men who offer no value. As a CSA your work is mundane and boring you gain no transferable skills and if you get promoted to a "Financial Advisor" you become a call center customer service rep.
Management is a joke.  They play favorites, do not reward hard work and are unprofessional.  Days go by without your work getting approved or processed by the operations manager.   If you do not agree with management they will hold a grudge.  Management will also make it difficult for you to make any type of internal transfer within UBS.  Management will be very spiteful and make sure you do not leave.
No one cares about clients.  The Investment Center is around to just collect fees.  No discount, nothing waived.

headline: Quite Satisfied
pros:
1) work life balance
2) Compensation Plans
3) Health Insurance benefits
cons: 1) Growth Opportunites in some departments

headline: Ok experience
pros: Good teams do exist inside the company
cons: hard to find these teams!

headline: mismanaged for a decade
pros: Most of the best advisors have left, but there are a few who came over in the past 5-7 years that are worth knowing.
cons: Too many to list, but mismanagement is telling by the number of times the company has reorganized their US operations over the past 5 years.

headline: It was awful, truth be told
pros: It was just an awful place to work, culture, compensation, management. You name it, it was awful
cons: Some colleagues were decent folks but in general everyone was out for themselves.

headline: Big name company but really not very good
pros:
1 Big company
2 Good location
3 Good office
cons:
1 Do not care about employees
2 Long working hours
3 No bonus

headline: Moving in the right direction but rather uninspiring
pros:
Some intelligent people
Decent pay and good benefits
It feels that you are being based on merit and that hard work can pay off
Good place to learn and to start a career
Access to education
UBS is and has been going through a lot of change recently, it feels that it's moving in the right direction but there is still a long way to go and the priorities are not always right.
cons:
Lack of accountability
Middle managers pursuing their own agenda and protecting their own fiefs above anything else
No sense of working together across teams as one company with people constantly trying to push responsibility to someone else
Can be extremely political at times 
Lack of inspiring people in the organisation
Poor infrastructure with lots of systems that do not communicate and no documentation available
Very bureaucratic and corporate
The usual problem with large organisations that senior management live on a different planet to most employees, communicated messages feel completely irrelevant
Long working hours and always low on resources

headline: UBS IB IT Review
pros:
- Lot of good technologies being used
- Very friendly culture
cons:
- Weak management
- No clear direction

headline: UBS : "In Class of its own"
pros: Transparency and professional work culture.
cons: Every firm will have downsides but as far as UBS is concerned its negligible.

headline: Overall a good firm to work but challenging for developing a career.
pros: I feel surrounded by talented individuals who are also fun to work with. The company treats its employees well and I feel a great deal of loyalty to my boss and the firm.
cons: Frustration has stemmed from our inability to avoid negative headlines. On a personal level, sometimes communication regarding firm strategy is lacking.

headline: Lack of appreciation (compensation) for exceptional work ethic
pros: Paid days off - sick and vacation
cons: Once employed, there is growth & movement opportunities within the company- however no salary/compensation increase to follow suit.

headline: Good people but trying to find direction
pros: Good salaries  Smart People Fair Good brand image
cons: Swiss nepotism Short Sitedness  Need to expand other businesses

headline: UBS then and now
pros:
-Financial Advisor centric organization
-Conveniently located to midtown Manhattan
-Beautiful campus on the Hudson, good cafeteria and food court
-A group of extremely talented, dedicated and hard working individuals in home office (IT and marketing organization in particular)
cons:
-Extreme cutbacks have made it impossible to stay current on IT, infrastructure and marketing 
-Senior management priorities change more frequently than I have ever experienced in my 20 year FS career. The outcome of this, has unfortunately had a severe impact on employee moral and unnecessary loss of project dollars and potential revenue

headline: Top wall st firm to work for
pros: Great management team, very focused.
cons: Number 2 and trying harder in US

headline: financial advisor
pros: chance to make a lot of money
cons: it takes at least 3 years to make a lot of money

headline: Good
pros:
Balance of work and life. Mostly nice people. Quite some smart ones
Decent internal opportunities.
cons:
As other large company, it could be bueaructaric.
Sometimes might not be complete fair.

headline: Highly dysfunctional corporate environment
pros:
Diverse organization
Good salary and benefits
Good Business University
cons:
Highly political environment 
Group think is prevalent - the motto of the SDM department is "if you're not with us, you're against us"
Immediate management believes in micro management.
The company is slow to acknowledge and change its bad habits.
Meritocracy does not exist.

headline: Great small wing of UBS AG
pros: Great intimate environment and excellent professionals
cons: Lack of upward mobility in the company

headline: Great Experience
pros:
Diverse workforce
Opportunity to move within the company
Rewarded for great performance
Smart people 
Competitive pay
Training opportunities
cons:
You must be outspoken to be noticed
Long hours

headline: Horrible Chop Shop
pros: Brand recognition (within the industry)
cons:
Low morals
Bad environment
Pure sales enviornment

headline: Good place to work at, with good and bad managers
pros:
International, Diversified, Strong Values, Intelligence
....................
cons:
Offshoring
Non flexible
Cost cutting
Short term view
.......

headline: CSA
pros:
- Friendly environment
- regular work schedule
cons:
- comfortability highly depended on your boss
- minimal potential development opportunities

headline: UBS Finance - probably better look for other options (if you have them)
pros:
Workinh hours are generally not bad. Some manage to work 9 to 5; 9 to 6:30 is probably the norm but some do work till 10pm / midnight (with no reward for that).
Finance has been immune from lay offs - do not know anyone from finance who has been made redundant in the last seven years.
cons:
Poor Pay. Espeially so if you are with UBS for a long time as they tend not to raise it. So you might find that the difference in pay between people doing the same job is as much as 25%-30% which is a lot for finanace.
Politics. Politics. Politics.
Lack of promotion. It is openly admitted by the management that due to very low promotion numbers existing staff are 1-2 ranks bellow equivalent new-comers.
Lots of incompetent, uneducated/unqualified management even in very technical roles.
Poor development and learning oppotunities.
""Take it or Leave it" culture to employee satisfaction.

headline: Unimpressed
pros:
Decent hours (for the most part)
Ok benefits
cons:
Pay 
Lack of support across business functions

headline: Complete chaos with a healthy dose of incompetence and very low moral throughout the office
pros: Back office support was outstanding
cons: Incompetency in management and very low moral throughout the office

headline: Clueless
pros: Great products and some good people.
cons: Management is clueless when it comes to running brokerage business.  They lag in business mix and keeping internal processes up to date.

headline: Poorly managed snake pit
pros:
(Former) good brand
(Former) good people
cons:
Management clearly lack key skills in merger integration, people management
Over-focused on balance sheet
All decisions filter through Switzerland
The great bankers with personality have left

headline: A very nice place to work
pros:
good working environment
helpful management
various growth option inside the company
good increment system
cons:
More focus on transportation system
employee should feel personalized with the HR so that he/she may discuss their problem incase they are facing some

headline: Very Good...
pros:
get to learn
good pay
nice environment to work
cons:
hire and fire attitude
very difficult to get noticed

headline: If you're not driven to be an investment banker, don't work here.
pros: Global investment bank. Potential high salary. Intellectual work (in many roles, not all).
cons: Huge organization. Red tape. Different teams passing responsibility off to other teams. Lack of accountability. Not a fun culture. Lots of people are not motivated or interested in their work.

headline: Fairly Good
pros: Great Managers; benefit package; prestige; work and life balance; Diversity; Training courses; competitive salary; flexible hours; Recruiters more likely to recruit you due to the name
cons: Yearly review process is not practical

headline: A company struggling to grow while cutting costs and shuffling management
pros: Large organization with diverse employees
cons: Highly political culture caused by rapid management turnover in recent years. Middle management is fearful and indecisive, spending effort trying to guess who to support rather than what is the right thing to do.

headline: low morale
pros: your coworkers do try to support each other
cons: there are constant lay offs there

headline: Sweet Company
pros: Sweetness, compassion, awesomeness, benefits and pay
cons: Hours, meaness, lameness, stupidity and red tape

headline: Its Ok .. Nothing great.
pros:
Exposure to huge infrastructure. 
Learning, engagement with cross functional teams..
If are looking to become a process horse
cons:
No Recognition.
Perception based on Networking with other teams, leaders.
Annual review process is completely outdated, zero fair practice.. all perception based.
Very political.

headline: Good
pros: The people are really friendly and respect your values
cons: Working hours are too much

headline: Challenging
pros: Diversity Is great and younger to meet all sorts of people
cons: Bureaucratic, could take a long time to get things done

headline: Easy Internship with No Challenges
pros: Very competitive company in general and you are surrounded by hard working individuals.  It is also a very successful company which helps you succeed if you work hard enough.
cons: Cutthroat business. If you don't put in the hard work and time then you will fail. But then again that might be a pro. It all depends on the type of person you are and what part of the company you join.

headline: It was great.
pros: Good growth opportunities in the firm, good recruitment team.
cons: Bureaucratic, slow, review, feedback, promotions are not transparent and straightforward.

headline: OK
pros: Take it easy culture, not much pressure.
cons: You would not be competing very hard or cutting edge.

headline: Good place to work, very performance oriented
pros: Good exposure in working with some of the best people in the industry. Very competitive and always provide challenges and opportunities for one to shine
cons: Limited resource but expected more to be delivered. A bit too bureaucratic. Dont let too many cooks spoil the broth!

headline: great
pros: great place to work at all levels
cons: too big for entry level pros

headline: Revolving Senior Management
pros: Great group of co-workers, was a prestigious firm and the respect it received was satisfying. Provided customers with a wide spectrum of services.
cons: Senior management didn't know what they wanted other than paying themselves. Big slices of revenue stream to people who'd work there for a year and be replaced.

headline: Great experiance but times are tough at UBS now, opportunities/compensation are minimal
pros: Complex environment, means you have the ability to always learn new things, and grow. People are great, and always helpful.
cons: Short staffed. No compensation at even an ED level. Bonus's are scarce. Many retrenchments. Long hours. Moral is low than normal.

headline: Good place for
pros: Good working hours, supervisor is very understanding and gives time off when you need to leave work. Internship allowance is also not bad.
cons: Interns were encouraged to attend training sessions, which may seem albeit pointless sometimes as it eats into your working hours and does not provide any value added to personal development.

headline: Senior
pros: Research is widely available and good
cons: Incompetent local manegement no growth perspective for front line client facing employees

headline: Just a nice job to have
pros: Looks great on a resume, potential for international travel, and social able employees. The people are generally the nicest you will meet at an IB
cons: Of the top10 IB banks, UBS is probably in the bottom half. NA headquarters is in Stamford Connecticut and that place is just terrible.

headline: Good commute if you live in CT.  Overly bureaucratic, not a place that works smart... Mostly reactive and fire dril mode
pros:
Good commute if you live in ct
Generally nice people to work with
Some really good leaders eg McCann, less so in IB with a few exceptions at functional level
Good pay - competitive with wall street, better than diversified financial services especially for logistics jobs
cons:
Bad commute if you don't live in ct 
Split operations between ny, ct , nj, can make managing and connecting disparate teams a challenge
Not the smartest bunch on the street

headline: Not good
pros: The people you meet there are friends for life. Great employees.
cons: POOR MANAGEMENT at all levels

headline: Positive
pros:
- excellent work-life balance
- good place to "cruise" if you are not very driven
cons:
- very consensus driven
---> results in (1) slow decision making (2) subject "experts" not having to develop detailed knowledge of the areas under their remit

headline: big bank big business
pros: know how, flows, ib & wealth management global presence, jo opportunities in different areas like working in tradig to eave to work to WM
cons: politics, sales and trading relation ships are not built n trust. no one wats to share knowledge or relationships with clients

headline: The best place I ever worked at...
pros: Everything was a "pro" when the market was doing fine.  Still, the company really appreciated its employees, and worked to make sure employees were trained well, gave input, and felt as if they were a part of the team.
cons: The investment bank dictates the organization. They would make the bulk of the money, and create the bulk of company risk. Of course, that means when times are great, everyone prospers. It also means when times are bad everyone suffers. Greed runs deep in this industry and UBS is no immune to that cycle.

headline: Above Average
pros: Nice working places with nice people. I like the culture of the office since everyone is so open and helpful.
cons: If you dont have any real project to do. You will have to deal with the scan machine all day.

headline: Intense and rewarding.
pros:
Big name.
Very nice people there.
Good learning experience.
Nice management.
cons: Not promote as fast as other firms.

headline: Great International Culture with smart and driven people
pros:
* the ibank has a great international sense to is
* Smart leadership typically - 
* good support as far as travelling, etc
cons:
* Tends to be alot of politics
* So big its tough to be noticed or have a major impact

headline: Neutral experience
pros: Flexibility, salary was good as an intern, learn a lot,
cons: lack of feedback, back office can get boring, not much opportunity for promotion

headline: Great Internship to learn if you ask for more work
pros:
-You're given real work 
-You meet great people and participate in corporate events
-You're given ample time to learn what you need to learn for the project
cons:
-Some miscommunication between HR and management about wanting interns. 
-It seemed random who was selected for full-time, some very hard working friends that completed great projects didn't get picked without really knowing why.

headline: Good work, undercut by poor culture
pros: Leader in Australia, good deal flow and brand recognition for CV
cons: Very 1 dimensional people - no real friendships between co-workers. A lot of the people clearly don't enjoy being there.

headline: Low growth
pros: Large firm, fairly open and mgt are ok
cons: Low prospects with pressure but no compensation.  Some people lack respect.

headline: aWesome
pros: Work culture is  really really good.
cons: Sometimes confusing. Have to work with bankers and little knowledge of finance would really help.

headline: Lack of meritocracy. Low compensation
pros: work life balance can be supported working with mgmt
cons: Promotion is based on "who likes you" rather than "what you have done"

headline: Hard to keep clients happy
pros: The pay is OK, but trying to keep clients happy in this poor infrastructure is frustrating.
cons: Communication is a major issue not only without the company but outside. Poor follow-through with accounts leads to dissatisfied customers which leads to loss of accounts. Upward mobility is difficult and some management are poorly chosen.

headline: Fantastic and great.
pros: It has a lot of opportunities to grow your career.
cons: They have been losing a lot of money in the past couple of years.

headline: It was good.
pros: They provided a great working environment and were very supportive. Mostly consisted of teams where I worked. Very good experience.
cons: It wasn't very analytical. A lot of clerical work. Meetings could have been conducted more efficiently. Nothing too bad, though.

headline: Great place to work
cons:
- Not so much room to change certain structures, outdated pathways
- Not so much effort to retain employees

headline: Boring job with data processing
pros: Stable job a lot of room for workspace
cons: Boring job, mess in management, not clear career development policy

headline: I have been recognized and rewarded for the value I have added to the organization.
pros: Collaborative, empowering environment which allows the employees to challenge the norm and participate in perfecting the client experience for our Financial Advisors.
cons: As the culture continues to shift to be client-focused, advisor-centric, there are still indviduals working here who do not understand our overall objective.

headline: Great but frustrating when sent over from overseas
pros: Employees from all over the world work there. In my department where about 15 nationalities in a team of 35. Great for many reasons to work in such multicultural environment
cons: Management still too much Paine Webber oriented

headline: Started out good place to work but eroded as layoffs and lack of direction destroyed morale
pros:
+ good benefit package
+ good vacation time
+ opportunity to work with variety of areas of business
cons:
- poor leadership
- employees undervalued
- little effort toward employee development
- people treated poorly during layoffs

headline: It is a good place to work
pros:
- well organised program
- a lot of constructive feedback
- good work-life balance
cons:
- awful coffee 
- some internal processes are not optimized

headline: Very enjoyable
pros: Good place to work with great team.
cons: Lack of promotion opportunities locally.

headline: I had the opportunity to work in the Salt Lake City offices and it was an awesome experience.
pros:
good work/life balance
excellent benefits
great work environment
competitive salary
cons:
It takes forever to get anything done because of bureaucracy.
It was tough to get  big bonus because company was not doing well financially.

headline: Great place to work but the company is shrinking
pros: Good exposure to different areas and technologies
cons: Still very old technology is used in key application areas

headline: Wealth management good, rest of company needs work
pros: Addition of Bob McCann has help make wealth management the driving force of the company. WM continues to get better and clients are taken care of well.
cons: Investment banking division is not well run. Tough to get good employees when compensation isn't good. Equity research needs improvement as other firms on the street have better research. All comes down to compensation. Compensation across the firm is the biggest weakness.

headline: relatively more friendly compared with other IB
pros: relatively better work life balance
cons: diverse working culture tends to cause conflict

headline: IT Staff at UBS
pros: good opportunity to come up with new ideas. Sometimes if your manager is favorable then you really excel in what you do.
cons: Official politics is way too ooo much... people like to talk and discuss more then doing the real work. Managers do not trust staff that much.

headline: Good place for young, but Bangalore type of work
pros: They pay comparatively well, give you some opportunities to develop. Most people are young and if you're lucky and good enough you can get promotion quite fast. Depending on the post, but sometimes you have lots of free time.
cons: Job itself may be dumb and dull. You cannot negotiate raises and promotions are granted annually. You hardly feel any influence on your benchmark.

headline: good place to work
pros: the work life balance  is good
cons: it is not easy to move internally

headline: Positive work environment which allows to reshape an industry leader
pros:
+ opportunity to join a company which is at/ behind turning point after financial crisis
+ be with the industry leader in global wealth management with outstanding investment products and services, stemming from a strong capital markets (& IB) franchise
+ opportunities for international career progression
cons: - at times feels a bit too much as rule-based organization

headline: Excellent
pros: Good work environment. Gets chance to balance both personal life and professional life.
cons: not dynamic. do not accept changes quickly

headline: A rewarding career so far with stints in Finance, HR and Risk
pros: Internal mobility is one of the best reasons to come and stay at UBS.  I"ve moved around quite a bit and seen my compensation grow exponentially, even through the various financial crises. I've lived in London for a couple years and have traveled to Singapore and Zurich during my time with UBS.
cons: Swiss culture/mindset is very different than the US, as is the wealth management culture (incl. WMA) vs. the investment bank. This can be incredibly frustrating.

headline: OK
pros: UBS is an OK to work but the opportunity is very lackluster
cons: UBS is an OK to work but the opportunity is very lackluster in growth

headline: Rife with politics and infighting... no team vibe
pros: There are good people here
cons: Not team oriented, too political.  Some individuals in power make decisions that cause untold harm to profitability and higher ups seem blind to this.  No solution in sight.

headline: In one sentence, lacking and disappointing would describe my overall experience with UBS.
pros:
* Decent work/life balance
* Technology overall
* Core branch team
* Benefits
cons:
* Complex Management
* Micromanagement 
* Firm/Complex-forced goals vs. branch needs
* Lack of support locally
* Lack of needed personnel
* Overworked at operational level

headline: Good look at WM industry...depends on the office you are working in
pros: Interning at UBS is a great opportunity to see how a top tier financial firm operates. If you work in the right WM group, you will learn a lot about the business.
cons: Experience completely depends on the office you are assigned to work with. You could get stuck with a jerk boss who makes you cold call from 9 to 5 (or even longer). Or you can have a great office to work in where you will actually do some finance stuff and learn.

headline: Great culture and people, excellent place to work at
pros:
- Great culture and people/colleagues/friends
- Most supervisors and directors are friendly and mixes with the analyst and associates
- Good amount of deal flow
- Great brand name in Asia
- Don't really have a culture of "Face-time"
cons:
- Bonus pool has been decreasing during the past few years
- Brand name not as strong as other top players in the US
- Defection of top dealmakers to rivals recently, affecting deal flow
- Hours are quite long

headline: good but very busy
pros: you get to work with people from all over the world. there are always events going on to try to boost employee morale. the company has taken a few financial hits but has bounced back due their security initiatives.
cons: outsourcing of jobs. working with limited resources.

headline: Very Flexible Employer, Nice People, but prospects of growth are nonexistent
pros: The culture is very laid back. It is not an entirely unpleasant place to work. It is not a high pressure environment, work is usually assigned with ample time to complete it.
cons: You work and never really see the results, things are very bureaucratic and political.  The environment makes delivering a good product very hard.  It is very rigid in some senses and not structured at all in other ways which are actually more relevant to what is produced software wise.

headline: I found my time at UBS to be very rewarding and very hands on.
pros: The people, the environment, the hours
cons: very busy and at times stressful

headline: It was a good learning experience, but a little dry.
pros:
-It has a great brand.
-Opportunity to work your way up.
-Lots of motivated people
-Good culture and business environment
cons:
-They have really old technology.
-People have been around forever.
-The firm is generally very thinly staffed
-need to work way more hard to get bonus

headline: Good
pros: Good Salary+benefits,brand name,work home balance.
cons: Insecurity of a layoff due to banking industry  crunches nowadays.You don't know what will happen just tommorow in the office.

headline: Very unprofessional experience -
pros:
High Compensation
Great Location
Decents Reputation
Great Middle Management
cons:
Long hours
No work life balance
Extensive unproductive projects
No strategy communicated

headline: not very good
pros: easy commute, outside of high management mostly decent people
cons: horrible leadership. used to be if not pru then go away, now if not merrill you  are nothing

headline: Poor Experience in Private Wealth Management
pros: Brand name wirehouse so that definitely helps
cons: This is true only for Private Wealth Management, but the Corporate Management seemed to place results above all else without regard to their employees

headline: I was especially pleased with the quality of my co-workers!
pros: Fine co-workers, good communication from management.
cons: Most employees have high workloads.

headline: UBS is a decent place to work. It really depends on which group you are in.
pros: Well established in the industry, good working atmosphere, good colleagues
cons: Unstable upper management, lot of internal politics, disparity between workers etc.

headline: Great
pros: Unique opportunity for growth whereyou can continue to acquire skills and to develop your career. Exciting and challenging working environment. Limitless opportunities.
cons: The firm is generally very thinly staffed. When it works well, it provides for a rich and intense experience, rapid learning, great advancement in exposure and responsibility.

headline: Good pace, opportunities are few but great
pros: Better atmosphere than most finance jobs.
cons: People can be difficult.  If you are not in, then you are out.

headline: Fair enough
pros: More laid back than other places. Good name on your resume. Overall seniors are nice (but really depends on who is your manager). Excellent benefits package. Better hours than other banks.
cons: Be aware of headcount and low total comp due to the massive losses in 2008-2011 (altough it's much better to work here than landing a job in the industry, or working at a boutique firm). UBS is also struggling to win local market; hopefully things will get better in the upcoming years

headline: I learned a lot and gained valuable experience
pros: UBS is full of smart and hard working people who appreciate a social environment and have a good client focus.
cons: Hard to get involved if you are younger and less experienced in the field.

headline: A great learning internship site
pros: UBS is dedicated to furthering knowledge of the employee and getting them to be the very best that he or she can be.
cons: When I worked with UBS the site was more focused on getting me to learn about the industry in general rather that their own company

headline: It was productive
pros:
1. compensation is competitive
2. team relationships are quite friendly
3. if you are not working with clients, starting time is flexible
cons: There was not good project management staff. They have project management office but  most of project managers are product of hallo effect and they do not have good understanding of project management

headline: OK
pros: Relative security of job ?
cons: Opportunities of growth and promotion very different in the bank.

headline: not a great place to be
pros: Not as demanding in terms of hours,
cons: low employee moral and does not compensate competitively

headline: exciting
pros: salary is above the industry mean . with signing bonus . team is friendly and competitive . overall not bad to be a starting place
cons: low reputation at all fields except fx . the bank is suffering from huge losses and due to CHF appreciation . need ot work way more hard to get bonus

headline: Great Global Opportunity to Develop your skill set
pros:
-Global presence and ability to view regions and how they perform and respond to challenges
-Good open-minded management
-Handles stressful financial system shocks well with foresight and planning
cons:
-Too risk averse at times in responding to challenges 
-lacks innovation in some areas and is a follower in other areas, not a leader

headline: It was a laid-back environment.
pros: It was laid-back and reserved in terms of the environment, yet provided a great exposure to the finance industry which I enjoyed.
cons: Some may view the environment as not very challenging or stimulating.  It can also be frustrating to deal with certain clients.

headline: It was a good experience
pros: UBS has a Recognizable name. It looks good on resume
cons: It is hard to move up within the company. No growth opportunity

headline: great experience, great corporate culture and environment
pros: good salary, good exposure, good environment and exit opportunities for growth, good networking options and corporate culture is extremely accomodating and helpful
cons: career growth might be stunted sometimes also they have to keep bailing out the IB industry hence sometimtes salaries arent as good some years.

headline: Difficult to find opportunities for advancement, and employee morale is quite low
pros: UBS is an internationally recognized financial services firm and a leader in the wealth  management space. Good to have on the resume.
cons: The firm is exiting many of its business and downsizing, thereby forcing employees to take on more responsibilities with few resources.

headline: Good training program if you can stand you office.
pros: Great facilities and locations to work. Product line is competitive with other firms and private wealth management shops and family offices.
cons: Long hours to make it as an advisor at any major brokerage firm. Once training is over you are on your own to sink or swim.

headline: Changes need to be made to return it to the firm it use to be..
pros: In the past, a great place to work, a lot of knowledge sharing and a true teamwork environment. In the current downsizing environment, it's not the case, and constant change in management, that is not always the best person or most qualified.
cons: No stability from management,  no clear communication of where the company is headed, in terms of outsources, group consolidations etc.

headline: It was not too bad :]
pros:
Matured Organization and decent people management skills.
Management ready to provide last min emergency off without fuss
Salary wise ok well that also depends upon your negotiation with the staffing agency.
cons:
Well i was a contractor so really no benefits from UBS HR or as such. No trainings, no clear career growth, no progression or work for very long to become eligible to get into perm role. I think its better to join ubs as perm staff than a contract

No input requested from contract staff when making decision effecting the way contract staff works

headline: A great learning experience.
pros: There are many groups within the firm that allow an employee to grow and excel. If one has an opportunity to join such a group, chances for advancement (career & salary) are incredibly high. Most importantly, these groups provide the employee with broad experience firm wide.
cons: Employee's who work for the service group have a less chance of advancement. There are many layers of management within the group that it makes it practically impossible to advance. The most advancement one might receive is just a transfer to a different group within the service group. Salary advancement is very minimal.

headline: Life changing
pros: Opportunities to succeed are there if you have the right attiude.  Have been able to try a few different things whch is motivating.
cons: Current issues are applicable to industry in general, but always being pushed to do more with less.  Sometimes the less is just not enough.

headline: Overall an okay experience, but depending on the group
pros: My group had a great culture and I definitely learned a lot during the first year in my position. There were a lot of trainings (lunch n learn, training the street, etc.).
cons: Constant management change, unclear strategy, lower comps than the rest of Wall Street firms. The corporate culture is mixed and your experience will depend a lot on the specific group you are in.

headline: One I would not want to repeat or recommend to others.
pros: The benefits package is quite flexible and generally good.
cons:
Lacks consistent vision.
Too many management changes, leading to changes in vision.
Too slow to make decisions. 
Simple decisions need to go to senior management when they should be dealt with by more junior management.

headline: My experience with UBS was rewarding.  I have learned much and have met very smart people.
pros:
-UBS provides a wide variety of computer based training toolkits which is easily accessible to all employees.  If you ever have any down-time, you can always use it to learn a new skill.  
-Ability to work from remote location.
-Great benefits
cons: -The constant changes in strategic tools can, at times, make it difficult to get work completed in a timely manner.

headline: Valuable work experience, smart, nice colleagues.
pros:
Valuable work experience
smart and nice colleagues
Recognizable company name
Balanced work and life
Prudent investment culture
Relatively good compensation
cons: It distributes bonus and announce promotion in late Feb or March, obviously just to keep people staying without paying them.

headline: nice place to work, some opp. but as usuall in a large company lots of politics.
pros: people are good here and suppportive
cons: you can get lost if you dont aline yourself with a project or team.
